column11:
The 1C FBU USA Release EPIC encompasses all foundational capabilities required to support the launch of the One Customer model for Food & Beverage (F&B) United USA accounts, as part of the global customer unification program. (This EPIC leverages Release 1 efforts which were focused on Canada.)This release focuses TBD aligning commercial activities to a single experience.  This release focuses on enabling a centralized Base Customer Account (BCA) structure with aligned sales skill records (e.g., Water and Hygiene), standardizing CRM processes, and ensuring system readiness across CRM, CDM, EBS, PowerApps, and reporting platforms. 
  

  
Key objectives include:   

 *  Identify the impact OneCustomer Release 1 will have on USA accounts. Release 1:  

 *  Establishing a dedicated Base Customer Account entity in CRM (Option 1 model)  
 *  Aligning Water and Hygiene sales skill records under BCA with proper security, filtering, and metadata visibility 
 *  Updating integrations between CRM, CDM, and Ecolab 3D to support new customer hierarchy and merged site logic 
 *  Enabling clean site/asset lineage and downstream compatibility with PowerApps and Power BI 
 *  Harmonizing business processes such as opportunity management, RTW, GTW, and contact handling across sales skills
 
 

 

 *  Review and validate as-is record structure and process flow for:   
 

 *  Tanks 
 *  EQR (Engineering Quote Request) 
 *  Ecolab3D– Service Summary Dashboard Integrations 
 *  Documents stored in CRM related to OneCustomer impacted records 
 *  Leads & TVD 
 *  Services 
 *  Power Apps? 
 

 

 *  Supporting critical regression testing for existing functionality affected by the structural changes 
 

This EPIC represents all business and technical requirements identified during the 10-day discovery workshops and stakeholder alignment sessions held August 18, 2025 - August 29, 2025.

column6: Integration: Prospect to Customer Setup Process Enablement via CLM (R2)
column11:
This feature will enable CRM to integrate directly with CLM APIs for the prospect-to-customer setup process as part of the One Customer Initiative. Today, during R1, Sales Ops would use their judgement to prevent duplicates in CRM and enter data into MDM via CLM UI manually. After the Sales Representative indicates that the prospect is ready to be converted to customer via the Dynamics CRM UI, Sales Operations (ops Admin) these as customer in CLM UI manually  which in turn triggers a transaction to MDM to start the customer setup process.
 

 
In R2, the process will shift to automation:
 

 *  Prospects created in CRM will automatically be validated, deduplicated, and processed via CLM (MDM) APIs. 
 *  Upon conversion, the Base Customer Account (BCA) and linked sales skill accounts will be updated seamlessly in CRM. 
 *  Duplicate checks will evolve to support the new sales skill model, ensuring no duplicate creation and enabling “add sales skill” scenarios. 
 *  CRM users will benefit from fewer manual steps, reduced risk of errors, and stronger alignment with MDM/EBS master data. 
 

 
Key Changes Introduced 

 *  Automate prospect creation flow between CRM ? CLM ? MDM. 
 *  Automate prospect-to-customer conversion by consuming CLM APIs directly. 
 *  Enhance duplicate check logic to align with sales skill model (multiple sales skills per site/address). 
 *  Support a new “add sales skill” integration path to append sales skills to existing customers. 
 *  Maintain CRM/MDM/EBS alignment using the Base Customer Account as the anchor identifier. 
 *  Provide clear ID and status synchronization across all systems (CRM, CLM, MDM, and EBS). 
 

 
High-Level Business Requirements 

 *  Automated Prospect Processing 

 *  When a prospect is created in CRM, the record must be automatically sent to MDM through CLM APIs for validation, duplicate check, and ID assignment. 
 

 *  Seamless Conversion to Customer 

 *  Upon prospect approval and conversion in CLM, the BCA and sales skill accounts in CRM must be automatically updated with the new ERP/MDM identifiers and ERP status set to Customer. 
 

 *  Duplicate Detection & Sales Skill Handling 

 *  If a duplicate is found, CRM must receive feedback from CLM to either: 

 *  Block creation of a new prospect, or 
 *  Create a new sales skill under an existing customer BCA. 
 

 

 *  Add Sales Skill Support 

 *  Provide integration path for CRM ? CLM ? MDM when a rep or Sales Ops adds a new sales skill to an existing customer account. 
 

 *  ID & Status Synchronization 

 *  CRM must maintain consistent BCAID, Sales Skill IDs, and ERP system identifiers across MDM/EBS/CLM. 
 *  ERP status transitions (prospect ? customer) must flow automatically into CRM. 
 

 *  User Experience Improvements 

 *  Eliminate manual form submissions (Ops Admin, emails). 
 *  Ensure CRM users see accurate prospect/customer statuses without requiring back-and-forth with Sales Ops. 
 

 *  Future-Proofing 

 *  Follow the CLM API roadmap to ensure a single-pass, simplified process in later releases. 
 *  Build flexibility for additional validations (address normalization, fuzzy match, etc.) to be applied via MDM.

column7: Consume CLM API Responses to Handle Duplicates and Add Sales Skills
column11:
Business Objective:
Enable CRM to intelligently respond to CLM/MDM validation outcomes during prospect creation. When a duplicate is detected, CRM must either block the creation of a new record or seamlessly trigger the addition of a new sales skill to the existing customer/prospect. This ensures data integrity, prevents duplicate accounts, and supports multi–sales skill structures in line with the One Customer model. 

 
Business Requirements: 

 *  During prospect creation in CRM: 

 *  Duplicate Check via CLM API: 

 *  CRM sends prospect data (name, address, district, sales skill). 
 

 *  CLM/MDM responds with one of three outcomes: 

 *  No match found ? Prospect creation proceeds as new Prospect BCA + Sales Skill Account. 
 *  Duplicate prospect found ? CRM blocks new creation, and user must use existing prospect record. 
 *  Existing customer found ? CRM must allow rep/ops to add a new sales skill to the existing BCA. 
 

 

 *  Blocking Rules: 

 *  Duplicate creation attempts must be stopped before a new P-number or BCA is assigned. 
 *  A clear message should guide the rep to the existing record. 
 

 *  Add Sales Skill Flow: 

 *  If CLM response indicates “existing customer,” CRM should trigger the “Add Sales Skill” process: 
 *  Create a new Sales Skill Account under the existing BCA. 
 *  Ensure correct linkage between BCA, Sales Skill Account, and ERP identifiers. 
 *  Status initially set to Pending Review until approved by Sales Ops (R2 automation). 
 

 *  Business Ownership: 

 *  Sales Ops retains authority to review final duplicate resolution in CRM. 
 *  Reps are prevented from bypassing the duplicate check by manually creating accounts. 
 

 

 
Technical Considerations: 

 *  CRM must consume and parse CLM API response codes for duplicates and matches. 
 *  Ensure synchronous handling so that users get immediate feedback on duplicate attempts. 
 *  Error scenarios: 

 *  If API fails or times out, fallback rule = prospect saved in Pending Review, flagged for Sales Ops review. 
 

 *  Mapping required between CLM-provided IDs and CRM IDs for record linking. 
 *  Ensure that “Add Sales Skill” triggered from CLM response is logged with traceability (audit trail). 
 *  Need to align with existing “Add Sales Skill” button logic to avoid duplicative implementations. 
 

 
Expected Deliverables: 

 *  CRM integrated with CLM duplicate-check API during prospect creation. 
 *  Automated handling of three outcomes: new prospect, duplicate block, or add sales skill. 
 *  Prevent duplicate account proliferation by enforcing CLM response logic. 
 *  Ability to expand existing customers with additional sales skills without creating duplicate accounts. 
 *  Documentation of response handling, error fallback, and process ownership. 
 *  Test scenarios covering: 
 *  No match (new prospect creation). 
 *  Duplicate prospect (blocked). 
 *  Existing customer (add sales skill).

column7: Automate Prospect-to-Customer Conversion Across CRM, CLM, MDM, and EBS
column11:
Business Objective:
Ensure seamless conversion of approved prospects into active customers by synchronizing CRM with CLM, MDM, and EBS. When a prospect is approved in CLM, the corresponding CRM records (Prospect BCA and linked Sales Skill accounts) must automatically update with the official ERP customer number and correct ERP status, eliminating manual intervention and ensuring system-wide consistency. 

 

 
Business Requirements:
 

 *  When Sales Ops approves a prospect in CLM: 

 *  CLM triggers the conversion process by sending details to MDM. 
 *  MDM processes the request and passes it to EBS for official customer account creation. 
 *  EBS generates the ERP customer number and returns it to MDM, which then flows back to CLM and CRM. 
 

 *  In CRM, the following updates must occur automatically: 

 *  Prospect BCA: 

 *  ERP Status flips from Prospect ? Customer. 
 *  ERP Customer Number is populated. 
 

 *  Sales Skill Accounts linked to the Prospect BCA: 

 *  Account Type flips from Prospect ? Customer. 
 *  ERP Customer Number is populated on each linked account. 
 

 *  Ownership: Updated to reflect any new ownership logic coming from CLM/MDM. 
 

 *  
 
 *  Status transitions must be fully automated with no manual updates in CRM. 
 *  All related downstream entities (opportunities, contacts, service records) must retain their links to the updated Customer accounts. 
 

 
Technical Considerations: 

 *  CRM must consume CLM/MDM integration events that include the official ERP Customer Number and updated status. 
 *  Update logic in CRM must ensure both the BCA and all linked Sales Skill Accounts remain synchronized. 
 *  Error handling: 

 *  If an ERP number is not received, the conversion should not complete in CRM. 
 *  Partial updates must be avoided; CRM should roll back or retry until successful. 
 

 *  Data mapping must include: 

 *  Prospect BCA ? Customer BCA. 
 *  Prospect ERP Status ? Customer ERP Status. 
 *  Sales Skill Account Type ? Customer. 
 *  ERP Number population at both BCA and Sales Skill levels. 
 

 *  Ownership sync: Clarify whether CRM should always overwrite ownership from CLM/MDM or allow manual override. 
 

 
Expected Deliverables: 

 *  Automated prospect-to-customer conversion process integrated across CRM, CLM, MDM, and EBS. 
 *  CRM records (BCA and Sales Skill accounts) automatically updated with ERP numbers and status changes. 
 *  ERP Status transitions (Prospect ? Customer) reflected consistently in both BCA and Sales Skill accounts. 
 *  Documentation of integration mapping, status transitions, and test cases. 
 *  Error-handling and retry mechanism for failed updates.

column8: Technical Spike: Validate EIN (Employee ID) Formatting in CRM – Leading Zeros, Data Quality, and Downstream Impact Assessment
column11:
As a CRM team,
I want to assess EIN formatting requirements (including leading zeros) and analyze downstream impacts of any normalization or data fix,
 
so that we can confidently pass a correct EIN to CLM and maintain consistency across CRM and dependent systems.
 

 
Background: 

 *  CRM will pass the rep’s EIN / Workday Employee ID (stored on System User as ECL_EmployeeId) as part of the CLM Launch context. We have identified potential data quality issues where some EIN values that should include leading zeros may be stored in CRM without them (e.g., 00123456 stored as 123456). Workday EIN length can vary (currently observed 6–8 digits), which creates ambiguity on whether CRM should: 

 *  Normalize at runtime (pad with leading zeros to 8 characters only when sending to CLM), or 
 *  Clean the source data in CRM (update user records to match the authoritative Workday/EBS source), with governance and downstream impact validation. 
 

 *  Before choosing an approach, we need to confirm: 

 *  the authoritative source and expected canonical format (exact string as Workday stores it) 
 *  if CRM and downstream systems (Power BI, integrations, reports, security mapping, etc.) assume a specific EIN format/length 
 *  whether leading-zero updates could break joins, historical reporting, or identity mapping 
 

 

Spike Objective
 
 

 *  Determine the correct EIN format and the safest remediation approach (runtime normalization vs. CRM data fix), including downstream impact analysis, and produce a recommended implementation plan.
column19: Moved out of state Sprint Ready
column22:
In Scope
 

 *  Current-state assessment of SystemUser.ECL_EmployeeId: 

 *  field type, max length, nullability, usage 
 *  frequency of EIN values by length (6/7/8) and suspected missing leading zeros 
 *  the team should document: 

 *  field schema (type, length, required/optional) 
 *  sample data patterns (6/7/8 digits, alphanumeric if any) 
 *  count of users by EIN length 
 *  count of suspected “missing leading zero” cases (based on comparison logic or authoritative source workday) 
 

 

 *  Determine canonical EIN representation: 

 *  confirm if Workday treats EIN as a string identifier (not numeric) 
 *  confirm whether leading zeros are meaningful and must be preserved 
 

 *  Evaluate solution approaches: 

 *  Option A: runtime normalization when building CLM token (e.g., pad-left to 8 only when appropriate) 
 *  Option B: one-time CRM data cleanup to correct stored EIN values to match authoritative system 
 

 *  Downstream impact assessment. Create an Inventory List: 

 *  each dependent system/artifact (Power BI datasets/reports, integrations, Snowflake views, ADF pipelines, etc.) 
 *  how EIN is used (join key, display field, filter, export) 
 *  risk rating per dependency (Low/Med/High) 
 *  required remediation per dependency if EIN format changes 
 

 *  Produce recommendation + implementation plan + risks 

 *  preferred approach (Option A or Option B, or hybrid) 
 *  exact normalization rule (if Option A) 
 *  scope + steps for one-time cleanup (if Option B) 
 *  list of follow-on user stories needed (data fix story, reporting updates, regression tests, comms/training

column9: Analysis of CDM and Service order integration for EIN field format change
column11: This task involves analyzing the CDM and Service Order integration for both EBS and NSAP to assess whether changes in the EIN format impact the integration. It also includes identifying the relevant code and coordinating with the respective teams as needed.

column8: Technical Spike: CRM Tokenized CLM Launch – AES-GCM POC, Key Storage Design, and Implementation Approach
column11:
As a CRM technical Architect ,
I want to prototype and document the end-to-end approach for launching CLM using a tokenized (encrypted) URL,
 
so that we can confirm feasibility, align on best practices (especially key storage), and unblock secure implementation for CLM launch.
 

 

Background: 
 

 *  To support secure launch of CLM from CRM without exposing PII (e.g., rep email/EIN) in URL query parameters, we will implement a tokenized launch pattern where CRM generates an encrypted token (primary approach: AES-GCM) and appends only the token to the CLM launch URL. CLM will decrypt the token server-side and route the user to the correct account. 
 *  Attached is a working AES-GCM console sample that demonstrates encryption/decryption and (optionally) token expiry logic. This spike is to prove the CRM implementation path (Ribbon button ? JS ? Custom API/Action/Plugin ? token ? URL launch) and to finalize key storage best practices. 
 *  A secondary exploration (time-permitting) is to assess feasibility of RS-256-based JWE as an alternative (without making it a required deliverable for this spike).
column19: Moved out of state In Development
column22:
In Scope
 

 *  Implement POC flow for AES-GCM token generation from CRM on button click: 

 *  Ribbon/Command Bar button 
 *  JavaScript handler to gather required fields 
 *  Invoke server-side logic (Custom API / Custom Action / Plugin) 
 *  Return encrypted token to JS 
 *  Build CLM launch URL and open CLM in new tab/window 
 

 *  Document recommended approach for: 

 *  Where/how AES key is stored 
 *  Rotation strategy and environment separation 
 *  Logging/telemetry guidance (no PII) 
 *  Error handling and fallbacks 
 

 *  Validate decryption compatibility assumptions with CLM (at least at interface level) 
 *  POC validation of decryption
 

 *  Given the generated token from CRM, 
 *  When it is decrypted using the paired AES-GCM decryption routine (test harness/console validation is acceptable for spike), 
 *  Then the decrypted payload matches the original inputs exactly and proves round-trip integrity. 
 

 *  Token expiry approach documented and proven
 
 *  Key storage decision documented 

 *  POC implementation in CRM (lower env acceptable): 
 *  button + JS 
 *  Custom API/Action/Plugin token generator (AES-GCM) 
 *  sample generated token output 
 

 *  Get sign off from Enterprise Architect and CLM & CRM Technical Stakeholders on the encryption approach 

 

 

Open Questions (track within spike)
 
 

 *  Should token generation be via Custom API vs Custom Action + Plugin (team recommendation)? 
 *  Where will we store the AES key: 

 *  Integration Settings table 
 *  Environment Variable (Dataverse) 
 *  Azure Key Vault (if available) + retrieval pattern 
 

 *  Do we need per-environment keys and rotation cadence?

column8: CRM – Show Launch CLM Button on Customer and Prospect Accounts
column11:
As a Sales Operations user
I want a Launch CLM action on eligible account records
 
So that I can initiate customer conversion or add a sales skill in CLM using the correct account and user context, without manual re-entry or ambiguity.

 
Business Objective and Background: 
Enable Sales Operations users to seamlessly initiate prospect-to-customer conversion and add new sales skills to existing customers by launching the CLM UI directly from CRM, while preserving context (account and user) and ensuring a controlled, auditable process. 

 *  In the One Customer (1C) model, customer creation and sales skill expansion are executed in CLM after Sales Ops approval in CRM. 
 *  CRM is the system of record for: 

 *  Prospect approval 
 *  Sales skill setup 
 *  BCA relationships 
 *  MDM identifiers 
 

 *  CLM is the system of execution for: 

 *  Customer creation 
 *  Adding sales skills to existing customers 
 

 *  To avoid manual searching and reduce errors, CRM must provide a Launch CLM action that passes sufficient context to CLM. CRM does not perform customer conversion logic; it only initiates the process and tracks outcomes returned by CLM and MDM. 
 

 
This story covers only CRM responsibilities. 
 

 
Functional Scope

 *  This story includes: 

 *  CRM ribbon button creation 
 *  Role-based visibility rules 
 *  Parameterized CLM URL construction 
 *  Launch behavior (parameterized and fallback) 
 *  Status tracking and validation of CLM/MDM updates (no new integrations) 
 

 *  This story does not include: 

 *  CLM UI development 
 *  CLM security implementation 
 *  IF-17 or MDM logic changes (validation only)
column19: Moved out of state In Test
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria 

 *  Button Visibility – Prospect Conversion 

 *  Given an 1C prospect with Approval Status = Approved, with MDM Number and BCA populated 
 *  And the user is a Sales Ops user 
 *  When the account form is opened 
 *  Then the “Launch CLM” button must be visible after the button + New 
 

 *  Button Visibility – For Adding Sales Skill to 1C Customer Account 

 *  Given an active 1C customer account 
 *  And the user is a Sales Ops user 
 *  And Approval Status = Pending 
 *  When the account form is opened 
 *  Then the “Launch CLM” button must be visible after the button + New 
 

 *  Non-Functional Requirements 

 *  URL construction must be configurable via environment variables 
 *  No hard-coded environment URLs 
 *  No sensitive data stored in CRM beyond existing fields 
 *  CRM must not block or delay user interaction if CLM is unavailable 
 

 

Additional Notes:  
 

 *  Launch CLM Action – Behavior Overview 

 *  Button launches CLM in a new browser tab 
 *  Button supports: 

 *  Prospect ? Customer conversion 
 *  Add Sales Skill to existing customer 
 

 *  Button passes agreed query parameters 
 *  CRM gracefully handles cases where CLM does not yet support parameterization 
 

 *  Launch CLM Button – Visibility Rules 

 *  Button is VISIBLE when ALL conditions are met 

 *  User role = Sales Ops 
 *  Account is linked to a 1C-enabled district 
 *  Account Status = Active 
 *  Account Type: 

 *  Prospect (approved) OR 
 *  Customer (active) for add-sales-skill scenario 
 

 *  MDM Number is populated 
 *  Base Customer Account (BCA) is populated 
 *  ERP Account Status: 

 *  Prospect (for conversion) 
 *  Customer (for add sales skill) 
 

 

 *  Button is HIDDEN when ANY condition is not true

column8: CRM – Launch CLM for Customer Conversion and Adding Sales Skill (IF17)
column11:
As a Sales Operations user
I want a Launch CLM action on eligible account records
 
So that I can initiate customer conversion or add a sales skill in CLM using the correct account and user context, without manual re-entry or ambiguity.

 
Business Objective and Background: 
Enable Sales Operations users to seamlessly initiate prospect-to-customer conversion and add new sales skills to existing customers by launching the CLM UI directly from CRM, while preserving context (account and user) and ensuring a controlled, auditable process. 

 *  In the One Customer (1C) model, customer creation and sales skill expansion are executed in CLM after Sales Ops approval in CRM. 
 *  CRM is the system of record for: 

 *  Prospect approval 
 *  Sales skill setup 
 *  BCA relationships 
 *  MDM identifiers 
 

 *  CLM is the system of execution for: 

 *  Customer creation 
 *  Adding sales skills to existing customers 
 

 *  To avoid manual searching and reduce errors, CRM must provide a Launch CLM action that passes sufficient context to CLM. CRM does not perform customer conversion logic; it only initiates the process and tracks outcomes returned by CLM and MDM. 
 

 
This story covers only CRM responsibilities. 
 

 
Functional Scope

 *  This story includes: 

 *  CRM ribbon button creation 
 *  Role-based visibility rules 
 *  Parameterized CLM URL construction 
 *  Launch behavior (parameterized and fallback) 
 *  Status tracking and validation of CLM/MDM updates (no new integrations) 
 

 *  This story does not include: 

 *  CLM UI development 
 *  CLM security implementation 
 *  IF-17 or MDM logic changes (validation only)
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria 

 *  Button Visibility – Prospect Conversion (covered in story #894136) 

 *  Given an 1C prospect with Approval Status = Approved, with MDM ID and BCA populated 
 *  And the user is a Sales Ops user 
 *  When the account form is opened 
 *  Then the “Launch CLM” button must be visible 
 

 *  Button Visibility – For Adding Sales Skill to 1C Customer Account (covered in story #894136) 

 *  Given an active 1C customer account 
 *  And the user is a Sales Ops user 
 *  And Approval Status = Pending 
 *  When the account form is opened 
 *  Then the “Launch CLM” button must be visible 
 

 

 *  Launch Behavior 

 *  Given a Sales Ops user clicks the “Launch CLM” button 
 *  When all required CRM data is available 
 *  Then CLM must open in a new browser tab 
 *  And the URL must include all defined query parameters (TBD)) 
 

 *  Parameterized Routing Success (Validation Only) 

 *  Given CLM supports parameterized routing 
 *  When the CLM URL is launched 
 *  Then CLM must open the corresponding account context automatically 
 

 *  Parameterized Routing Not Available (Validation Only) 

 *  Given CLM does not yet support parameterized routing 
 *  When the CLM URL is launched 
 *  Then the CLM home page must load without error 
 *  And the user can manually search for the account 
 

 *  Submission Tracking (Validation Only) 

 *  Given the Sales Ops user submits customer conversion in CLM 
 *  When CLM sends updates back to CRM 
 *  Then CRM must reflect: 

 *  MDM Status update (e.g., Customer Conversion Submitted)  
 *  Correlation ID populated 
 *  No additional CRM logic is executed beyond validation 
 

 

 *  Post-Conversion Validation 

 *  Given IF-17 updates are received 
 *  When CRM processes the update 
 *  Then: 

 *  Account Type must update correctly (Customer) 
 *  ERP Account Status must update correctly (Active) 
 *  Account Number must populate (EBS Account Number/Source Account Number) 
 *  BCA and all related sales skill accounts must reflect the same account number 
 

 *  IF17 Attribute mapping to validate (No Dev work needed on the CRM side as part of this user story and IF17 is built by the MDM team, the only effort needed here is validation) 
 *

 *  Non-Functional Requirements 

 *  URL construction must be configurable via environment variables 
 *  No hard-coded environment URLs 
 *  No sensitive data stored in CRM beyond existing fields 
 *  CRM must not block or delay user interaction if CLM is unavailable 
 

 

Additional Notes:  
 

 *  Launch CLM Action – Behavior Overview 

 *  Button launches CLM in a new browser tab 
 *  Button supports: 

 *  Prospect ? Customer conversion 
 *  Add Sales Skill to existing customer 
 

 *  Button passes agreed query parameters 
 *  CRM gracefully handles cases where CLM does not yet support parameterization 
 

 *  Launch CLM Button – Visibility Rules 

 *  Button is VISIBLE when ALL conditions are met 

 *  User role = Sales Ops 
 *  Account is linked to a 1C-enabled district 
 *  Account Status = Active 
 *  Account Type: 

 *  Prospect (approved) OR 
 *  Customer (active) for add-sales-skill scenario 
 

 *  MDM ID is populated 
 *  Base Customer Account (BCA) is populated 
 *  ERP Account Status: 

 *  Prospect (for conversion) 
 *  Customer (for add sales skill) 
 

 

 *  Button is HIDDEN when ANY condition is not true 
 

 *  CLM URL Parameterization (CRM Responsibility) 

 *  CRM constructs a parameterized URL using integration settings and runtime data. 

 *  Parameters passed by CRM 

 *  sourceSystem = CRM 
 *  action = ConvertCustomer OR AddSalesSkill 
 *  crmId = CRM Account GUID 
 *  mdmId = MDM ID 
 *  mdmAccountId = MDM Account ID (if available) 
 *  repEmail = Primary Owner Email 
 *  repEIN = Primary Owner Workday / EIN 
 

 

 

 *  Fallback Behavior 

 *  If CLM does not yet support parameterized routing: 
 *  CLM UI opens to home page 
 *  User manually searches for the account 
 *  No CRM change required once CLM enables parameter handling

column8: CRM – Create “1C – Prospects Ready for Customer Conversion” View
column11:
As a Sales Operations user
I want a CRM view that clearly lists all approved 1C prospects that are eligible for customer conversion
 
So that I can efficiently identify, filter, and prioritize prospects that are ready to be converted to customers using CLM, without manually inspecting multiple records.
 

 
Business Context / Background 

 *  In the One Customer (1C) model, prospect-to-customer conversion is a controlled Sales Ops–led process. Only prospects that have completed address validation, duplicate checks, Sales Ops approval, and MDM onboarding are eligible for customer conversion. 
 *  This user story introduces a dedicated operational queue—“1C – Prospects Ready for Customer Conversion”—that serves as the single source of truth for Sales Ops to identify and act on eligible prospects. 
 *  This view is a prerequisite for the CLM launch action implemented in a subsequent user story.
column19: Moved out of state In QA
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria: 

 *  Eligibility Inclusion 

 *  Given an account is a Prospect Sales Skill Account 
 *  And it meets all defined eligibility filter criteria 
 *  When the “1C – Prospects Ready for Customer Conversion” view is opened 
 *  Then the record must appear in the view 
 

 *  Column Visibility 

 *  Given a Sales Ops user views the grid 
 *  When the view is loaded 
 *  Then all specified columns must be visible and available for filtering and sorting as shown below 
 

 *  Sorting Behavior 

 *  Given multiple eligible prospects exist 
 *  When the view is loaded 

 *  Then records must be ordered by Modified On and Created On (Ascending) (Oldest to Newest) 
 

 

 *  Security Enforcement 

 *  Given a non-Sales Ops user accesses CRM 
 *  When they attempt to locate this view 
 *  Then the view must not be visible or selectable 
 

 

 
View Configuration 

 *  View Name - 1C – Prospects Ready for Customer Conversion 
 *  View Filter Criteria (ALL conditions must be met) The view must include only Account records that meet all of the following criteria: 

 *  Account Type = Prospect 
 *  Prospect Approval Status = Approved 
 *  Account Status = Active 
 *  ERP Account Status = Prospect 
 *  MDM ID is populated 
 *  Base Customer Account (BCA) is populated 
 *  MDM Status does not equal to Customer Conversion Submitted  
 *  Account is associated to a district with 1C flag = Yes (FBU 1C) 
 

 *  View Columns (Explicit Column List) The following columns must be included in the view to support Sales Ops filtering, analysis, and prioritization: 

 *  Account & Location  
 *  Account Name 
 *  Account Name 2 (if applicable) 
 *  Account Number 
 *  Account Type 
 *  City 
 *  State / Province 
 *  Country 
 *  Corporate Account 
 *  Sales Skill 
 *  District

 *  Sales Manager 
 *  Primary Owner 
 *  Owner 
 *  AVP  
 *  BDM 
 *  CAM

 *  GAM(Corporate Account) 
 *  Associate AM / Technician 
 *  Market Segment 
 *  Sub-Segment 
 *  Sub-Segment Description 
 *  Prospect Approval Status 
 *  ERP Account Status 
 *  MDM Sync Status 
 *  BCA 
 *  ERP Account Status (BCA) 
 *  Created On 
 *  Modified On 
 

 *  Sorting Rules 

 *  Primary Sort: Modified On and Created On 
 *  Sort Order: Ascending 
 *  Oldest eligible prospects must appear at the top of the view 
 

 *  Security & Visibility Rules 

 *  View must be visible only to Sales Ops personas 
 *  View must be hidden from Sales Reps and non-Sales Ops roles

column7: Automate prospect creation flow in CRM ? CLM ? MDM with API payloads for address validation, duplicate check, and ID return.
column11:
Business Objective:
Enable CRM to automatically integrate with CLM/MDM during the creation of a new prospect, so that address validation, duplicate checking, and unique ID assignment are performed in real-time. This ensures higher data quality, prevents duplicate records, and establishes a consistent customer identity across CRM, CLM, and MDM from the first point of entry. 

 
Business Requirements: 

 *  When a prospect is created in CRM, the record must be automatically sent to CLM/MDM via the CLM API. 
 *  CLM/MDM must perform: 

 *  Address validation to ensure standardization and accuracy. 
 *  Duplicate check against MDM to confirm whether this is a new prospect or an existing record. 
 *  ID return to provide a unique MDM identifier for valid new prospects. 
 

 *  If the duplicate check determines a match: 

 *  CRM must not create a new prospect record but should instead flag the scenario for Sales Ops review. 
 

 *  If no duplicate is found: 

 *  A prospect BCA is created in CRM and linked with the returned MDM ID. 
 

 *  The process should be fully automated, minimizing Sales Ops manual interventions at the point of prospect entry. 
 

 
Technical Considerations: 

 *  CRM must consume the CLM API endpoints for address validation, duplicate check, and ID return (API orchestration may be needed if APIs are separate). 
 *  Data mapping of CRM fields (prospect name, address, sales skill, district) to CLM/MDM API payload must be defined. 
 *  Response handling logic must be built in CRM: 

 *  Success (new prospect ? ID assigned). 
 *  Duplicate (block creation + flag for review). 
 *  Error (API failure ? clear error message to user). 
 

 *  Audit trail of API requests/responses should be logged for traceability. 
 *  Performance testing required to ensure responsiveness does not slow down prospect creation. 
 

 
Expected Deliverables: 

 *  Automated prospect creation workflow in CRM integrated with CLM APIs. 
 *  Standardized address and duplicate check validations running during prospect save. 
 *  Automatic creation of a Prospect BCA in CRM with the returned MDM ID and P-number. 
 *  Error-handling framework and user-friendly messages for failed API responses. 
 *  Documentation of API payload mapping and test scenarios.

column8: Unique ID Assignment for New Prospects
column11:
As a CRM system
I want to receive a unique MDM ID for valid new prospects
So that the prospect can be consistently identified across systems.
column22:
Scenario: Valid new prospect 
  Given a prospect passes address validation and duplicate check 
  When MDM returns a unique ID 
  Then CRM should store the MDM ID in the prospect record 
  And create a Prospect BCA linked to the MDM ID

column8: Technical Spike – Define IF10 Payload Mapping for Prospect Create (CRM ? MDM)
column11:
As a technical architect, I want a clear IF10 payload mapping for prospect creation so that CRM can send consistent, correct data to MDM when creating or updating prospects. 

 *  Identify all CRM fields required in the IF10 “prospect create” message (e.g., CRM ID, account number, name, address, division, sales skill, contact information). 
 *  Confirm which fields are mandatory vs optional in MDM for prospect creation. 
 *  Define mapping rules for: 

 *  New prospect (no MDM ID present). 
 *  Additional sales skill for an existing MDM prospect (MDM ID populated). 
 

 *  Document transformation rules (e.g., formatting, trimming, code conversions). 
 *  Produce a finalized field-by-field IF10 mapping specification to be used by the CRM Plugin and integration team.
column19: Moved out of state In Development
column22:
*  Scope & Objective 

 *  Produce a complete field-by-field IF10 payload mapping for prospect creation from CRM to MDM. 
 *  Cover both scenarios: 

 *  New prospect (no MDMID). (Start with Katie C. document) 
 *  Add-sales-skill to an existing MDM prospect (MDMID present). 
 

 *  Ensure only correct identifiers are used: CRMID, MDMID, EBS Account ID. 
 

 *  Field Discovery and Requirements 

 *  Identify all CRM fields required in the IF10 prospect-create request. 
 *  Confirm mandatory vs optional fields with MDM. 
 *  Capture all relevant CRM fields, including: 

 *  CRMID (GUID) 
 *  Account name 
 *  Standardized address lines 
 *  City, state/province, postal code, country 
 *  Division / Sales Org 
 *  Sales skill 
 *  Market segment and sub-segment 
 *  Contact phone, email (if required by MDM) 
 *  Account type (prospect vs customer) 
 *  MDMID (only for add-sales-skill scenario) 
 *  EBS Account ID (only for update scenarios after IF17 flow) 
 

 *  Scenario-Specific Mapping Requirements (Add comments if there is a scenario specific map) 
 *  New Prospect (No MDMID present): 
 *  IF10 must be prepared with CRMID. 
 *  MDMID must be null/empty. (Best way to pass null, "", no entry) 
 *  Use standardized address fields. (Street1, Street2 (optional), City, State, Country, Postal Code) 
 *  Map all mandatory prospect fields as required by MDM. 
 *  Ensure mapping covers all fields required for initial prospect creation. 
 

 *  Add-Sales-Skill to Existing MDM Prospect (MDMID present): 

 *  IF10 must include CRMID for the new sales-skill account. 
 *  IF10 must include MDMID returned earlier. 
 *  Distinguish shared vs unique fields across sales skills. 
 *  Capture rules for linking CRM accounts under the same MDM prospect. 
 *  Define usage of EBS Account ID only when applicable. 
 

 *  Transformation Rules 

 *  Document transformation rules for every mapped field. 
 *  Specify trimming, formatting, uppercase/lowercase requirements. 
 *  Include all code-conversion rules (CRM option set ? MDM codes). 
 *  Define default values for fields missing in CRM. 
 *  Capture length restrictions and truncation logic. 
 *  Document address handling logic for standardized vs bypassed addresses. 
 *  Confirm mapping for sales skill conversion from CRM format to MDM format. 
 

 *  Required Mapping Document Structure 

 *  Excel sheet: IF10 Request Payload Mapping must contain: 

 *  IF10 field name 
 *  IF10 JSON path 
 *  Business description 
 *  Data type 
 *  Required (Yes/No) 
 *  CRM source entity 
 *  CRM source field logical name 
 *  Transformation rule 
 *  Default value 
 *  Usage scenario (new prospect, add-sales-skill, or both) 
 *  Sample value 
 *  Notes 
 

 *  Excel sheet: IF10 Response Mapping (IF10 Confirmation ) must contain: 

 *  Response field name 
 *  JSON path 
 *  Description 
 *  Data type 
 *  Required in CRM (Yes/No) 
 *  CRM target entity 
 *  CRM target field 
 *  Transformation rule 
 *  Null-handling rule 
 *  Sample value 
 *  Notes 
 *  Usage (e.g., update CRM.MDMID, update MDM Account ID) 
 

 

 *  Sample Payload Requirements (Postman Collection) 

 *  Provide sample IF10 JSON payload for new prospect (MDMID empty). 
 *  Provide sample IF10 JSON payload for add-sales-skill (MDMID present). 
 *  Sample must include CRMID, standardized address block, division, sales skill, and scenario-specific fields. 
 *  Include notes showing where EBS Account ID is later updated via IF17. 
 

 *  Integration / Plugin Considerations (Ankita / Ashish Consultation) 

 *  Document how CRM plugin will gather data for building the IF10 payload. 
 *  Identify all CRM fields the plugin must read before constructing the payload. 
 *  Document dependencies such as: 

 *  Address validation completion (AddressValidationCheck? :Field requirements in CRM, how will they drive decisions in the plug-in) 
 *  Duplicate check completion (DuplicationCheck? : Field requirements in CRM, how will they drive decisions in the plug-in) 
 *  Approval status 
 

 *  Clarify identifier usage: 

 *  CRMID used as cross-reference to CRM. 
 *  MDMID used to link records in MDM. 
 *  EBS Account ID populated only after IF17. 
 

 

 *  Edge Cases and Error Handling (work with Ruchi) 

 *  Document how to handle missing or partial address values. 
 *  Document how to handle bypassed address validation. 
 *  Identify behavior when an existing CRM account contains a stale or wrong MDMID. 
 *  Define minimum data requirements for sending IF10. 
 *  Specify conditions where IF10 must NOT be sent (e.g., pending approval, MDMID mismatch, missing required fields). 
 

 *  Deliverables 

 *  Completed Excel mapping document containing:  

 *  Full IF10 request payload mapping  
 *  Full IF10 response and IF17 response mapping  
 *  All transformation/business rules  
 *  Sample JSON payloads  
 *  Required vs optional documentation  
  

 *  Complete list of assumptions and open questions. 
 *  Final recommendation ready for build.  
 *  Review and sign-off from CRM architecture, MDM integration, and development leads.

The documentation also covers master data handling, such as lookup mappings, normalization rules, reference data alignment, and data cleansing requirements. This serves as a key reference for developers, testers, and integration stakeholders to ensure consistency and accuracy in data processing.

Documented all error handling scenarios relevant to the integration and application processes. This includes

 *  Edge Cases and Error Handling 

 *  Document how to handle missing or partial address values. 
 *  Document how to handle bypassed address validation. 
 *  Identify behavior when an existing CRM account contains a stale or wrong MDMID. 
 *  Define minimum data requirements for sending IF10. 
 *  Specify conditions where IF10 must NOT be sent (e.g., pending approval, MDMID mismatch, missing required fields).

column8: Technical Spike – Define End-to-End Prospect Creation & Duplicate Check Orchestration (Confirm the correct sequence of CRM Dup Check vs MDM Dup Check)
column11:
As a Solution Architect, I want to design and validate the end-to-end prospect creation and duplicate-check orchestration between CRM and MDM so that we can choose the optimal sequence (CRM dupe vs MDM dupe first) and user experience before build. 

 *  Analyze two orchestration patterns: 

 *  CRM internal dupe check first, then MDM dupe/search. 
 *  MDM dupe/search first, then CRM dupe (or no CRM dupe). (Skipping?) 
 

 *  Document the pros/cons for each approach from: 

 *  Sales Representative (Rep) experience (steps, prompts, interruptions). 
 *  Sales Operations (Ops) workload (volume of manual reviews). 
 *  Data quality and risk of duplicates. 
 

 *  Produce simple UI/UX mockups/flow diagrams showing: 

 *  What the rep sees on save (messages, pop-ups, error banners). 
 *  How “pending approval” vs “auto-approved” records behave. 
 

 *  Recommend a preferred orchestration pattern (with rationale) to be used for detailed design and downstream stories. 
 *  Define Fallback Behavior for API Failures and Mobile/Offline Prospect Creation
column19: Moved out of state Pending PO Review
column22:
*  Orchestration Models Are Fully Analyzed 

 *  The spike must document two complete orchestration patterns: 

 *  Pattern A: CRM Duplicate Check ? MDM Duplicate Check 
 *  Pattern B: MDM Duplicate Check ? Optional CRM Duplicate Check 
 *  (or skip CRM dupe check entirely depending on MDM output) 
 

 *  For each pattern A, documentation must include: 

 *  Full step-by-step sequence from prospect save ? every check ? final status. 
 *  Required inputs (address, name, sales skill, district, etc.). 
 *  Decision logic for “duplicate found / no duplicate / error”. 
 *  Correct CRM update behavior (approval status, fields, flags). 
 *  Plugin invocation path and expected plugin outputs. 
 

 *  Analyze how the pattern A Vs B works for Excel imports and Prospects created from leads. 
 

 *  Pros & Cons Evaluation Is Completed 

 *  A side-by-side evaluation must be created for both orchestration patterns, addressing: 

 *  Sales Rep UX 
 *  Number of prompts, interruptions, modal windows, banners. 
 *  When rep is blocked vs. allowed to continue. 
 *  Clarity of messages such as “duplicate found”, “no match”, “pending approval”. 
 

 *  Sales Ops Impact 

 *  Expected queue volume based on the orchestration pattern. 
 *  Manual workload reduction (auto-approval) scenarios. 
 *  Error-handling load when APIs fail. 
 

 *  Data Quality & Duplicate Prevention 
 *  Likelihood of preventing duplicates across rep-created prospects. 
 *  Risks associated with CRM-only or MDM-only checks. 
 *  Technical Feasibility 

 *  Plugin complexity. 
 *  API latency.  
 *  Interaction between CRM native dupe rules and plugin-driven MDM checks. 
 

 *  Maintainability 

 *  Future enhancements (new API parameters, sales skill logic). 
 *  Configurability without code changes. 
 

 

 *  UI/UX Mockups Must Be Delivered 

 *  The spike must include mockups or diagrams showing: 

 *  What the Rep Sees 
 *  Before Save 
 *  Address validation step and required-field behavior 
 *  Validation button / banner 
 *  On Save 
 *  CRM duplicate check outcomes 
 *  MDM duplicate check silent execution 
 *  After Save 
 *  Auto-approved success toast / banner 
 *  Pending approval notification 
 *  Navigation to existing account when rep chooses a CRM match 
 

 *  What Sales Ops Sees 

 *  MDM validation section 
 *  Duplicate check button 
 *  Returned list of MDM matches (formatted JSON in a grid or popup) 
 

 

 *  Technical Diagrams 

 *  Process flow for each orchestration pattern 
 *  Plugin invocation chain (JS ? Custom Action ? Plugin ? MDM API ? plugin response ? form scripting) 
 

 *  Formal Recommendation Must Be Produced 

 *  The spike must end with a clear written recommendation that includes: 
 *  The chosen orchestration pattern (CRM-first, MDM-first, or hybrid). 
 *  Business rationale (rep experience, ops workload, accuracy). 
 *  Technical reasoning (plugin feasibility, API completeness, reliability). 
 *  Dependencies (address standardization, MDM search API design). 
 *  Known limitations and risks. 
 

 *  Offline & API Failure Behavior Must Be Fully Defined 

 *  The spike must define fallback rules for: 

 *  MDM API Failure / Timeout 
 *  Plugin must return structured error output. 
 *  CRM must interpret failures as “duplicate check not completed”. 
 *  Prospect must be saved as Pending Approval. 
 *  Flags updated: 
 *  AddressCheck = Verified / Bypassed 
 *  DuplicateCheckCompleted = No 
 

 *  Rep Offline (Mobile App / No Network) 
 *  No MDM API call should be attempted. 
 *  No CRM duplicate check if offline. 
 *  Prospect must always save as Pending Approval. 
 *  No blocking error messages. 
 *  CRM Unreachable Services (Dataverse throttling, plugin failure) 

 *  Same fallback: Pending Approval  
 

 *  All fallback rules must be clearly documented . 
 

 *  Final Deliverables Required 

 *  The spike must deliver the following artifacts: 
 *  End-to-end orchestration diagram for both patterns. 
 *  Decision matrix comparing CRM-first vs. MDM-first. 
 *  UI mockups for rep and sales ops experiences. 
 *  Recommendation document selecting the preferred pattern. 
 *  Fallback behavior specification (API failure, offline). 
 *  List of downstream user stories for implementation.

column9: Document Step-by-step sequence for CRM -> MDM dup check
column11:
Document the step by step sequence for CRM dup check -> MDM Dup check 

 

 *  Required inputs (address, name, sales skill, district, etc.). 
 *  Decision logic for “duplicate found / no duplicate / error”. 
 *  Correct CRM update behavior (approval status, fields, flags). 
 *  Plugin invocation path and expected plugin outputs.

*  A side-by-side evaluation must be created for both orchestration patterns, addressing: 

 *  Sales Rep UX 
 *  Number of prompts, interruptions, modal windows, banners. 
 *  When rep is blocked vs. allowed to continue. 
 *  Clarity of messages such as “duplicate found”, “no match”, “pending approval”. 
 

 *  Sales Ops Impact 

 *  Expected queue volume based on the orchestration pattern. 
 *  Manual workload reduction (auto-approval) scenarios. 
 *  Error-handling load when APIs fail. 
 

 *  Data Quality & Duplicate Prevention 
 *  Likelihood of preventing duplicates across rep-created prospects. 
 *  Risks associated with CRM-only or MDM-only checks. 
 *  Technical Feasibility 

 *  Plugin complexity. 
 *  API latency. 
 *  Interaction between CRM native dupe rules and plugin-driven MDM checks. 
 

 *  Maintainability 

 *  Future enhancements (new API parameters, sales skill logic). 
 *  Configurability without code changes.

*  Technical Diagrams 

 *  Process flow for each orchestration pattern 
 *  Plugin invocation chain (JS ? Custom Action ? Plugin ? MDM API ? plugin response ? form scripting) 
 

 *  Formal Recommendation Must Be Produced 

 *  The spike must end with a clear written recommendation that includes: 
 *  The chosen orchestration pattern (CRM-first, MDM-first, or hybrid). 
 *  Business rationale (rep experience, ops workload, accuracy). 
 *  Technical reasoning (plugin feasibility, API completeness, reliability). 
 *  Dependencies (address standardization, MDM search API design). 
 *  Known limitations and risks. 
 

 *  Offline & API Failure Behavior Must Be Fully Defined 

 *  The spike must define fallback rules for: 

 *  MDM API Failure / Timeout 
 *  Plugin must return structured error output. 
 *  CRM must interpret failures as “duplicate check not completed”. 
 *  Prospect must be saved as Pending Approval. 
 *  Flags updated: 
 *  AddressCheck = Verified / Bypassed 
 *  DuplicateCheckCompleted = No 
 

 *  Rep Offline (Mobile App / No Network) 
 *  No MDM API call should be attempted. 
 *  No CRM duplicate check if offline. 
 *  Prospect must always save as Pending Approval. 
 *  No blocking error messages. 
 *  CRM Unreachable Services (Dataverse throttling, plugin failure) 

 *  Same fallback: Pending Approval  
 

 *  All fallback rules must be clearly documented .

column8: Technical Spike – Define Cutover Strategy for Address Standardization & Prospect MDM Backfill
column11:
As a technical architect, I want a cutover strategy for bulk address standardization and MDM backfill for existing prospects so that new prospect flows can rely on standardized addresses and existing prospects are correctly linked to MDM.

 

 *  Analyze the current volume and quality of CRM prospect records (1C + non-1C) and their address completeness. 
 *  Define a bulk process to: 

 *  Send existing prospect addresses to the MDM address validation service. 
 *  Update CRM address fields with standardized values. 
 

 *  Define a bulk process to: 

 *  Load existing CRM prospects into MDM (if not already there). 
 *  Obtain MDM IDs and cross-reference CRM IDs. 
 *  Update CRM with MDM ID, MDM account number, and source account number as appropriate. 
 

 *  Identify required tools (e.g., ADF, Azure Functions, batch jobs) and constraints (volume, timing, downtime if any). 
 *  Document cutover steps, sequencing, and validation checks to be executed before R2 go-live.
column22:
*  Analysis & Discovery Requirements 

 *  Analyze the total volume of CRM prospect records across 1C and non-1C districts. 
 *  Analyze data quality and completeness of address fields for all existing prospects.  
 *  Identify prospects missing postal code, state/province, country, or other mandatory fields required by MDM Address Validation API.  
 *  Identify records with stale or invalid standardized addresses (CRM-side cleanliness assessment).  
 *  Identify which prospect records already have for (NA): 

 *  CRMID 
 *  MDMID 
 *  MDM Account ID 
 *  EBS Account ID 
 

 

 *  Bulk Address Standardization Strategy 

 *  Define the end-to-end bulk process to send all existing CRM prospect addresses to MDM Address Validation API. 
 *  Document criteria for selecting the address validation method: 

 *  Whether ADF, SSIS, Logic App, batch call, or SQL staging pipeline will be used. 
 

 *  Define how to handle outcomes returned from the Address Validation API: 

 *  Valid standardized address found ? update CRM Street1/City/State/Postal/Country. 
 *  Multiple matches ? determine fallback rule (pick first, flag for manual review, create exception file). 
 *  No match returned ? identify fallback behavior (retain CRM address but set “Address Validation Bypassed = Yes”). 
 *  API failure ? define retry logic or batch rerun scenario. 
 

 *  Define data transformation rules for address updates, including trimming, casing consistency, and special character handling. 
 *  Define logging requirements for batch address validation: 

 *  Total processed 
 *  Total successfully standardized 
 *  No-match list 
 *  API failure list 
 *  Manual correction list 
 

 

 *  Prospect MDM Backfill Strategy 

 *  Define the bulk process for loading existing CRM prospects into MDM (acknowledging that MDM team will run their internal load). 
 *  Document input/output expectations from MDM: 

 *  MDM will share a mapping file containing CRMID ? MDMID ? MDM Account ID ? EBS Account ID. 
 

 *  Define CRM-side update process using the MDM-provided backfill file: 

 *  Update CRM.MDMID for each prospect. 
 *  Update CRM.AccountNumber (MDM Account ID) where applicable. 
 *  Update CRM.MDMNumber (MDM Account ID) where applicable. 
 *  Update CRM.EBS Account ID (Source Account Number) if returned. 
 

 *  Define required validations after CRM update: 

 *  MDMID must not be null for any record included in MDM backfill list. 
 *  AccountNumber and MDMNumber must match expected formats and lengths. 
 *  Verify no duplicate CRM records exist that map to the same MDMID unless intentional (multi-sales-skill scenario). 
 

 

 *  Technical Tools & Infrastructure Requirements 

 *  Identify and recommend tools for address standardization batch processing: 

 *  ADF pipelines 
 *  SSIS packages 
 *  SQL stored procedures / staging tables 
 *  Custom batch jobs 
 

 *  Identify tool for CRM-side batch update of prospect backfill data: 

 *  ADF CRM connector 
 *  Dataverse API bulk update 
 *  Plugin on-demand bulk job (if low volume) 
 

 *  Evaluate constraints such as: 

 *  Volume size 
 *  API throttling limits 
 *  MDM API rate limitations 
 *  Parallelism opportunities 
 *  Recommended window/timing 
 

 *  Identify whether downtime is required during cutover. 
 *  Determine whether address standardization and MDM backfill should be executed sequentially or in parallel. 
 

 *  Cutover Steps & Sequencing 

 *  Define the exact step-by-step cutover sequence required for R2 go-live: 

 *  Extract all active CRM prospects and Customers for FBU. 
 *  Execute bulk address validation via MDM API. 
 *  Update CRM with standardized address results. 
 *  MDM executes bulk import of all standardized CRM prospects. 
 *  Receive MDM backfill output file from MDM team. 
 *  Update CRM with MDMID, MDM Account ID, and EBS Account ID. 
 *  Execute post-update validations. 
 *  Prepare exception list for unresolved issues. 
 

 *  Identify prerequisite dependencies such as: 

 *  All CRM prospects must have valid sales skill and district. 
 *  Address fields must be populated sufficiently to perform validation. 
 *  CRM maintenance window for loading MDM backfill. 
 

 

 *  Validation & Reconciliation Requirements 

 *  Document all validation steps to be executed after cutover: 

 *  Count match between CRM prospect count and MDM backfill file count. 
 *  Spot check standardized addresses against MDM Address Validation API. 
 *  Validate all prospects now have MDMID and AccountNumber populated. 
 *  Validate no orphan records remain without MDMID. 
 *  Validate that prospect PCA records are aligned correctly. 
 

 *  Define reconciliation reports to be generated: 

 *  Address standardization success/failure summary 
 *  Backfill success/failure summary 
 *  Exception report for manual remediation 
 

 

 *  Deliverables 

 *  Cutover strategy document covering: 

 *  Address standardization batch process 
 *  Prospect backfill process 
 *  Tooling recommendations 
 *  API usage patterns 
 *  Error handling and retry strategy 
 *  Sequencing and validation logic 
 

 *  Updated cutover sequencing template with all new R2 steps inserted in correct order. 
 *  Pros/cons analysis for each tooling option (ADF vs SSIS vs custom job). 
 *  List of open questions and dependencies to be clarified with CRM, MDM, and Integration teams.

column8: Technical Spike – Analyze MDM Dupe Check API vs MDM Search API (Including Address Validation API)
column11:
As a Solution Architect, I want to compare the MDM dupe-check API and the MDM search API (and understand the address validation API) so that we can decide which services to call from CRM for prospect deduplication and address validation. 

 *  Review MDM dupe-check API capabilities and constraints: 

 *  Required and optional input fields (e.g., name, address, division, sales skill). 
 *  Output structure and what is or isn’t returned (e.g., no sales-skill support). 
 

 *  Review MDM search API: 

 *  Inputs required, including ability to pass sales skill, division, and other attributes. 
 *  Output attributes: sales skill, account type (prospect/customer), MDM ID, etc. 
 *  Whether it can replace/augment the dupe-check API in the prospect flow. 
 

 *  Review MDM address validation API: 

 *  Required address input fields and supported formats. 
 *  Output structure (standardized address lines, postal code, country, etc.). 
 *  Error handling / “no match” behavior. 
 

 *  Produce a mapping document for each API: 

 *  CRM fields ? API request payload. 
 *  API response ? CRM fields (or temporary objects). 
 

 *  Recommend which API(s) to use for: 

 *  Address validation step. 
 *  Silent MDM duplicate evaluation. 
 *  Sales Ops visible dupe resolution.
column19: Moved out of state Pending PO Review
column22:
*  API Capability Evaluation 

 *  Document full endpoint details, authentication requirements, and invocation method for: 

 *  MDM DupCheck API 
 *  MDM Search API 
 *  MDM Address Validation API 
 

 *  Capture all required and optional input fields for each API. 
 *  Document supported field formats, validations, and constraints. 
 *  Document output structure for each API, including all response fields and data types. 
 *  Capture whether each API supports sales skill, division, customer type, and fuzzy matching (spelling errors - can API do this?). 
 *  Document limitations such as missing sales skill support in DupCheck API. (might not support Sales Skill) 
 *  Document behavior for zero, one, or multiple match responses. 
 *  Document error and timeout behaviors for each API. 
 

 *  Address Validation API Analysis 

 *  Identify required address input fields: Street 1, Street 2, City, State/Province, Postal Code, Country. 
 *  Document supported formats and validation rules for the address input fields. 
 *  Capture output fields such as standardized address lines, city, state, postal code, and country code. 
 *  Document behavior when no standardized address match is returned. 
 *  Document behavior when multiple address candidates are returned. 
 *  Document bypass scenarios and how CRM should interpret “no match”. 
 

 *  DupCheck API Analysis 

 *  Document all input attributes needed for the DupCheck request payload. 
 *  Document the response structure and list all fields returned. 
 *  Identify whether the API can be used for silent duplicate evaluation. 
 *  Identify functional gaps such as no sales skill in the response. 
 *  Document scenarios where the API is unsuitable. 
 

 *  Search API Analysis 

 *  Document input attributes accepted by the Search API including name, address lines, sales skill, division, and other filters. 
 *  Document full output attributes, including: 

 *  MDM ID 
 *  Customer/Prospect type 
 *  Sales skill 
 *  Source system 
 *  Match indicators or scores 
 

 *  Document whether Search API can fully replace DupCheck API for prospect creation. 
 *  Identify suitability of Search API for SalesOps visible duplicate resolution. 
 

 *  Mapping Document Deliverables 

 *  Produce a mapping document for all APIs in an Excel-ready structure. 
 *  Required columns for Request Mapping: 

 *  API Input Field Name 
 *  Description 
 *  Required (Yes/No) 
 *  Data Type 
 *  CRM Source Field (logical name) 
 *  Transformation or formatting logic 
 *  Sample Value 
 *  Notes or constraints 
 

 *  Required columns for Response Mapping: 

 *  API Response Field Name 
 *  Description 
 *  Data Type 
 *  Expected Values / Ranges 
 *  CRM Target Field 
 *  Transformation logic 
 *  Null or no-match handling 
 *  Sample response value 
 *  Where it is used in the prospect process (silent vs visible) 
 

 *  JSON Contract Documentation (Postman Collection) 

 *  Produce a full sample request JSON for each API. 
 *  Break down each element of the JSON into mapping rows using the mapping template. 
 *  Produce a sample response JSON for each API. 
 *  Capture typical success, duplicate-found, no-result, and error responses. 
 *  Document rules for interpreting “duplicate found” vs “no duplicate found”. 
 

 

 *  Comparative Analysis of DupCheck vs Search API (why choose one or the other) 

 *  Document capability differences for each API in terms of: 

 *  Input flexibility 
 *  Output richness 
 *  Support for sales skill 
 *  Match scoring 
 *  Fuzzy vs strict matching 
 

 *  Document UX impact for sales reps and sales ops. 
 *  Document data quality implications when using each API. 
 *  Document technical feasibility, plugin complexity, response handling, and performance. 
 *  Produce a recommendation on: 
 *  The API for silent background evaluation (rep flow) 
 *  The API for visible detailed evaluation (sales ops flow) 
 *  Whether DupCheck API should be deprecated 
 *  Whether Search API becomes the primary service 
 

 *  Sequence and Integration Flow Outputs 

 *  Deliver a prospect-level sequence diagram showing: 

 *  When CRM calls Address Validation 
 *  When CRM performs silent MDM evaluation 
 *  How SalesOps trigger visible duplicate resolution 
 

 *  Document fallback behavior for offline or API-unreachable conditions. 
 *  Document how CRM should update fields like “Is Duplicate Check Completed”, “Duplicate Check User Selection”, etc. 
 

 *  Error Handling Definition 

 *  Document expected CRM behavior for: 

 *  API timeouts 
 *  No match returned 
 *  Multiple match results 
 *  Single match returned 
 *  Invalid or malformed input 
 

 *  Document bypass rules for address validation when no standardized address is found. 
 *  Document pending-approval behavior when APIs cannot be reached. 
 *  Document mobile offline behavior: all records created offline must go to pending approval by default. 
 

 *  Design Recommendation Deliverables 

 *  Provide a clear recommendation for: 

 *  API to be used for address validation 
 *  API to be used for silent background dupe evaluation 
 *  API to be used for SalesOps visible duplicate review 
 *  Proposed fallback rules 
 

 *  Provide a summary of required CRM plugin development. 
 *  Provide a summary of needed UI/UX changes (no wireframes required in this spike unless trivial). 
 *  Provide a list of downstream user stories dependent on this spike. 
 *  Provide a decision register summarizing what was evaluated and what is recommended. 
 

 *  Completion Criteria 

 *  All API capability analyses completed and documented. 
 *  All mapping documents delivered in tabular form. 
 *  All JSON contract examples documented. 
 *  Full comparison matrix and recommendation prepared. 
 *  Sequence diagram delivered.  
 *  All findings reviewed with CRM + MDM architecture leads. (Arpit, Shamil, Tom F, Siddharth) 
 *  Final recommended pattern approved by solution architects.

I want the system to automatically send new prospect data to CLM/MDM
So that address validation, duplicate checking, and ID assignment are performed in real-time.

column8: Placeholder 1
Hub – Align Hub / Mobile Prospect Creation Behavior with New Address & MDM Dupe Logic (Pending Approval Path)
column11:
As a Hub user (field rep), I want the Hub prospect creation flow to follow the same address validation and MDM duplicate-check rules as CRM so that behavior is consistent regardless of where I create prospects.

 *  Update Hub prospect creation screens to: 

 *  Capture the same minimum address, sales skill, and segmentation fields as CRM. 
 *  Invoke the same address validation logic (via API/Azure Function) and show standardized address choices. 
 

 *  Ensure Hub triggers the same MDM duplicate evaluation (via Azure Function) and follows the “auto-approve vs pending approval” rules defined for CRM. 
 *  For offline/mobile scenarios: 

 *  Define behavior when MDM services are unreachable (e.g., always route to pending approval). 
 

 *  Ensure that prospects created in Hub end up in CRM with the same statuses and flags (address verification, duplicate-check fields, approval status) as if they had been created directly in CRM.

column8: Duplicate Check Against MDM
column11:
As a CRM system
I want to check for duplicate prospects in MDM
So that duplicate records are prevented.
column22:
Scenario: Duplicate prospect found 
  Given a prospect is submitted to MDM for duplicate check 
  When a matching record is found 
  Then CRM should block the creation of the new prospect 
  And flag the record for Sales Ops review 

Scenario: No duplicate found 
  Given a prospect is submitted to MDM for duplicate check 
  When no matching record is found 
  Then CRM should proceed with prospect creation 
  And link the new record with the returned MDM ID

column8: CRM – Invoke MDM Search on Prospect Save and Drive Auto-Approval vs Pending Approval
column11:
As a sales rep, I want CRM to silently evaluate duplicates in MDM after I save a prospect so that non-duplicate prospects are auto-approved and potential duplicates are routed to Sales Ops for review.
 

 

 *  After CRM duplicate check passes/ignores, call the chosen MDM API (dupe-check or search) via CRM plugin. 
 *  Interpret MDM response as: 

 *  “No duplicate found” (no relevant results). 
 *  “Duplicate found” (one or more relevant MDM records). 
 *  “API unreachable/error” (technical failure or timeout). 
 

 *  For no duplicate found: 

 *  Set “Is duplicate check completed” = Yes. 
 *  Set “Duplicate check user selection” = No Duplicate Found. 
 *  Set prospect approval status = Approved. 
 *  Trigger IF10 to create the prospect in MDM (MDM ID blank; send CRM ID, account attributes, sales skill). 
 

 *  For duplicate found or API unreachable: 

 *  Save prospect with approval status = Pending Approval. 
 *  Leave MDM ID blank. 
 *  Mark “Is duplicate check completed” accordingly (e.g., No or Error state per spike outcome). 
 

 *  Ensure behavior is identical whether the prospect was created via Quick Create or full form and clearly documented for Sales Ops. 
 *  Auto-Approve Prospect and Trigger IF10 Create When MDM Returns No Duplicate or Set Prospect Pending Approval When MDM Returns Duplicate or API is Unreachable
column19: Moved out of state In Development
column22:
*  MDM Evaluation Trigger (Post-CRM Dupe Check) 

 *  Given a sales rep creates or edits a prospect and clicks Save 

 *  When the internal CRM duplicate check has returned no matches,  
 
 *  Then CRM must immediately invoke the MDM Search API 
 

 

 *  Consistency Across All Prospect Entry Points 

 *  Given the prospect was created from Quick Create or Full Account Form 

 *  When Save is clicked 
 *  Then the MDM evaluation must execute identically in both flows. 
 

 

 *  MDM API Response Handling — No Duplicate Found 

 *  Given the MDM API returns no results (API response empty or “no match”) 

 *  When CRM interprets the API response 
 *  Then CRM must: 

 *  Set IsDuplicateCheckCompleted = Yes 
 *  Set DuplicateCheckUserSelection = “No Duplicate Found” 
 *  Trigger the IF10 request to MDM to set up this prospect (This is handled in a separate user story) 
 *  The IF10 Confirmation should update the MDMID returned by MD into the ecl_mdmid field 
 *  Set Approval Status = Approved  
 *  Set Worked By = system user (Auto-Approved)  
 

 

 

 *  MDM API Response Handling — Duplicate Found (One or More Matches) 

 *  Given the MDM API returns one or more matching MDM records 

 *  When CRM interprets the API response 
 *  Then CRM must: 

 *  Set Approval Status = Pending 
 *  Set IsDuplicateCheckCompleted = No 
 *  Leave CRM.MDMID blank 
 *  Save the record so that it appears in the Sales Ops Pending Approval view 
 

 

 

 

 *  MDM API Response Handling — API Unreachable / Technical Error / Timeout 

 *  Given the MDM API call fails due to timeout, 500-error, authentication failure, or network issue 

 *  When CRM attempts to evaluate the response 
 *  Then CRM must: 

 *  Set Approval Status = Pending 
 *  Set IsDuplicateCheckCompleted = No 
 *  Set DuplicateCheckUserSelection = Null (system default) 
 *  Leave CRM.MDMID blank 
 *  Save the record so Sales Ops can resolve the situation 
 

 
 *  Display a non-blocking toast banner notification: 

 *  “MDM evaluation could not be completed. Prospect has been routed to Sales Ops for review.” 
 

 

 

 *  Mobile App Behavior: 

 *  Given the prospect was created from mobile app / offline mode 

 *  When the API cannot be invoked 
 *  Then the exact same behavior applies—prospect is saved as Pending Approval. 
 

 

 

 *  Given a prospect is created via Hub app 

 *  When the mobile app submits data to CRM 
 *  Then CRM still performs the MDM evaluation and applies the same routing (auto-approve or pending). 
 

 *  Non Functional Requirement: Logging & Auditing Requirements  

 *  Given CRM invokes an MDM API  
 *  When CRM receives a response (success or failure)  
 *  Then CRM must log:  

 *  CRM Prospect GUID  
 *  Timestamp  
 *  API called (Search)  
 *  API Request Payload (masked for sensitive fields)  
 *  API Response (success, no match, match found, error)  
 *  Resulting CRM decision (Auto-Approved / Pending Approval)  
 

 

 *  User Experience Requirements 

 *  Given the user clicks Save 

 *  When the MDM evaluation is processing, it should be in backend and user should not see any loading process. 
 *  Then the user sees a short non-blocking spinner overlay (max 2–3 seconds if synchronous). 
 

 

 

 

Note: When New fields are created to support this feature, please ensure you refer to this story to know the list of fields that needs to be created. #890505

column9: Analysis- MDM Evaluation Trigger (Post-CRM Dupe Check)
column11:
Analysis- MDM Evaluation Trigger (Post-CRM Dupe Check)

 *  MDM Evaluation Trigger (Post-CRM Dupe Check) 
 *  Given a sales rep creates or edits a prospect and clicks Save 

 *  When the internal CRM duplicate check has either: 

 *  returned no matches, or 
 *  returned matches that the user explicitly ignored 
 

 *  Then CRM must immediately invoke the selected MDM API (Search API) via CRM plugin.

column8: CRM – Invoke MDM Prospect Creation post MDM Dup Check
column11:
As a sales rep, I want CRM to silently send the valid prospect details into MDM after I save a prospect so that non-duplicate prospects are auto-approved and created in MDM
 
 

 *  After CRM duplicate check passes/ignores, call the chosen MDM API (dupe-check or search) via CRM plugin. 
 *  Interpret MDM response as: 

 *  “No duplicate found” (no relevant results). 
 *  “Duplicate found” (one or more relevant MDM records). 
 *  “API unreachable/error” (technical failure or timeout). 
 

 *  For no duplicate found: 

 *  Set “Is duplicate check completed” = Yes. 
 *  Set “Duplicate check user selection” = No Duplicate Found. 
 *  Set prospect approval status = Approved. 
 *  Trigger IF10 to create the prospect in MDM (MDM ID blank; send CRM ID, account attributes, sales skill). 
 

 *  For duplicate found or API unreachable: 

 *  Save prospect with approval status = Pending Approval. 
 *  Leave MDM ID blank. 
 *  Mark “Is duplicate check completed” accordingly (e.g., No or Error state per spike outcome). 
 

 *  Ensure behavior is identical whether the prospect was created via Quick Create or full form and clearly documented for Sales Ops. 
 *  Auto-Approve Prospect and Trigger IF10 Create When MDM Returns No Duplicate or Set Prospect Pending Approval When MDM Returns Duplicate or API is Unreachable
column19: Moved out of state Sprint Ready
column22:
*  MDM Evaluation Trigger (Post-CRM Dupe Check) 

 *  Given a sales rep creates a prospect and clicks Save/Save & Close 

 *  When the internal CRM duplicate check is completed had has returned matches or matches that the user explicitly ignored and proceeded 
 *  And MDM duplicate check (Via Search API) has returned no matches 
 

 

 

 *  MDM API Response Handling — No Duplicate Found 

 *  Given the MDM API returns no results (API response empty or “no match”) 

 *  When CRM interprets the API response 
 *  Then CRM must: 

 *  Trigger IF10 Prospect Create message to MDM 
 *  Pass CRM ID (accountid), Account Name (accountname), Standardized Address (street1,ecl_country,city,postalcode,ecl_state), Division, Sales Skill, and other mapped fields 
 *  Pass MDM ID (ecl_mdmid)= blank (because MDM will generate one) 
 

 

 *  Given IF10 confirmation returns with an MDM ID 

 *  When CRM receives the IF10 response 
 *  Then CRM must update: 

 *  CRM.MDMID = MDM.MDMID 
 *  Update CRM.MDM Sync status = Success 
 *  Update MDM Sync Description = "Prospect create request -  Submitted in MDM successfully. Correlation ID - [Correlation ID], Process ID - [Process ID]" 
 *  Update Last Sync Date = Current Timestamp 
 

 

 *  Given IF10 confirmation returns a failure/ IF10 request has failed 

 *  Then CRM must update: 

 *  Update CRM.MDM Sync status = Failure 
 *  Update MDM Sync Description = "Prospect create request -  Failed in MDM" 
 *  Update Last Sync Date = Current Timestamp 
 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 *  MDM API Response Handling — API Unreachable / Technical Error / Timeout 

 *  Given the MDM Duplicate Check API call fails due to timeout, 500-error, authentication failure, or network issue 

 *  When CRM attempts to evaluate the response 
 *  Then CRM must: 

 *  Leave CRM.MDMID blank 
 *  Do not send IF10 
 *  Save the record so Sales Ops can resolve the situation 
 *  Set Approval Status = Pending Approval 
 

 *  Display a non-blocking toast banner notification:  

 *  “MDM evaluation could not be completed. Prospect has been routed to Sales Ops for review.”  
  

  

 *  Given the prospect was created from mobile app / offline mode 

 *  When the API cannot be invoked 
 *  Then the exact same behavior applies—prospect is saved as Pending Approval. 
 

 

 *  Consistency Across All Prospect Entry Points 

 *  Given a prospect is created through QuickCreate 

 *  When MDM prospect creation is triggered 
 *  Then behavior must match the full Account form without exception. 
 

 *  Given a prospect is created via Hub app 

 *  When the mobile app submits data to CRM 
 *  Then CRM still performs the MDM prospect creation. 
 

 

 *  Logging & Auditing Requirements  

 *  Given CRM invokes an MDM API  
 *  When CRM receives a response (success or failure)  
 *  Then CRM must log:  

 *  CRM Prospect GUID  
 *  Timestamp  
 *  API called (Search)  
 *  API Request Payload (masked for sensitive fields)  
 *  API Response (success, no match, match found, error)  
 *  Resulting CRM decision (Auto-Approved / Pending Approval) 
 

 

 *  User Experience Requirements 

 *  Given the user clicks Save 

 *  When the MDM call is processing, Then it should be in backend and user should not see any loading process. 
 

 

 *  IF17 Response Handling: 

 *  Given when the Prospect is set up in MDM  
 *  When ERP Account Status is set to Prospect and MDM Number is updated by IF17 

 *  Then Update the Approval Status = Approved And Worked By Integration System User  
 *  And Validate that a BCA is created and linked to this Prospect (If not already created) 
 *  Update CRM.MDM Sync status = Success 
 *  Update MDM Sync Description = "Prospect create request -  Created in MDM successfully" 
 *  Update Last Sync Date = Current Timestamp 
 

 

 

Note: When New fields are created to support this feature, please ensure you refer to this story to know the list of fields that needs to be created. #890505

column8: CRM – Implement Sales Ops MDM Search Action and Reject or Merge the MDM Customer/Prospect
column11:
As a Sales Ops user, I want a dedicated MDM duplicate-check and resolution section on the prospect account form so that I can review pending prospects, link them to existing MDM accounts, or reject them.
 

 

 *  Add an “MDM Validation” section to the prospect account form (Sales Ops view), showing: 

 *  Address validation status. 
 *  Duplicate-check status and prior system decisions. 
 

 *  Provide an action/button for Sales Ops to trigger MDM duplicate again for pending approval prospects. 
 *  Display returned MDM candidates in a selectable list (with key fields like name, sales skill, status, MDM ID). 
 *  Support Sales Ops actions: 

 *  No duplicates found --> Prospect saved - approved status 
 *  Duplicates found, the SalesOps can: 

 *  Link (Existing record with different sales skill) -- Covered in #890515 
 *  Reject (Existing record with same sales skill and no related entities)  
 *  Merge (Existing record with same sales skill and related entities) 
 

 

 *  Ensure that upon approval, IF10 is sent (if needed) and CRM fields (MDM ID, account number, MDM number) are updated per defined rules. 
 *  Auto-Populate MDM IDs, Account Number, and MDM Number on Sales Ops Approval 
 *  Auto-Populate Approval Metadata and Comments for Auto-Approved and Manually Approved Prospects
column19: Moved out of state Sprint Ready
column22:
*  Sales Ops Action –   
 *  Possible Matches Found  

 *  Given the modal window appears  
 *  When one or more MDM candidates are returned  
 *  Sales Ops has two button options:  

 *  *Proceed --> This button will be disabled until one of the rows on the modal is selected (radio button selection) --- For next steps refer section below  
 *  Cancel --> Close the modal, No data changes, gives opportunity to SalesOps to make any required updates on the Account form  
  

 *  Merge, Reject or linking action buttons are not shown to the SalesOps at this point. 
 

  

  

 *  *Proceed  

 *  Given the SalesOps clicks on 'Proceed' after Possible Matches are found  
 *  Then the CRM system evaluates the selected MDM match against the current prospect  

 *  Outcome A: --> Selected Match has different Sales Skills than the newly added Prospect (Covered in #890515)  

  

  

 *  Outcome B: --> Selected Match has same Sales Skills as the newly added Prospect  

 *  Given that the Selected Match has same Sales Skill as the current Prospect    
 *  Then the system will show a modal window:   

 *  With message --> "Duplicate detected. This prospect may have related entities. Choose Merge to consolidate the new data into the existing record, or Reject to deactivate the new entry."  
 *  The values of the below attributes should be shown to the SalesOps to make a decision. Incase the attribute is not applicable for the scenario, show 'Not Applicable':  

 *  Current Prospect Sales Skill  
 *  Select Match Sales Skill   
 *  BCA Name (if available)  
 *  Survivor CRM Account Name  
 *  Survivor CRM Account ID  
 *  Current Prospect CRM ID  
  

   

 *  And will have buttons:   

 *  Reject as Duplicate --> Newly added prospect will be rejected/deactivated as duplicate   

 *  Update Audit/Log fields:   

 *  Update IsDuplicateCheckCompleted = Yes   
 *  Update DuplicateCheckUserSelection = "Duplicate Found" 
 *  Update "Approval Status" = Rejected 
 *  Update Worked By = Logged in User 
 *  Update Rejection Comments = "Duplicate Found" 
  

  

 *  Merge --> Newly added prospect will be merged  

 *  Update Audit/Log fields: 

 *  Update IsDuplicateCheckCompleted = Yes 
 *  Update DuplicateCheckUserSelection = "Duplicate Found" 
 

 *  Context:  

 *  Survivor = selected MDM matched record  
 *  Subordinate= newly added prospect  
 *  Dataverse OOB merge logic to be utilized  
  

 *  CRM system will update:  

 *  Dependent record to survivor per standard merge rules  
 *  Merge audit history will be preserved  
 *  Show message --> "Merging of record is in progress"- Values in all primary record will prevail.  
 *  Redirects to the primary merged record 
 *  The record should get deactivated 
   

   

 *  Cancel--> Cancels the modal and returns to Possible Matches Found modal window
