column8: Create Billing Arrangement–Account (SHIP-TO) Related Table for One-to-Many Associations (Introduces new related table without removing existing Sold-To / Ship-To lookups in BA table)
column11:
As a CRM platform
I want to introduce a new related table that associates a single Billing Arrangement to one or more SHIP-TO Accounts
 
So that Billing Arrangements can be linked to multiple account records without duplicating Billing Arrangement numbers, while preserving existing functionality during the R1 timeframe.
 

 
Background: 

 *  Today, the Billing Arrangement table in CRM stores direct lookups to: 

 *  Sold-To Account 
 *  Ship-To Account 
 

 *  With the One Customer (1C) model, a single customer may have multiple CRM account records (e.g., Water and Hygiene sales skills) tied to the same Base Customer Account (BCA). 
 *  This creates a challenge when: 

 *  A single Billing Arrangement number must apply to multiple SHIP-TO accounts 
 *  Duplicating Billing Arrangement records is not acceptable because Billing Arrangements represent master data 
 

 *  To support this model while minimizing risk for R1, a new related table will be introduced to enable a one-to-many relationship between Billing Arrangements and SHIP-TO Accounts. 
 *  Important R1 constraint: 

 *  Existing Sold-To and Ship-To lookups on the Billing Arrangement table must remain unchanged 
 *  No existing integrations or downstream processes should break 
 

 *  This design enables a phased transition: 

 *  R1: Introduce the new relationship model safely 
 *  Future releases: Migrate consuming logic to the related table and retire legacy lookups
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria: 

 *  New Related Table Creation 

 *  Given the CRM Billing Arrangement data model 
 *  When the solution is deployed 
 *  Then a new related table exists to associate Billing Arrangements to SHIP-TO Accounts in a one-to-many relationship 
 

 *  Relationship Structure 

 *  Given a Billing Arrangement record 
 *  When one or more SHIP-TO Accounts need to be associated 
 *  Then the related table allows multiple SHIP-TO Account references to be linked to a single Billing Arrangement 
 

 *  Backward Compatibility  

 *  Given existing Billing Arrangement records  
 *  When the new related table is introduced  
 *  Then existing Sold-To and Ship-To lookups on the Billing Arrangement table remain intact and unchanged 
 

 *  Security and Ownership  

 *  Given access to Billing Arrangement data  
 *  When users or integrations interact with the related table  
 *  Then security and ownership are inherited or enforced consistently with Billing Arrangement access rules

column8: Coexistence of SAP and EBS Billing Arrangements
column11:
As a CRM data model
I want to support both SAP and EBS billing arrangements
So that legacy and new customer data can coexist without conflict
column22:
Scenario: Distinguish between SAP and EBS records 
    Given CRM contains both SAP and EBS billing arrangements 
    When a record is created or updated 
    Then it should include a source indicator (e.g., ERP type) 
    And the system should not overwrite existing SAP records

column8: ADF Pipeline: Enhance EBS Billing Arrangement Inbound Integration to Populate SHIP-TO Associations in Related Table (Continue Water-only population on BA table; add SHIP-TO records for Water and Hygiene into related table)
column11:
As an inbound integration (ADF pipeline)
I want to populate Billing Arrangement data in CRM using a consistent, sales-skill–aware logic
 
So that Billing Arrangements are correctly associated to Water and Hygiene SHIP-TO accounts without duplicating Billing Arrangement numbers and while preserving existing R1 behavior.
 

 
Background: 

 *  Billing Arrangements (BA) are received from EBS and loaded into CRM via ADF pipelines. 
 *  Today, the Billing Arrangement table supports only one Sold-To and one Ship-To lookup, which creates a limitation under the One Customer (1C) model: 

 *  A single BA number can apply to both Water and Hygiene sales skills 
 *  CRM stores Water and Hygiene as separate account records, even when they belong to the same Base Customer Account (BCA) 
 *  Duplicating BA records is not acceptable, as BA is master data 
 

 *  For R1, Water processes (Field Service, ASA, recurring services) are the primary consumers of Billing Arrangements. Therefore: 

 *  The Billing Arrangement table must continue to store one primary Sold-To / Ship-To 
 *  A new related table must capture all SHIP-TO associations (Water and Hygiene) for future use 
 

 *  This user story defines how the ADF inbound integration must populate: 

 *  The Billing Arrangement table (primary association) 
 *  The Billing Arrangement – Account related table (complete association set) 
 

 *  High-Level Integration Behavior: 

 *  The Billing Arrangement table will store one primary association, prioritized for Water 
 *  The related table will store all applicable SHIP-TO associations (Water and/or Hygiene) 
 *  This ensures no BA duplication while supporting future-state use cases
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria: 

 *  Scenario 1: Only Hygiene Sales Skill Exists 

 *  Given a Billing Arrangement is received from EBS 
 *  And only a Hygiene sales skill account exists for the BA 
 *  When the ADF pipeline processes the record 
 *  Then the Billing Arrangement table is populated with the Hygiene Sold-To and Ship-To 
 *  And the related table contains a single SHIP-TO association for the Hygiene account 
 

 *  Scenario 2: Only Water Sales Skill Exists 

 *  Given a Billing Arrangement is received from ABS 
 *  And only a Water sales skill account exists for the BA 
 *  When the ADF pipeline processes the record 
 *  Then the Billing Arrangement table is populated with the Water Sold-To and Ship-To 
 *  And the related table contains a single SHIP-TO association for the Water account 
 

 *  Scenario 3: Water and Hygiene Share the Same Billing Arrangement 

 *  Given a Billing Arrangement is received from EBS 
 *  And both Water and Hygiene sales skill accounts exist 
 *  And they share the same Billing Arrangement number 
 *  When the ADF pipeline processes the record 
 *  Then the Billing Arrangement table is populated only with the Water Sold-To and Ship-To 
 *  And the related table contains two SHIP-TO associations: 

 *  One for the Water account 
 *  One for the Hygiene account 
 

 

 *  Scenario 4: No Duplicate Billing Arrangement Records 

 *  Given a Billing Arrangement number already exists in CRM 
 *  When additional sales skill associations are identified 
 *  Then no new Billing Arrangement record is created 
 *  And associations are added only to the related table

column6: Integration: CRM to Ecolab 3D and Ecolab 3D to CRM Integration Regression & Sanity Testing for One Customer Structure
column11:
This feature captures the end-to-end regression and sanity testing scope for existing bi-directional integrations between Microsoft Dynamics 365 CRM, CDM, and Ecolab 3D, in preparation for the One Customer structure go-live.
 

 
While no new functionality or core changes are expected across the CRM ? Ecolab 3D integration stack, the introduction of Base Customer Account (BCA), SOLD-TO realignment, business line convergence, and sales skill tagging necessitates thorough regression and sanity testing to ensure continued stability and accuracy of these flows.
 

 
The integration covers four key synchronization areas, each with associated testing scope:
 

 
Integration Flows & Testing Scope: 

 *  Asset Tree Integration (Ecolab 3D ? CRM) 

 *  Sync Type: Event-driven via Azure Event Hub and Service Bus 
 *  Mechanism: CDM syncs site and asset keys ? Ecolab 3D emits JSON ? CRM receives via Azure Function and stores in Dataverse. 
 *  Testing Scope: 

 *  Regression Testing: 

 *  Site Merge Scenarios: Ensure asset linkage, service plans, and visits remain intact. 
 *  Site Split Scenarios: Validate fallback logic for asset reassignment and CRM updates. 
 

 *   Sanity Testing: 

 *  New site creation: Confirm creation on-the-fly in CRM via CDM API if not pre-existing. 
 *  Field updates (e.g., BCA, sales skill) are preserved in sync logic.

 
 

 

 

 *  Action Logs / Recommendations (CRM to Ecolab 3D and E3D to CRM) 

 *  Sync Type: Bi-directional via API + Service Bus 
 *  Terminology: “Recommendation” in CRM = “Action Log” in Ecolab 3D 
 *  Testing Scope: 

 *  Regression Testing: 

 *  Validate OIP ID-based sync continues to match correct asset/site post merge/split. 
 *  Confirm filtering and sales skill tagging attributes flow correctly. 
 

 

 

 *  Sanity Testing: 

 *  Test creation and update in both systems sync correctly. 
 *  Validate attachment storage (Azure Blob) and metadata mapping. 

 
 

 

 

 *  Service Summary Dashboard (SSD) 

 *  Components: 

 *  Widget in Ecolab 3D (pulls service completion data from CRM) 
 *  PDF Report pushed to customer post-service 
 

 *  Testing Scope: 

 *  Sanity Testing: 

 *  Ensure widget renders correctly for merged site/account structures. 
 *  Confirm SSD PDFs trigger and send as expected. 
 

 

 *  No change expected in logic; test only for structural impacts. 

 
 

 *  Additional Scenarios to Cover in Testing: 

 *  Edge cases with homeless sites in Ecolab 3D awaiting mapping. 
 *  Filtering by business line (Water, F&B Hygiene, Textile) post-convergence. 
 *  Impact of changes in CRM field structures (e.g., new BCA, sales skill) on existing integration libraries (library shared across CDM and E3D). 
 *  Action log filtering by responsible party, timestamps, and problem status. 

 
 

 *  Testing Notes & Responsibilities: 

 *  No change required in core integration code unless business flags new requirements. 
 *  Shared libraries (e.g., fallback fetch via CDM API) may require minor updates for any new field inclusions like sales skill or BCA. 
 *  Testing to be isolated to functional flows, not underlying infrastructure. 
 *  Coordination needed with Ecolab 3D team, CRM Dev team, and CDM integration owners to validate test results. 
 *  Include non-prod (QA/Test) environment validation, considering partial sync coverage due to legacy data. 

 
 

 *  Outcome: 

 *  Upon successful completion of regression and sanity testing, the CRM to Ecolab 3D and E3D to CRM integrations will be certified as ready for One Customer Go-Live, with confidence in structural alignment, action/asset traceability, and business line filtering logic.

41. Regression Test All E3 to CRM and CRM to E3D integrations Post One Customer Structure Alignment
column11:
Business Context:
 
Ecolab 3D and Microsoft Dynamics 365 CRM are integrated to support service delivery, asset visibility, and site-level analytics. The One Customer initiative introduces key structural changes like Base Customer Account (BCA), Sold-To replacing Ship-To, and sales skill–based segmentation. These changes may impact how data flows between CRM and Ecolab 3D. While no direct changes to the integration are currently planned, thorough regression and sanity testing are needed to confirm continued functionality across all core integration flows, especially in merged or split site scenarios.
 

 
Business Requirements:
 

 *  Validate that asset records remain accurately synced between CRM and Ecolab 3D after site merges or splits. 
 *  Confirm that recommendations (CRM) and action logs (Ecolab 3D) remain bidirectionally synced and correctly attributed to sites and assets. 
 *  Ensure that the Service Summary Dashboard (SSD) continues to function correctly, including PDF generation and data display. 
 *  Verify that filtering by sales skill, business line (Water, F&B Hygiene), and Ecolab Water for Climate flags works correctly after site/account changes. 
 *  Confirm fallback logic triggers appropriately when CRM is missing site or account records referenced by Ecolab 3D. 
 

 
Detailed Regression and Sanity Testing Scope: 

 *  Asset Tree Sync (Ecolab 3D to CRM) 

 *  Regression Testing: 

 *  Validate asset sync from merged CDM sites to unified CRM site records. 
 *  Confirm behavior in split site cases where asset relationships may need reassignment or manual review. 
 

 *  Sanity Testing: 

 *  Validate that newly created CDM sites sync properly to CRM and Ecolab 3D. 
 *  Test near real-time asset updates from Ecolab 3D to CRM.

 
 

 

 *  Recommendations and Action Logs (Bi-directional) 

 *  Regression Testing: 

 *  Validate recommendations and action logs are preserved across merged or realigned sites and assets. 
 *  Check proper division and sales skill tagging post-merge. 
 

 

 *  Sanity Testing: 

 *  Confirm new CRM recommendations sync to Ecolab 3D and vice versa. 
 *  Validate updates and attachment references remain functional. 

 
 

 

 *  Service Summary Dashboard (SSD) 

 *  Sanity Testing: 

 *  Confirm SSD widget shows latest service data post-site/account changes. 
 *  Validate customer-facing PDFs are still generated correctly. 
 *  Check that global business fields and division filters are unaffected. 
 

 

 

 

 

 
Expected Deliverables: 

 *  A complete regression testing checklist including all key integration scenarios. 
 *  Executed test cases for site merges, site splits, asset re-linking, and action log flows. 
 *  Sanity test results confirming that key sync points behave correctly in edge cases. 
 *  Documentation of any integration gaps, sync issues, or defect findings. 
 *  Final stakeholder sign-off confirming integrations are stable and regression tested for One Customer go-live.

column6: Integration: Build new EBS Product Integration
End-to-End Process:  Guided Value Power App-->TVD Calculator-->CRM-->Financial Impact - - Regression Testing Only
column11:
End-to-End Business Process FlowDescription: 
•GuidedValue Power App 
•Repsaccess the Guided Value Power App via the Hub to explore instructional TVDprograms and value opportunities. 
•Theapp pulls site-specific content from CRM and helps reps identify relevantcalculators and inputs  
•. 
•TVDCalculator 
•Afteridentifying an opportunity, reps launch the TVD Calculator (a standalone Mobileapp) to perform value calculations. 
•Thecalculator uses site and account data, performs calculations locally, andstores results in Azure Blob Storage  
•. 
•CRMIntegration 
•Oncecalculations are complete, the TVD Calculator pushes the data to CRM via anAPI. 
•CRMcreates a TVD program record with key fields like program title, site, accountnumber, and value category  
•. 
•CRM TBD Program Record Lifecycle 
•TheTVD program progresses through CRM stages: Identified ? Approved ? In Process ?Implemented ? Final Sign-Off. 
•Repsmanage and update the record, which can be used for reporting and customerengagement  
•. 
•FinancialImpact (Ecolab 3D) 
•CRMdata is ingested into Snowflake, which feeds the Financial Impact dashboards inEcolab 3D. 
•Customersand internal teams view delivered, pipeline, and potential value at site orcorporate levels  
•. 
•AI-GuidedPotential 
•AImodels mine completed TVD programs from Snowflake to surface best-in-classopportunities. 
•Theseare visualized in Ecolab 3D and can be converted into new TVD programs manually

column6: Data Conversion: CRM & SharePoint: Documents (File Attachments)
column11:
Storage by Document Storage ToolType 
•Dataverse(CRM):Hygiene uses custom Attachment table to store documents. (Dataverse File Typefield is used to store the documents) 
•SharePoint:Water Uses Native CRM SharePoint integration to store documents 
Validated Findings: 
•NoHarmonization:  
•R1/R2scope does not include unifying document storage strategies.  
•HarmonizingWater & Hygiene use of SharePoint/Dataverse for document management is notdesired and not required for R2. 
•Security Considerations:Attachment table in CRM offers native record level security; SharePoint doesnot. Harmonization would require significant effort and change management.Security profile is not significant enough to warrant adding documentharmonization to known future scope. 
•Thereare no requirements for BCA To have a consolidated view of documents. 
•Thereare no R2 requirements to enable Hygiene/Dataverse documents to merge as partof OneCustomer Account record merging efforts. This because it is handled viaout of the box  record merging capabilitywhen the accounts are merged. 
•Water/SharePointdocuments will not automatically merge when these Accounts are merged. Sothere would Data Migration work involved to move documents from the Inactivewater account’s SharePoint Site to the surviving water account’s SharePointSite, when multiple versions of a water account are merged before linking thesurviving water account to the BCA in CRM. 
•Enterpriselevel document management tool that will be introduced by Ecolab in the futureis not in scope for R1/R2. That project may complete mid-2026. 
• 
Expected Changes 
•Nochanges to current document workflows for hygiene or water in R1/R2. 
•ManualSharePoint migration is required for water account merges. 
Hygieneonboarding to Ecolab3D is phased: initial enablement followed by full assetsetup by February 2026.

column7: Migrate SharePoint Documents During Account Merge
column11:
Business Context:
When merging multiple Nalco Water accounts into a surviving account before linking to a BCA, SharePoint folders tied to the deactivated accounts must be migrated to the surviving account’s folder. This is not handled by native CRM merge logic and requires a manual or automated migration. 
Business Requirement: 

 *  Identify SharePoint folders tied to accounts being merged. 
 *  Migrate all documents from deactivated account folders to the surviving account’s folder. 
 *  Ensure document visibility in Ecolab 3D remains intact post-merge. 
 *  Maintain metadata and folder structure during migration. 
 

Technical Considerations: 

 *  Requires SharePoint API or Power Automate flow for migration. 
 *  Must validate document integrity and access post-migration. 
 *  Coordinate with Ecolab 3D team to ensure My Documents reflects updated structure. 
 

Expected Deliverables: 

 *  Document migration plan and automation flow. 
 *  Validation checklist for migrated documents. 
 *  Regression testing for Ecolab 3D visibility.

column8: Technical Spike – Migration of SharePoint Documents from Inactivated Accounts to Surviving Accounts During Account Merges
column11:
As a Technical Architect,
I need to investigate, design, and document a viable approach to migrate SharePoint documents from inactivated accounts (resulting from CRM account merges) into the surviving account’s SharePoint library,
 
so that all historical documents remain accessible, searchable, and aligned with the surviving customer record after account merges executed during the 1C data conversion.
 

 
Context and Background: 
During the 1C conversion, multiple Water account versions will be merged into a single surviving account prior to linking with the corresponding Base Customer Account (BCA).
CRM’s native account merge process does not migrate SharePoint documents. The SharePoint library belonging to the inactivated account remains intact and detached after the merge.
 

 
This spike will determine:
 

 *  How to identify all inactivated accounts created during the conversion merges. 
 *  How to detect and migrate all SharePoint documents from those inactivated accounts to surviving accounts. 
 *  How to handle related records that have their own SharePoint folder structures but may be rooted inside the account folder tree. 
 *  Whether the migration should be performed using SSIS, Power Automate, or another integration approach—including pros/cons and feasibility. 
 *  Which CRM tables/entities are SharePoint-enabled and may require migration. 
 *  What the final folder structure should be after migration and whether record reparenting causes any broken SharePoint references. 
 *  A recommended end-to-end migration process, including error handling 
 

 
The output of this spike is a documented technical recommendation, including entity lists, folder-structure mapping, migration steps, and proposed implementation design.
column19: Moved out of state Pending PO Review
column22:
*  Identify Impacted Entities & Folder Structures 

 *  Given CRM account merges will inactivate multiple Water accounts, 
 *  When the technical investigation begins, 
 *  Then the team identifies and documents: 
 *  All SharePoint-enabled CRM tables/entities (account and related). 
 *  Which of these entities store documents under the account-level root folder. 
 *  Which entities use their own independent folder structure. 
 *  Which related records may experience reparenting during the merge. 
 

 *  Analyze SharePoint Folder Dependencies During Merge 

 *  Given a CRM account merge does not consolidate SharePoint libraries, 
 *  When an account is merged and becomes inactivated, 
 *  Then the spike must document: 
 *  What happens to each document library and folder reference. 
 *  Whether subfolders (e.g., Service Visits ? Documents) remain linked to the inactivated account folder. 
 *  The impact of record reparenting on folder paths. 
 *  Any broken links, orphaned directories, or required re-mapping. 
 

 *  Determine Migration Options (SSIS vs. Power Automate vs. Others) 

 *  Given documents need to be migrated from inactivated account libraries to the surviving account’s library, 
 *  When evaluating technical approaches, 
 *  Then the team must produce a comparison including: 
 *  Feasibility of Power Automate to copy/move SharePoint content at scale. 
 *  Feasibility of SSIS/KingswaySoft using SharePoint APIs. 
 *  Pros/cons including performance, error handling, authentication, volume limits, throttling, monitoring, extensibility. 
 *  A recommended approach with justification. 
 

 *  Define Migration Logic & Required Metadata 

 *  Given multiple inactivated accounts may merge into a surviving account, 
 *  When migration logic is analyzed, 
 *  Then the spike must define: 

 *  How to map every inactivated account to its surviving account. 
 *  How to detect and migrate associated subfolders (e.g., service visits, work orders, etc.). 
 *  How to preserve version history, created by, and timestamps (if feasible). 
 *  How to handle file conflicts (same name, same folder). 
 *  How to handle large file types or unsupported file formats. 
 

 

 *  Document All Scenarios 

 *  Given not all entities behave the same way, 
 *  When reviewing all folders and references, 
 *  Then the spike must document separate approaches for: 
 *  Account-level folders only 
 *  Account-level + nested related-record folders 
 *  Entities with independent folder roots 
 *  Entities that do not require migration 
 *  Scenarios where reparenting does not require moving documents 
 

 *  Define End-to-End Technical Approach 

 *  Given a recommended solution must be provided, 
 *  When the spike is complete, 
 *  Then the team must deliver a document outlining: 
 *  Overall design (workflow, triggers, inputs, outputs) 
 *  Step-by-step migration procedure 
 *  Error handling and retry strategy 
 *  Estimated run-time and performance considerations 
 

 *  Deliver Final Technical Recommendation 

 *  Given this spike’s purpose is decision-making, 
 *  When all investigation tasks are complete, 
 *  Then the team must deliver a finalized recommendation including: 
 *  Selected migration technology (SSIS, Power Automate, or hybrid) 
 *  Why it is the recommended approach 
 *  Required configuration changes (SharePoint + CRM)

column8: Migrate CMV Tool SharePoint Documents During Account Merge
DC: 1C Go-Live – Migrate SharePoint Documents During Water Account Merges (Canada & USA)
column11:
As a data conversion team member,
I need to identify and migrate SharePoint documents from inactive (merged) Water accounts to the surviving Water account,
 
so that all customer documents remain accessible post-merge, since Dataverse account merge does not automatically move SharePoint libraries.
 

 
This activity must support both Canada and USA 1C Go-Live cutovers and apply to all merge scenarios involving multiple Water accounts. 
 

 
Background/Context: 

 *  As part of the 1C account merge process, multiple Water accounts may be merged into a single surviving Water account 
 *  Dataverse out-of-the-box account merge does NOT merge SharePoint document libraries 
 *  Without intervention: 

 *  Documents remain attached to inactive Water accounts 
 *  Users lose visibility to historical documents post-merge 
 

 *  This impacts both: 

 *  Canada 1C Go-Live 
 *  USA 1C Go-Live 
 

 

Source of Truth for Merge Identification:
 
 

 *  Canada: [1CGoLiveExcelData] 
 *  USA: [1CGoLiveExcelData_USA] 
 *  These tables define: 

 *  Survivor Water account 
 *  Inactive (merged) Water accounts 
 *  Applicable merge scenarios 
 

 

In-Scope Merge Scenarios:
 
 

 *  This story applies to Water-only merge scenarios, including (but not limited to):(Any scenario where multiple Water accounts collapse into one surviving Water account) 
 *  Sold_To_5 
 *  Sold_To_6 
 *  Sold_To_9 
 


 
 
In Scope: 

 *  Identify inactive Water accounts being merged 
 *  Identify surviving Water account 
 *  Detect SharePoint documents attached to inactive accounts 
 *  Move documents to the survivor account’s SharePoint library 
 *  Preserve: 

 *  Document content 
 *  File names 
 *  Versions 
 *  Metadata (where supported)
column19: Moved out of state Sprint Ready
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria: 

 *  Identify Water Account Merge Candidates 

 *  Given Go-Live data is available 
 *  When the conversion process runs 
 *  Then the system identifies all scenarios where: 

 *  Multiple Water accounts exist 
 *  One Water account is marked as the survivor 
 *  One or more Water accounts are marked inactive post-merge 
 

 

 *  Source Table Selection 

 *  Given the cutover country is known 
 *  When merge identification begins 
 *  Then: 

 *  Canada merges use [1CGoLiveExcelData] 
 *  USA merges use [1CGoLiveExcelData_USA] 
 

 

 *  Detect SharePoint Documents on Inactive Accounts 

 *  Given an inactive Water account is identified 
 *  When its SharePoint document location is evaluated 
 *  Then all documents associated with that account’s SharePoint library are identified for migration 
 

 *  Move Documents to Survivor Account 

 *  Given documents exist on an inactive Water account 
 *  When document migration is executed 
 *  Then documents are moved to the surviving Water account’s SharePoint library 
 

 *  Preserve Document Integrity 

 *  Given documents are migrated 
 *  When the move completes 
 *  Then: 

 *  File content is preserved 
 *  File name is unchanged 
 *  Folder structure is preserved (where applicable) 
 *  Version history is retained (subject to SharePoint constraints) 
 

 

 *  Avoid Duplicate Document Creation 

 *  Given documents are moved 
 *  When a document with the same name already exists on the survivor account 
 *  Then the process: 

 *  Prevents silent duplication 
 *  Follows defined conflict handling rules (e.g., append suffix or log exception) 
 

 

 *  Logging and Traceability 

 *  Given document migration occurs 
 *  When the process completes 
 *  Then a log is produced containing: 

 *  Source account ID 
 *  Survivor account ID 
 *  Document count moved 
 *  Any failures or skipped records

column8: DC: USA 1C – Go-Live Data Conversion via SSIS Package Cloning
column11:
As a data conversion team member,
I want to clone and update existing Canada 1C SSIS packages to support USA 1C Go-Live data using a separate source table,
 
so that both Canada and USA 1C data are available in lower environments for UAT without impacting or reworking the existing Canada conversion logic.
 

 
Background / Context: 

 *  The Canada 1C Go-Live data conversion is already implemented using SSIS packages that source data from: 
 *  [1CGoLiveExcelData] 
 *  For USA 1C, a new table has been created and populated with identical schema: 
 *  [1CGoLiveExcelData_USA] 
 *  To support parallel UAT for Canada and USA (targeting mid-January 2026), the data conversion logic must: 

 *  Reuse the existing Canada SSIS logic 
 *  Avoid modifying or destabilizing Canada packages 
 *  Introduce USA-specific cloned packages that point exclusively to USA Go-Live data 
 

 

Scope: 
 

 *  Cloning existing SSIS packages that currently reference [1CGoLiveExcelData] 
 *  Updating cloned packages to reference [1CGoLiveExcelData_USA] 
 *  Supporting all Sold-To and Ship-To scenarios currently handled for Canada 
 *  Updating validation and post-load scripts to support USA data 
 

Naming Convention: 

 *  Canada packages: No change
 
 *  USA packages: USA_<ExistingPackageName> 

 *  Example:  

 *  USA_Load_1C_SoldTo_Accounts 
 *  USA_Load_1C_ShipTo_Sites
column19: Moved out of state In Development
column22:
*  SSIS Package Cloning 

 *  Given existing SSIS packages that source data from [1CGoLiveExcelData] 
 *  When USA Go-Live conversion support is implemented 
 *  Then each relevant package is cloned with prefix USA_ and retained as a separate SSIS package 
 

 *  Source Table Updates 

 *  Given a cloned USA SSIS package 
 *  When reviewing all source queries and data flows 
 *  Then all references to [1CGoLiveExcelData] are replaced with [1CGoLiveExcelData_USA] 
 

 *  Destination Mapping Consistency 

 *  Given a USA SSIS package 
 *  When data is loaded into CRM staging and target tables 
 *  Then destination tables, mappings, and transformations remain identical to the Canada logic 
 

 *  Script Updates 

 *  Given pre-load, post-load, and validation SQL scripts used by Canada packages 
 *  When USA conversion is implemented 
 *  Then equivalent USA scripts are created that reference [1CGoLiveExcelData_USA] 
 

 *  Scenario Coverage 

 *  Given the existing Canada conversion supports: 

 *  Sold-To scenarios (e.g., Sold-To-1 through Sold-To-9) 
 *  Ship-To scenarios 
 

 *  When USA packages are executed 
 *  Then all the same scenarios are supported using USA Go-Live data 
 

 *  Parallel Execution 

 *  Given both Canada and USA packages exist 
 *  When SSIS packages are executed in lower environments 
 *  Then Canada packages read only from [1CGoLiveExcelData] 
 *  And USA packages read only from [1CGoLiveExcelData_USA] 
 *  And neither execution impacts the other

column8: DC: Recreate Water SOWs to Surviving Hygiene H5 Accounts.
column11:
As a Data Conversion Analyst,
 
I need to re-parent all active Scope of Work (SOW) records from Water H5 accounts to the surviving Hygiene H5 account during the 1C consolidation,
 
So that there is a single surviving H5 account holding both Water and Hygiene SOWs, ensuring continuity and alignment with the One Customer model.
 

 
Background & Rationale:
 

 *  In the One Customer (1C) design, Water H5 accounts are being merged into Hygiene H5 accounts. 
 *  Today, SOWs are tied directly to H5 accounts. Without re-parenting, Water SOWs would remain orphaned on inactive Water H5 accounts. 
 *  Business requires that all active Water SOWs be preserved and made visible under the surviving Hygiene H5 account. 
 *  Re-parenting ensures data continuity, user visibility, and downstream alignment with Sales Skill–based filtering. 
 *  Non-1C accounts remain unchanged. 
 


 
Business Requirements: 

 *  Identify all Water H5 accounts marked for consolidation into Hygiene H5 accounts. 
 *  Re-parent all active SOWs from Water H5 accounts to the mapped surviving Hygiene H5 account. 
 *  Ensure inactive/expired SOWs remain untouched. 
 *  Preserve all SOW attributes during migration (Name, Start Date, End Date, Status, Owner, Sales Skill, Commitments). 
 *  Update relationships so that re-parented SOWs appear correctly in the SOW tab of the surviving Hygiene H5. 
 *  Generate audit logs of re-parenting (source H5, target H5, SOW IDs moved, timestamp). 
 *  Produce an exception report for any failures or unmapped records. 
 *  Apply changes only for 1C districts; no impact to non-1C H5s.
column19: Moved out of state In QA
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria:
 
 
 
 

 *  Scenario 1 – Active Water SOWs on 1C H5 merge 

 *  Given a Water H5 account is merged into a Hygiene H5 account as part of 1C consolidation, 
 *  When the data conversion process runs, 
 *  Then all active SOWs from the Water H5 must be re-created to the surviving Hygiene H5 account. 
 

 *  Scenario 2 – Expired/Inactive Water SOWs 

 *  Given a Water H5 account has inactive or expired SOWs, 
 *  When the data conversion process runs, 
 *  Then those inactive records remain unchanged and do not require re-parenting. 
 

 *  Scenario 3 – Data continuity validation 

 *  Given re-parenting has been executed, 
 *  When I view the surviving Hygiene H5 account, 
 *  Then all previously active Water SOWs should appear in the SOW grid of the Hygiene H5, with their original details preserved (name, start/end date, status, owner, sales skill). 
 

 *  Scenario 4 – Non-1C accounts 

 *  Given a Water H5 account is not in a 1C district, 
 *  When the data conversion runs, 
 *  Then no changes occur and the Water H5 retains its existing SOWs. 
 

 *  Scenario 5 – Exception reporting 

 *  Given a re-parenting job is run, 
 *  When a Water SOW cannot be re-parented (e.g., missing Hygiene H5 mapping), 
 *  Then the process must log the exception with record details for reconciliation.

column8: DC: Analysis - U.S. Sold-To / Ship-To Data Analysis for 1C Conversion Readiness
column11:
As a CRM Data Migration Analyst,
I need to perform a comprehensive analysis of the U.S. Sold-To and Ship-To Go-Live dataset shared by the business,
 
so that all 1C scenarios, gaps, discrepancies, H5 alignment issues, and corporate account mismatches are fully identified and communicated prior to design and build.
 

 
Context and Background: 

 *  The business has shared a U.S. dataset (Sold-To + Ship-To) for validating the 1C conversion and merge rules. 
 *  This story covers data profiling and scenario classification only—no build or CRM updates. 
 *  The analysis must: 

 *  Load the U.S. dataset into a staging table for querying. 
 *  Identify and classify all Sold-To scenarios (1 through 9) based on business definitions. 
 *  Determine which Ship-Tos will be converted into Sold-Tos based on scenario logic. 
 *  Cross-validate U.S. Go-Live data against current CRM production data to find mismatches. 
 *  Validate H5 (Org Account) alignment for all accounts. 
 *  Identify any “missing” accounts that are active in CRM but not provided in the 1C file, and vice-versa. 
 *  Analyze corporate account alignment between Water and Hygiene. 
 *  Produce a consolidated analysis summary and discrepancy list to the business for cleanup. 
 

 *  This story ensures the data foundation is correct before any 1C conversion logic or migration is executed.
column19: Moved out of state In Development
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria:  

 *  Load U.S. dataset for analysis 

 *  Given the business has shared a U.S. Sold-To/Ship-To file, 
 *  When analysis begins, 
 *  Then the file must be loaded into a temporary SQL table for classified scenario analysis. 
 

 *  Classify all Sold-To scenarios (Scenario 1–9) 

 *  Given the data is available in the staging table, 
 *  When scenario logic is applied, 
 *  Then each record must be categorized into one of the following: 

 *  Sold-To Scenario 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, or 9— 
 *  and counts must be produced per scenario. 
 

 

 *  Identify Ship-Tos that will convert to Sold-Tos 

 *  Given scenario rules include Ship-To ? Sold-To transformations, 
 *  When conditions are evaluated, 
 *  Then the analysis must produce: 

 *  List of Ship-To numbers converting to Sold-To 
 *  Count of such records 
 *  Flag per record indicating the scenario causing the conversion 
 

 

 *  Cross-validate account existence against CRM Production 

 *  Given CRM production contains active 1C districts and active accounts, 
 *  When the dataset is compared, 
 *  Then the output must identify: 

 *  Accounts present in CRM but missing in the business file 
 *  Accounts present in the business file but inactive in CRM 
 *  Accounts repeated or incorrectly duplicated 
 *  Any district-mismatch issues 
 

 

 *  Validate H5 (Org Account) alignment for Water accounts 
 *  Given each Water Sold-To is tied to an Org Account 
 *  When child accounts related to that Org Account are retrieved , 
 *  Then the analysis must identify: 

 *  What child Accounts linked to Water Org Account are missing from business go live data for USA Accounts 
 *  How many org accounts have all child accounts part of the 1C go live data 
 *  Accounts mapped to legacy Water/Hygiene org accounts that do not exist in the 1C file 
 

 *  Identify “surviving” vs “non-surviving” records 

 *  Given the 1C business file includes survivor markers, 
 *  When those flags are read, 
 *  Then the analysis must: 

 *  Produce a list of expected surviving accounts 
 *  Confirm whether surviving accounts actually exist in CRM 
 *  Identify records incorrectly flagged or missing a survivor indicator 
 

 

 *  Analyze corporate account alignment (Water vs Hygiene) 

 *  Given corporate IDs differ between Water and Hygiene in many cases, 
 *  When comparison is run per BCA, 
 *  Then the analysis must identify: 

 *  Mismatches where Water ? Hygiene 
 *  Missing corporate IDs on either side 
 *  Cases where Hygiene corporate is empty but Water corporate has value 
 *  Cases where Water is empty but Hygiene has value 
 

 

 *  Provide detailed counts and summaries 

 *  Given analysis has been completed, 
 *  When preparing outputs, 
 *  Then the story must produce: 

 *  Total Sold-To / Ship-To counts per scenario 
 *  Count of valid matches 
 *  Count of mismatches 
 *  Count of missing or unexpected records 
 *  Corporate alignment summary 
 *  H5 alignment summary 
 *  Final exceptions list 
 

 

 *  Provide detailed discrepancy list to business 
 *  Given all discrepancies are identified, 
 *  When results are compiled, 
 *  Then a structured output must be delivered containing: 

 *  Missing accounts 
 *  Inactive vs active mismatches 
 *  Corporate ID misalignment 
 *  Orphan child accounts 
 *  Invalid scenario records 
 *  Possible business data quality issues requiring correction  
 

 *  and shared with Bri and business teams for review.

column8: DC: Data Migration of Service Templates to Surviving H5 Organization Accounts After 1C Conversion
column11:
As a CRM Data Migration Engineer,
I need to migrate all Water service templates (and their dependent child records) from legacy Water organization accounts into the surviving merged H5 Organization Account,
 
so that Water + Hygiene share a single combined service template structure under the unified 1C account model, without losing any legacy configurations.
 

 
Context and Background: 
In the current (pre-1C) CRM structure, Water and Hygiene maintain separate Organization Accounts and separate Service Templates for the same customer.
After 1C conversion:
 

 *  Both Water and Hygiene Sales Skill Accounts will be merged and linked to one unified H5 Organization Account. 
 *  Under the 1C model, each H5 org account must have one combined service template per asset type (not separate Water/Hygiene templates). 
 

 
Therefore, as part of data migration: 

 *  We must identify all legacy Water org accounts participating in the 1C merge. 
 *  For each Water org account, retrieve all active service template records and copy them under the corresponding surviving H5 org account. 
 *  Ensure no duplicate service templates are created if the Hygiene org account already owns a template for the same asset type. 
 *  Migrate the entire hierarchy of template-related records: 

 *  Asset Type Template 
 *  Asset Type Service Template 
 *  Asset Type Service Template Activity 
 *  Asset Type Service Template Sub-Task 
 

 *  Mark each migrated template with the correct SalesSkillDescription value (Hygiene / Water / Hygiene and Water ). 
 *  All moves are copy-and-relink, not delete-and-replace. 
 *  All joins, child table logic, and conditions must follow CRM table listed in the attached SQL Queries
column19: Moved out of state In QA
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria: 

 *  Identify all Water org accounts requiring migration 

 *  Given a list of legacy Water Sold-To accounts that participate in 1C merging, 
 *  When the migration begins, 
 *  Then the system must retrieve: 

 *  The Water Org Account ID linked to each Sold-To. 
 *  The corresponding surviving H5 Org Account ID from the 1C Go Live table ([1CGoLiveExcelData]). 
 

 

 *  Retrieve all active service template records from Water org accounts 

 *  Given a Water org account that is being merged, 
 *  When querying the template tables, 
 *  Then the migration must fetch only active records from: 

 *  ECL_AssetTypeTemplate 
 *  ECL_AssetTypeServiceTemplate 
 *  ECL_AssetTypeServiceTemplateActivity 
 *  ECL_AssetTypeServiceTemplateSubTask 
 

 *  Using the proper joins between: Attached SQL Query has all the joins properly identified 
 *  AssetTypeTemplate ? ServiceTemplate ? Activity ? SubTask 
 

 *  Prevent creation of duplicate service templates under H5 

 *  Given an asset type already exists in the Hygiene/H5 service templates, 
 *  When Water templates are being migrated, 
 *  Then: 
 *  Do NOT create a new Asset Type Template for the same asset type under the H5 org account. 
 *  Only copy related child records (ServiceTemplate, Activity, SubTask) and re-link them to the existing template. 
 

 *  Create new Asset Type Template only when asset type does not already exist 

 *  Given the Water org account has a template for an asset type that does not exist under H5, 
 *  When migrating, 
 *  Then: 
 *  Create a new Asset Type Template under the H5 org account. 
 *  Set the SalesSkillDescription value appropriately: 
 *  “Water ” 
 *  “Hygiene ” 
 *  “Water and Hygiene” (if combined) 
 

 *  Migrate the hierarchy of related template records 

 *  Given Water template records are being copied, 
 *  When creating corresponding ServiceTemplate, Activity, and SubTask records under H5, 
 *  Then: 
 *  All child objects must be created with new GUIDs. 
 *  All parent-child links must reference the H5 Asset Type Template version. 
 *  Only active original records should be migrated. 
 

 *  Re-link all migrated records to H5 org account 

 *  Given the new or existing H5 Asset Type Template record, 
 *  When creating the migrated versions, 
 *  Then: 
 *  All records must reference the H5 Organization Account ID. 
 *  No migrated record should reference the legacy Water org account. 
 

 *  No changes should be made to original Water templates 

 *  Given Water org accounts will be made inactive after the merge, 
 *  When the migration is executed, 
 *  Then: 
 *  Original Water templates remain untouched. 
 *  Only the new copies under H5 are used going forward. 
 

 *  Migration audit output must be produced 

 *  Given migration execution is complete, 
 *  When generating the summary, 
 *  Then the team must produce: 
 *  Count of templates found 
 *  Count of templates migrated 
 *  Count of asset types skipped due to duplicates 
 *  Count of activities & subtasks migrated 
 *  Any errors or mismatches

Scenario 2 – Retrieve all activeservice template records from Water org accounts

Scenario 3 – Prevent creation ofduplicate service templates under Food & Beverage Org/H5 Account 
Precondition: An asset type template already exists for the Destination Food & Beverage Org/H5 account. 

 
 *  Validate     no new Asset Type Template is created for the same asset type under the Food & Beverage Org/H5 account. 
 
 *  Ensure     Only related child records are copied (ServiceTemplate, Activity, SubTask) to the existing template 
 

Scenario 4 – Create new Asset TypeTemplate only when asset type service template does not already exist under Food & Beverage Org/H5 Account 
Precondition:  The Water org account has atemplate for an asset type that does not exist under Food & Beverage Org/H5 Account

Scenario 5 - Migrate the hierarchyof related template records 
Precondition: Water template records are beingcopied 

 
 *  Validate     all parent-child links reference the Food & Beverage Org/H5 Account Asset Type Template version. 
 
 *  Ensure     only active records from the Source Asset Type templates are copied to the Food & Beverage Org/H5 Account Asset Type Template version. 
 

Scenario 6 – Re-link all migratedrecords to H5 org account  
Precondition: Water template records are beingcopied.  

 
 *  Validate     all records must reference the H5 Organization Account ID.  
 
 *  Ensure     no migrated record should reference the legacy Water org account.  
 

Scenario 7 – No changes should bemade to original Nalco Water Asset Type templates 
Precondition: Water org accounts will be madeinactive after the merge.  

 
 *  Validate     the Original Water templates remain untouched.  
 
 *  Ensure     only the new copies under H5 are used going forward.

column6: CRM: TSR’s (Technical Service Requests) Process - Technical Spike and Regression Testing Only
column11:
*  
Requirements:  
 
 

 *  
Global Business Field Replacement 
 

 *  Hide Global Business field in future state 
 *  Introduce Sales Skill as the driver for form logic and field visibility. 
 

 

 *  
EBS Integration Readiness 

 *  Ensure TSR forms and logic are compatible with EBS-driven account structures. 
 *  Prepare for mapping and updating SAP Work Center codes to EBS equivalents. 
 

 
 


 

 
Context: 
 

 *  The TSR process is used to initiate and manage technical service requests across divisions (Nalco Water, Food & Beverage, Life Sciences). 
 *  It supports service delivery, resource assignment, and approval workflows. 
 *  A separate active project is focused on harmonizing the TSR process across divisions to ensure consistency and enable CRM-driven automation and reporting. 
 *  This harmonization effort is not in R1 or R2 scope. No ETA on project timeline. 
 

 
 
Groups:
 
 

 *   Hygiene, Water, & Life Sciences 
 

 
 
Personas: 
 
 

 *  Product Owner: Kathleen Guekens 
 *  Sales Representatives initiate TSRs. 
 *  Technical Resource Managers (TRMs) approve and assign Subject Matter Experts (SMEs). 
 *  SMEs execute the service visits. 
 *  Field Service Operations teams manage recurring services and validate billing arrangements 
 

 
 
 
Business Process Flow:
BPF stages: Origination, Manager (for some groups), Routing, In-Process, Finalize
 

 *  Sales Rep navigates to an Account in CRM 
 *  Sales Rep creates TSR in CRM. 
 *  Selects TSR group, type, application area, and unit. 
 *  Inputs cost center and pack code (if applicable). 
 *  Specifies business status (new, existing, jeopardy), issue, and scope. 
 *  TSR is routed to manager (if required) and then to TRM. 
 *  TRM approves and assigns SME. 
 *  TSR may include travel approval and risk assessment. 
 *  TSR is finalized with classification and optional attachments 
 

 
 
Downstream Systems/Integration:

 *  TSRs link to CRM master data and drive service visit creation. 
 *  Integration with SAP for service orders via SAP Work Center codes. 
 *  Billing arrangements (BA) are validated and linked to TSRs. 
 *  Value Added Services (VAS) may be created from TSRs or service activities  
 

 
Impact Considerations:
 

 *  TSR Originator form in CRM has a quick view form showing “Global Business” field.   
 *  TSRs rely on SAP Work Center codes, which will be replaced by EBS Work Center codes. A mapping exercise is required to update existing recurring service orders  
 *  Billing Arrangements (BA) will continue to exist post-EBS migration, but the integration strategy and data feed updates are still under discussion. 
 *  There’s a need to determine how to handle field service users who are not aligned to district teams, as they lack sales skill or district attributes that drive current logic 
 *  Field visibility and requirements are driven by: 

 *  Global Business (currently visible, future state hidden). 
 *  Sales Skill (to replace Global Business for field logic). 
 *  TSR Group (determines required fields like pack code). 
 *  Stage of TSR (fields may become mandatory at later stages). 
 *  Harmonization aims to standardize forms and reduce discrepancies between divisions 
 

 *  Existing separate project is doing this. Not in R2scope. No eta on project timeline.

column7: CRM: Enable Sales Skill–Based Logic and Future Harmonization for Technical Service Request (TSR) Process
column11:
As part of the One Customer (1C) initiative, Ecolab aims to harmonize the Technical Service Request (TSR) process across Water, Food & Beverage (Hygiene), and Life Science divisions to ensure a unified, consistent user experience and to prepare the platform for cross-divisional service standardization.

 
Today, TSR behavior (forms, approvals, field requirements, and reporting) differs across divisions: 

 *  Nalco Water requires PAC Code and Cost Center, and includes a Manager Approval stage. 
 *  Food & Beverage (Hygiene) excludes those fields and omits Manager Approval. 
 *  Life Science adds an additional Motivation step linking TSRs to Opportunities, TVD Programs, or RTW records. 
 *  Additionally, field visibility is currently controlled by Global Business, which will no longer be reliable under the 1C model. 
 

 
To align TSRs with the One Customer model and future-proof system behavior: 

 *  Global Business–based logic must be replaced by Sales Skill–driven logic. 
 *  UI components (like the Account Quick View on TSR) must dynamically display Sales Skill for 1C accounts. 
 *  A technical spike must first identify all field, BPF, and approval flow differences, as well as harmonization feasibility and effort estimates for implementation in a future release. 
 

 
This requirement establishes the foundation for harmonizing TSRs and ensuring that 1C-related accounts are fully integrated with the Sales Skill–based architecture. 

 
Business Objectives 

 *  Create a unified and flexible TSR process compatible with One Customer (1C) architecture. 
 *  Replace outdated Global Business logic with Sales Skill for all 1C accounts. 
 *  Enable accurate filtering, field visibility, and approval routing across divisions. 
 *  Prepare CRM for future TSR harmonization and consistent reporting across all business units. 
 

 
Scope 

 *  In Scope: 

 *  All divisions currently using TSR (Nalco Water, F&B Hygiene, Life Science). 
 *  CRM form changes (Quick View adjustments, field visibility, BPF review). 
 *  Technical spike to analyze harmonization feasibility, configuration, and effort. 
 *  Preparation for future R3 harmonization implementation. 
 

 *  Out of Scope (for R2): 

 *  Actual harmonization of TSR workflows and approval processes. 
 *  Major reengineering or consolidation of TSR entities. 
 

 

 
Expected Business Outcome 

 *  One consistent foundation for TSR process improvement and harmonization. 
 *  Sales Skill–based logic implemented for field visibility on all 1C records. 
 *  Feasibility report and roadmap defined for harmonized TSR rollout in a future release. 
 *  Reduced confusion for users managing TSRs across Water and Hygiene accounts.

column8: Technical Spike – Assess Feasibility and Effort for Harmonization of Technical Service Request (TSR) Process Across Divisions
column11:
As a Solution and Technical Architect,
I want to conduct a detailed technical analysis of the Technical Service Request (TSR) process across Nalco Water, Food & Beverage (Hygiene), and Life Science,
 
so that we can determine the changes, effort, and dependencies required to harmonize the TSR entity, business process flow, and field visibility/requirement logic into a single standardized configuration for future One Customer (1C) enablement.
 

 
Context and Background 
The TSR module is used by multiple Ecolab divisions to document, approve, and execute technical service activities. 
While the process intent is similar, each division follows different configurations, resulting in inconsistent behavior, reporting, and approval flows:
 

 *  Nalco Water: 

 *  Includes a Manager Approval stage. 
 *  Requires Cost Center and PAC Code fields. 
 

 *  Food & Beverage (Hygiene): 

 *  No Manager Approval stage. 
 *  Cost Center and PAC Code are not required. 
 

 *  Life Science: 

 *  Adds an additional Motivation step for linking TSRs to Opportunity, TVD Program, or Retain-to-Win (RTW). 
 

 

 
The long-term goal is to harmonize these differences so all divisions follow a unified TSR process, ensuring consistent data and user experience across Ecolab. 
However, full harmonization is not part of R2 scope — instead, this technical spike aims to analyze feasibility, enumerate all process and configuration differences, and estimate the effort required for implementation in a future release (R3 or later).
 

 
Objectives of the Spike 

 *  Catalog field-level differences (visibility, requirement, default values, conditional logic). 
 *  Identify where PAC Code and Cost Center are required, hidden, or optional. 
 *  Compare Business Process Flow (BPF) configurations, stages, and transition rules across divisions. 
 *  Assess how Sales Skill can replace Global Business for field visibility and requirement logic in 1C. 
 *  Evaluate approval logic (Manager Approval vs. SME Approval) and its technical implementation. 
 *  Document data model and integration dependencies (EBS, reporting). 
 *  Estimate effort and outline a recommended harmonization approach for future release. 
 

 
Deliverables 

 *  Field-Level Comparison Matrix: Required/optional/hidden fields by division (Water, F&B, Life Science). 
 *  BPF Comparison Document: Stage names, transitions, and conditional logic across divisions. 
 *  Visibility Logic Mapping: Transition from Global Business–based logic to Sales Skill–based logic. 
 *  Harmonization Approach Proposal: Options for unifying TSR forms, workflows, and approvals. 
 *  Effort and Risk Estimate: Configuration, development, regression, and testing effort. 
 *  Summary Report: Documented findings and next-step recommendations.
column19: Moved out of state In Development
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria 

 *  Scenario 1 – Field-Level Comparison Across Divisions 

 *  Given that each division (Water, F&B, Life Science) has different field configurations, 
 *  When the spike analysis is conducted, 
 *  Then the output must clearly list for each field whether it is: 

 *  Required 
 *  Optional 
 *  Hidden 
 *  Conditional (depends on stage or role) 
 *  And specifically identify where PAC Code and Cost Center are mandatory vs. not used. 
 

 

 *  Scenario 2 – Business Process Flow (BPF) Mapping 

 *  Given that divisions use distinct BPFs, 
 *  When the stages and approval flows are analyzed, 
 *  Then the documentation must highlight all stage-level differences, including: 
 *  Presence/absence of Manager Approval 
 *  Motivation step linkage in Life Science 
 *  Field requirement changes per stage. 
 

 *  Scenario 3 – Harmonization Feasibility and Effort Estimation 

 *  Given that all differences have been cataloged, 
 *  When the team reviews dependencies and configuration effort, 
 *  Then the spike must provide: 

 *  Estimated story-point or hour effort for each harmonization component, 
 *  Identified risks, and 
 *  Technical feasibility summary. 
 

 

 *  Scenario 4 – Reporting and Downstream Impact 

 *  Given that unified reporting is an expected outcome of harmonization, 
 *  When the team reviews data models and reporting integrations, 
 *  Then the output must indicate: 
 *  Current reporting limitations, 
 *  Required data alignment (Snowflake/Power BI), and 
 *  Regression-testing impacts. 
 

 *  Completion Criteria 

 *  Comparative analysis and proposed harmonization approach reviewed with Kathleen (PO) and core technical leads (Shamil, Arpit, Zahara). 
 *  Findings documented in Confluence/SharePoint and linked to the R2 technical backlog. 
 *  Review session conducted to finalize harmonization recommendations and effort sizing.

column6: CRM: Total Value Delivered (TVD) Programs - Regression Testing Only
column11:
Context:  
•TheCRM system serves as the central platform for managing customer interactions,tracking Total Value Delivered (TVD) programs, and integrating data fromvarious tools and applications. It enables: 
•Lifecyclemanagement of projects from initiation to completion. 
•Integrationwith calculators, Power BI, and Ecolab 3D for reporting and visualization. 
•Supportfor both manual and automated data entry processes 
Groups:  
•Hygiene& Water As-Is. No change required for R2.  
Personas: 
•SalesRepresentatives:To initiate and manage CRM the programs/projects and customer interactions. 
•AccountManagers:To track and update CRM records through various stages. 
•CRMTechnical Team:To support integrations, API management, and data flow. 
•TVDCalculator Team:To push calculated data into CRM. 
•GlobalBI Team:To consume CRM data for reporting. 
•Ecolab3D Team:To visualize CRM data for customer-facing dashboards 
Downstream Systems/Integration: 
•Snowflake:Aggregates CRM data for reporting and visualization. 
•Ecolab3D:Displays financial impact and project status to customers. 
•PowerBI:Used internally to monitor TVD Program performance. 
•AIGuided Potential:Uses CRM data to surface best-in-class opportunities 
Impact Considerations (Useof Account, Ship-To, and Site field values): 
•Site:Primary driver for TVD Program creation and calculator alignment. Nochanges for R2. 
•AccountNumber:Used to associate TVD Programs with customer records. No changes for R2. 
•SalesSkill:Will be added to differentiate Program types (e.g., hygiene vs. water). Nochanges for R2. 
•Ship-To:Not directly used in CRM or calculator integration but may appear in accountalignment scenarios No changes for R2. 

 
Business Process Flow: 
1.Initiation 
1.TVDPrograms are pushed to CRM from TVD calculator via the TVD Calculator API.Calculated data is pushed to CRM via API, creating a CRM TVD Program record. 
2.SalesRep manually creates the TVD Program record in CRM.  
2.CRMTVD Program Record Lifecycle Management 
1.SalesRep updates the CRM Program record, fills in the business process flow stageinputs. 
2.CRMtracks the TVD Program through stages: Identified ? Approved ? In Process ?Implemented ? Final Sign-off. 
3.Ifthe TVD Program was manually created in CRM, then the record pushes to Ecolab3D 

 
3.Reporting& Visualization 
1.CRMdata is accessed via Snowflake views, which feed Power BI and Ecolab 3Ddashboards

column6: CRM: Tank Orders Process
column11:
Business Purpose/Context
 
 
 
 
 
D365 Tank Order is used by Sales Reps to capture Tank Order details and facilitate order approval.
Volume: 60 new Base Tank (PORTA-feed) orders per month. 90% USA, 10% Canada.
The Tank Order Process is a feature within the F&B United CRM system designed to manage the end-to-end lifecycle of tank orders, primarily for Base Tank (PORTA-feed) and Bulk Tank types.

 
Tank Order Types & Definitions 
 

 *  Two main Order Types: Base Tank (PORTA-feed) and Bulk Tank.  
 *  Three Request Types: New, Product Change, Label Change. 
 *  Label changes are increasing due to EVD standards. 
 *  Base Tank (PORTA-feed) represents the bulk of Tank Orders.  
 

 
Key Functionalities: 
- Manual entry of tank serial numbers, product setup, and label Adjust CRM views and workflows to support new matching logic. 
- Retain manual approval steps until automation is feasible. 
- Manual entry of tank serial numbers, product setup, and label requirements. 
- Embedded safety and delivery checklists (currently manual). 
- Mandatory fields include Ship-To Sold -To address and delivery info. 
- Ship-To Sold -To logic is restrictive—only one pre-existing address can be selected per order 

Integration & Data Management: 
- No current integration with NSAP/EBS; master data duplication expected. 
- CRM must support dual maintenance of customer and tank records across EBS and NSAP. 
- Legacy account numbers and mapping logic need updates for post-EBS migration. 
- Mapping between EBS Ship-To and NSAP intercompany Ship-To is a critical challenge. 

 
Workflow & Approvals: 
- Business Process Flow (BPF) manages approvals. 
- Reviewer/Approver is assigned by matching Ship-To Zip Code with Base Tank Plants table Zip Code. 
- CRM automates warehouse assignment and hazardous product checks using static reference tables. 
- Fulfillment involves 6–7 functional groups (logistics, safety, compliance, warehousing). 
- Final step ("Customer Setup") pushes Tank Order data to downstream systems (manual today). 
 
 

 *  Business Process Flow (BPF) manages approvals, but actual fulfillment steps remain manual. 
 *  Varies per Order and Request Type 
 *  Longest for Order Type = Base Tank 
 *  At end of step “Customer Steup” the Tank Order data, including Ship-To, flows out of D365 to downstream systems t0 Prepare Tank. (Manually done today 
 *  CRM automates warehouse assignment and hazardous product checks but relies on static reference tables Base Tank Plants & Base Tank Sizes (zip - warehouse). 
 *  Approvals trigger CRM queues, but no downstream automation or automated messaging exists today. 
 *  Reviewer/Approver is assigned by matching the Tank Orders table Ship-To Zip Code value with the Base Tank Plants table Zip value. 
 *  Tank order fulfillment involves 6–7 functional groups across warehousing, logistics, safety, and compliance. 
 

 

 
 
Sales Rep Experience 

 *  Current CRM flow requires multiple manual steps with mandatory fields, ship-to logic, and delivery info. 
 *  Safety and delivery checklists are embedded but heavily manual. 
 *  Ship-To is restricted to one pre-existing Ship-To address per tank order. 
 *  Tank Delivery Business Phone field is not linked to a Contact or Address record. 
 

 

 
 
MasterData Management

 *  Tankserial numbers, bulk tank setup, and product changes are all manually enteredin CRM. 
 *  Nointegration with NSAP/EBS yet; master data duplication is expected. 
 

 
EBS/NSAP Dual Maintenance (Post-Migration) 

 *  Customers, ship-to, and bill-to will exist in both EBS and NSAP, requiring mapping. 
 *  EBS is the system of record, NSAP continues for fulfillment until phased out. 
 *  Mapping between ship-to in EBS and intercompany ship-to in NSAP is a critical technical challenge. 
 *  Tank and ship-to data must be synchronized across CRM, EBS, and NSAP. 
 *  Dual account numbers must be supported (EBS + NSAP). 
 *  Existing CRM logic (e.g., “legacy account number”) will need updates to handle dual mappings. 
 

 


 

BUSINESS PROCESS FLOW:

Tank Order Business Process Flow (As-Is) 

1. Initiation 

 *  Persona: Sales Representative 
 *  Action: Creates a new Tank Order in D365 CRM. 
 *  Details: Selects Order Type (Base Tank or Bulk Tank) and Request Type (New, Product Change, Label Change).  
 

2. Data Entry 

 *  Persona: Sales Representative 
 *  Action: Inputs mandatory fields including Ship-To address, delivery info, and tank details. 
 *  Details: Manual entry of tank serial numbers, product setup, and label requirements.  
 

3. Safety & Delivery Checks 

 *  Persona: Sales Representative + Safety & Compliance Team 
 *  Action: Completes embedded checklists for hazardous product handling and delivery safety. 
 *  Details: Manual process; no automated validation.  
 

4. Approval Routing 

 *  Step: Approval Routing 
 *  Persona: Reviewer/Approver 
 *  Action: CRM routes the Tank Order for approval. 
 *  Logic: The system matches the Ship-To Zip Code from the Tank Orders table with the Zip Code in the Base Tank Plants table. 
 *  Purpose: This determines the appropriate reviewer/approver and initiates CRM queue routing. 
 *  Note: This step currently relies on static reference tables and manual fulfillment.  
 

5. Customer Setup Completion 

 *  Persona: Sales Operations 
 *  Action: Finalizes customer setup and pushes data downstream. 
 *  Details: Ship-To and tank data flow out of CRM to prepare the tank manually.  
 

6. Warehouse Assignment 

 *  Persona: Warehouse Coordinator 
 *  Action: Assigns warehouse based on Zip Code logic. 
 *  Details: Uses static reference tables (Base Tank Plants & Sizes). 
 

7. Tank Fulfillment 

 *  Persona: Logistics, Safety, Compliance, and Warehouse Teams 
 *  Action: Coordinates tank delivery and setup. 
 *  Details: Involves 6–7 functional groups; fulfillment is manual.  
 

8. Post-Order Integration (Currently this is manual. Ecolab wants this automated.) 

 *  Persona: CRM Admin / Integration Specialist 
 *  Action: Syncs data between CRM, EBS, and NSAP. 
 *  Details: Dual maintenance of customer and tank records; legacy account numbers supported.
 
 *  After the "Customer Setup" step, Tank Order data (including Ship-To) flows out of D365 CRM to downstream systems to prepare the tank.  

 *  Customer Setup Group opens NSAP Customer record, creates an Equipment record, associates the product and bask tank to the Equipment record.  
 *  Some sort of approval occurs 
 *  Then, TBD is manually updated in CRM.  
 *  Business to determine EBS/NSAP/CRM data flow needs such as in which system does the Tank record setup begin.  
 

 *  This integration is not automated and lacks messaging or queue management.  
 *  CRM currently supports manual dual maintenance of customer and tank records between EBS and NSAP, including legacy account numbers. 

 


 

Dual Maintenance:

1. Customers, Ship-To, and Bill-To Exist in Both Systems
 
   - Ensures CRM can access and validate customer data regardless of which system it's stored in.
 
   - Prevents order failures due to missing or mismatched customer records.
 

 
2. EBS Is the System of Record; NSAP Continues for Fulfillment
 
   - EBS holds authoritative data, but NSAP still executes deliveries.
 
   - Dual maintenance allows both systems to function in parallel until NSAP is fully phased out.
 

 
3. Mapping Between Ship-To in EBS and Intercompany Ship-To in NSAP
 
   - Critical for accurate fulfillment and warehouse assignment.
 
   - Avoids delivery errors and ensures compliance with logistics protocols.
 

 
4. Synchronization Across CRM, EBS, and NSAP
 
   - Keeps tank and customer data aligned across platforms.
 
   - Supports seamless order processing, approval routing, and fulfillment.
 

 
5. Support for Dual Account Numbers (EBS + NSAP)
 
   - Enables CRM users to reference either system depending on business context.
 
   - Facilitates legacy data access and historical tracking.
 

 
6. Updates to Existing CRM Logic (e.g., Legacy Account Number)
 
   - Necessary to handle dual mappings and prevent logic failures.
 
   - Ensures CRM workflows remain functional and accurate during the transition.

 


 
High-Level Requirements for Regression Testing: 

User Role 
 

When I (Action/Context) 
 

Then I See (System Behavior) 
 

So That I Can (Business Value) 
 

Sales Rep 
 

create a tank order in CRM 
 

required fields and workflow steps 
 

ensure complete and accurate order setup 
 

Sales Rep 
 

submit a tank order 
 

order routed to appropriate approval queues 
 

track progress and receive status updates 
 

Sales Rep 
 

tank order is rejected 
 

receive notification in CRM/email 
 

quickly address issues and resubmit 
 

Data Admin 
 

migrate accounts to EBS 
 

legacy NSAP account numbers retained 
 

maintain supply chain fulfillment links 
 

Sales Rep 
 

select ship-to address 
 

only valid, integrated ship-to options 
 

prevent errors and ensure correct delivery 
 

Sales Rep 
 

request new tank setup 
 

serial number assigned after approval 
 

link tank to customer for future orders

column11:
Enable F&B United CRM to support automated dual-system maintenance for customer and tank order data across EBS and NSAP during post-migration operations. 

 
 
 
Currently this is manual Data flow occurring at the end of the Tank Order Business Process Flow: from EBS to CRM. Then from CRM to NSAP. Then, some details go from NSAP to CRM.   
 

8. Post-Order Integration (Currently this is manual. Ecolab wants this automated.) 

 *  Persona: CRM Admin / Integration Specialist 
 *  Action: Syncs data between CRM, EBS, and NSAP. 
 *  Details: Dual maintenance of customer and tank records; legacy account numbers supported.
 
 *  After the "Customer Setup" step, Tank Order data (including Ship-To) flows out of D365 CRM to downstream systems to prepare the tank.  

 *  Customer Setup Group opens NSAP Customer record, creates an Equipment record, associates the product and bask tank to the Equipment record.  
 *  Some sort of approval occurs 
 *  Then, TBD is manually updated in CRM.  
 *  Business to determine EBS/NSAP/CRM data flow needs such as in which system does the Tank record setup begin.  
 

 *  This integration is not automated and lacks messaging or queue management.  
 *  CRM currently supports manual dual maintenance of customer and tank records between EBS and NSAP, including legacy account numbers. 
 

 

 *  in CRM the records are called Customer Ship To records.  
 *  in EBS the records they are called CPIDS 

 *  EBS has: Customer Sold To, Customer Ship To, Customer Billed To. These are the Customer Account that is tied to the food and beverage sales district and to CRM dynamics
 
 

 *  in NSAP the records are called Receiving Points or Tanks. NSAP has Ecolab
an intercompany ship to that has all of these customer details. Also, one generic sold to for US and there's one generic sold to for Canada. 
 
 


 
EBS/NSAP Dual Maintenance (Post-Migration) 

 *  Customers, ship-to, and bill-to will exist in both EBS and NSAP, requiring mapping. 
 *  EBS is the system of record, NSAP continues for fulfillment until phased out. 
 *  Mapping between ship-to in EBS and intercompany ship-to in NSAP is a critical technical challenge. 
 *  Tank and ship-to data must be synchronized across CRM, EBS, and NSAP. 
 *  Dual account numbers must be supported (EBS + NSAP). 
 *  Existing CRM logic (e.g., “legacy account number”) will need updates to handle dual mappings. 
 

 

 
Business Justification: 
 

 *  The importance of EBS/NSAP Dual Maintenance (Post-Migration) lies in ensuring operational continuity, data integrity, and system interoperability during a phased transition from NSAP to EBS. 
 *  Dual maintenance is a strategic safeguard to ensure that tank orders, customer setups, and fulfillment operations continue smoothly while the enterprise migrates from NSAP to EBS. 
 *  Customers, Ship-To, and Bill-To records will exist in both EBS and NSAP. 
 *  EBS will serve as the system of record, while NSAP continues to fulfill orders until fully phased out. 
 *  Accurate mapping between EBS Ship-To and NSAP intercompany Ship-To is essential for fulfillment and supply chain continuity. 
 

Functional Requirements: 

 *  Dual Record Support 

 *  CRM must support dual maintenance of customer and tank records across EBS and NSAP. 
 *  Legacy account numbers must be retained and referenced. 
 

 *  Mapping Logic 
 

 

 *  Implement logic to map Ship-To and Sold-To between EBS and NSAP. 
 *  Ensure mapping supports both Canada and US go-live scenarios. 
 

 *  CRM Logic Updates 
 

 

 *  Update existing CRM logic (e.g., “legacy account number” fields) to handle dual mappings. 
 *  Adjust CRM views and workflows to reflect both systems. 
 

 *  Data Synchronization 
 

 

 *  Ensure tank and Ship-To data are synchronized across CRM, EBS, and NSAP. 
 *  Validate mapping accuracy in QA/Staging environments before go-live. 
 

 *  Interface Documentation 
 

 

 *  Provide technical documentation for EBS/NSAP mapping interfaces. 
 

 

 

 
Non-Functional Requirements: 

 *  Maintain data integrity across systems. 
 *  Ensure compatibility with manual approval steps until automation is feasible. 
 *  Support future automation of notifications and queue management. 
 

 
Dependencies: 
 

 *  Technical spike for Ship-To handling (Siva / Carol). 
 *  Legacy data retention review (Siddharth). 
 *  Mapping documentation (Megan). 
 *  QA/Staging validation (Team). 
 

 
Why Dual Maintenance Is Critical: 
1. Customers, Ship-To, and Bill-To Exist in Both Systems  

 *  Ensures CRM can access and validate customer data regardless of which system it's stored in.  
 *  Prevents order failures due to missing or mismatched customer records. 
 

2. EBS Is the System of Record; NSAP Continues for Fulfillment  

 *  EBS holds authoritative data, but NSAP still executes deliveries.  
 *  Dual maintenance allows both systems to function in parallel until NSAP is fully phased out. 
 

3. Mapping Between Ship-To in EBS and Intercompany Ship-To in NSAP  

 *  Critical for accurate fulfillment and warehouse assignment.  
 *  Avoids delivery errors and ensures compliance with logistics protocols. 
 

4. Synchronization Across CRM, EBS, and NSAP  

 *  Keeps tank and customer data aligned across platforms.  
 *  Supports seamless order processing, approval routing, and fulfillment. 
 

5. Support for Dual Account Numbers (EBS + NSAP)  

 *  Enables CRM users to reference either system depending on business context.  
 *  Facilitates legacy data access and historical tracking. 
 

6. Updates to Existing CRM Logic (e.g., Legacy Account Number)  

 *  Necessary to handle dual mappings and prevent logic failures.  
 *  Ensures CRM workflows remain functional and accurate during the transition.

column8: Update the Filter Logic for Products on the Tank Order Detail Page
column11:
As a system, I need to update the filter logic for products on the Tank Order Detail page for Base Tank requests raised for EBS Accounts so that the Sales Rep can select the right value and proceed to submit the Base Tank Request 

 
Existing Logic for NSAP: 
 
When the Order Type is Base and the Request Type is New,  
the system shows only the products that belong to the selected Sales Org. 
 If the Order Type is Base and the Request Type is Product Change, the products are filtered based on the selected tank capacity and the transfer service value, and only matching product numbers (.31, .33, .36, .38, .91) from the same Sales Org are shown.  
For Base + Label Only, only products with product type 1 linked to that Sales Org are displayed.  
When the Order Type is Bulk and the Request Type is New or Label Only, the lookup shows all products of type 1 or 2 for the selected Sales Org. For Bulk + Product Change, the system filters products according to the chosen bulk tank capacity and transfer service, and then shows only those valid for the selected Sales Org.

column8: Update the Filter Logic for Base Tank Size on the Tank Order Detail Page
column11:
As a system, I need to update the filter logic for Base Tank Size on the Tank Order Detail page for Base Tank requests raised for EBS Accounts so that the Sales Rep can select the right value and proceed to submit the Base Tank Request 

 
Existing Logic for NSAP: 
FilterTankSizeAsperProductSelected checks the Order Type (must be Base = 806460000) and the Product number.
It sets flags (N31, N33, N36, N38, N91) and applies a Tank Size lookup filter based on the product: 
 .31, .33, .91 ? 200 or 400 
 .36 ? 75, 105, 200, 400 
 .38 ? 30, 55, 65, 75, 105, 200, 400 
 If no matching product, a dummy filter is applied (0 capacity), so no records are shown.

column8: Technical Spike: Technical Spike: Evaluate Integration Approach to Synchronize Unloading Point Updates from ERP to CRM (Tank Orders & Tanks)
column11:
As a technical architect,
I need to analyze the feasibility, data sources, models, and integration options for synchronizing unloading point updates from ERP (EBS/NSAP) into CRM,
 
so that future changes to unloading points in ERP are automatically reflected on Tank Order and Tank records in CRM, reducing manual updates and improving data accuracy.
 

 
Context and Background: 

 *  When a new tank order is created in CRM, the unloading point is captured on the Tank Order Detail and carried over into the Tank record created afterward. 
 *  After the tank record is created, no integration exists today to sync future unloading point updates that occur in ERP. 
 *  Business has confirmed that this gap introduces: 

 *  inconsistent unloading point information 
 *  unnecessary manual maintenance 
 *  risk of incorrect logistics and delivery instructions 
 

 *  This spike determines how the integration can be built and what is required to support it.
column19: Moved out of state Sprint Ready
column22:
*  Source Identification (ERP ? Snowflake) 

 *  Identify where unloading point is stored in EBS/NSAP: 

 *  Table name 
 *  Field name 
 *  Associated metadata (ship-to, site, product, or tank linkages) 
 

 *  Determine whether unloading point updates are: 

 *  stored at the ship-to level 
 *  stored at the tank/equipment level 
 *  or stored at the order level 
 

 *  Document how unloading point deltas are captured in ERP. 
 

 *  Snowflake Modeling 

 *  Identify which Snowflake view(s) today contain unloading point data. 
 *  Investigate whether existing E-Commerce unloading point integration already sources this data. 
 *  Document: 

 *  View name 
 *  Columns 
 *  Join keys (serial number, equipment number, ship-to number, etc.) 
 

 *  Assess whether the same Snowflake view can be reused for CRM: 

 *  If yes ? document required transformations 
 *  If no ? document required new Snowflake view(s) 
 

 

 *  CRM Data Impact 

 *  Identify the correct target fields in CRM: 
 *  On the Tank record (final source of truth) 
 *  On the Tank Order Detail (legacy reference—should NOT be updated after tank creation) 
 *  Confirm update key: 

 *  Primary key should be Serial Number + Equipment Number for matching tanks 
 *  Validate fallback keys (Tank ID, external key, or GUID mapping) 
 

 

 *  Integration Pattern Options 

 *  ADF Pipeline  

 *  Scheduled incremental pulls 
 *  Compare Snowflake ? CRM tank table 
 *  Upsert unloading point into CRM Tank record 
 

 

 *  Technical Outputs Required 

 *  Spike output must clearly document: 

 *  ERP table and field source 
 *  Snowflake view and field mapping 
 *  Proposed CRM field updates 
 *  Recommended integration pattern 
 *  Effort estimate (S/M/L)
