column6: CRM: EQR (Engineering Quote Request) Process - Regression Testing Only
column11:
•Purposeand Context of EQR(Engineering Quote Request) 
•AllowsSales Reps to request a quote for projects of type Innovation or Non-Standard.These require engineer team to formulate the quote. 
•KathleenGuekensfrom Belgium is the primary point of contact for EQR’s 
•Budgetaccounts for >50% of all EQR’s 
•Relatedto Account, Opportunity 
•Persona’s 
•UserGroups: Nalco Water + F&B  
•SalesReps – Create the EQR 
•EQEngineers  - Are assigned to the EQR.Then, generate the quote. The engineers from FB use different quote system thanthe Water quote system. 
•OpenProject for EQR  - Expected to Go-LiveOct 2025 
•Thereis an open project updating the process for EQR’s. 
•TheEQR process is being harmonized to reduce division-specific differences andstreamline workflows 
•Ecolabproject to update EQR process will be live in production in October 2025.  Non-prod availability will be sooner,September 2025. 
•Harmonizedprocess will align both divisions to start EQR from an opportunity, withexceptions for budget quotes.  
•Datamigration for EQRs will be addressed as part of harmonization stories 
•Accountfield “Sales Skill” will inform EQR record assignment.  
•BusinessProcess Flow 
•Waterdivision starts EQR from an opportunity; Hygiene starts from an account.  
•EQRsare currently linked to accounts (Hygiene) or opportunities (Water). 
•Futurestate: Both divisions will use opportunities for EQRs, except for equipmentfund/budget quotes, which remain at the account level. 
•Salesskill field will distinguish between Water and Hygiene accounts in CRM, evenafter one customer account migration.  
•EQRs are assigned to engineering teamsbased on sales org and account type. 
•Engineering managers review and assignEQRs based on skill and capacity. 
•Teams are set up per division but maymerge as harmonization progresses.  
•Document management remains adivision-specific process. 
•OneCustomerImpact Considerations 
•Noforeseen impacts to EQR from Release 2. Only regression testing needed forRelease 2. 
•EQRprocess does not use the Ship-To Address. Rather, it relies on the Account (Sold To Address).  
•Theship-to address is not used in the EQR process, so its remediation is notneeded for EQR process in the 1C structure. 
•Pendingchanges to EQR are not expected to have an impact on OneCustomer. 
•Documentmanagement systems (SharePoint vs. attachments) are currently separate; This isnot expected to change thus no Release 2 changes required.  
•Datamigration impact when multiple versions of water accounts merge into 1 accountin CRM using the native CRM merge capabilities. The SharePoint documents needto be moved from the Inactive account to the surving water account post CRM merge 
•Salesskill will be the key differentiator for Water vs. Hygiene in the future CRMstructure.

column7: Regression testing of as-is EQR (Engineering Quote Request) Business Process
column11:
Regression testing of as-is EQR(Engineering Quote Request) Business Process
 
 
 
AcAction Items: 
Share sample records for regression testing – Kathleen – Due 8/27/2025.
 

 
•BusinessProcess Flow 
•Waterdivision starts EQR from an opportunity; Hygiene starts from an account.  
•EQRsare currently linked to accounts (Hygiene) or opportunities (Water). 
•Futurestate: Both divisions will use opportunities for EQRs, except for equipmentfund/budget quotes, which remain at the account level. 
•Salesskill field will distinguish between Water and Hygiene accounts in CRM, evenafter one customer account migration.  
•EQRs are assigned to engineering teamsbased on sales org and account type. 
•Engineering managers review and assignEQRs based on skill and capacity. 
•Teams are set up per division but maymerge as harmonization progresses. 
•Documentmanagement remains a division-specific process 

 

 
 

 

  

  
User Story 
  

 

 

  

  
As a sales rep, when I initiate an EQR for a  new project, then I start from an opportunity so that I follow a unified  process across divisions. 
  

 

 

  

  
As a sales rep, when I need a budget/equipment  fund quote, then I can create an EQR directly from the account so that I  avoid unnecessary pipeline visibility. 
  

 

 

  

  
As an engineering manager, when an EQR is  submitted, then I see all relevant documents and project details so that I  can assign the right engineer efficiently. 
  

 

 

  

  
As a system admin, when accounts are migrated  to one customer, then I see sales skill on each account so that I can  distinguish Water and Hygiene for routing. 
  

 

 

  

  
As a user, when I upload documents for an EQR,  then I use the designated document section so that engineering has all  required information in one place. 
  

 


 

 
Training Guide: https://ecolab-my.sharepoint.com/:p:/p/kgeukens/EXYfLciY_uBDlBkP6TrgzQQBCNwCusXncT0jYOKf6Is-OA?%3d%3d&sdata=dmh4YXhkdlJDZjJldUFFQWIrTjVtTTJTaCtTek1yemExdFFKY29BUWNZTT0%3d

column6: CRM: Analytical Sampling App (ASA) –  Regression Testing Only
column11:
This feature ensures that the Analytical Sampling App (ASA) continues to function seamlessly under the new One Customer data model, where Ship-To records are retained for both NSAP and EBS accounts. The previous plan to remove Ship-To references and refactor the app for Sold-To-based logic is no longer applicable.

 
The feature now focuses on confirming end-to-end stability of ASA with the current CRM–EBS data structure and implementing integration updates for EBS billing arrangements.
 

 
Scope and Objectives 

 *  Regression Validation: 

 *  Confirm that ASA continues to operate without functional or data integrity issues when Ship-To records are fully loaded from both EBS and NSAP sources. 
 *  Validate that all existing workflows—sample creation, billing selection, and LIMS integrations—function as designed with no behavioral deviations. 
 

 *  Billing Arrangements Integration: 

 *  Deactivate all legacy NSAP billing arrangements in CRM so they are no longer selectable in ASA. 
 *  Introduce new integration pulling billing arrangements from EBS via Snowflake, mapping them correctly to Ship-To and Sold-To accounts. 
 *  Ensure no artificial modification of NSAP arrangement end dates; retain their historical values. 
 *  Handle interim billing via district or PO billing if EBS billing arrangements are not yet available at runtime. 
 

 *  LIMS Integration: 

 *  Maintain existing LIMS linkage through Ship-To-based CDM keys. No refactor is needed since Ship-To data remains present. 
 *  UI and Functionality: 
 *  No UI redesign required for ASA. 
 *  Maintain the same experience and logic for all ASA users across business lines. 
 

 

 
Technical Deliverables 

 *  Snowflake Technical Spike: 

 *  Review Snowflake views to confirm data structures for EBS billing arrangements. 
 *  Validate mapping logic from Snowflake to CRM billing arrangement tables. 
 *  Propose view enhancements if additional attributes (e.g., effective dates, account keys) are required. 
 

 *  Integration Development: 

 *  Build or update integration pipelines for EBS billing arrangements and allocations. 
 *  Validate synchronization between CRM, Snowflake, and ASA modules. 
 

 *  Data Conversion Task: 

 *  Deactivate NSAP billing arrangements tied to impacted accounts for R1 and R2 accounts. 
 *  Ensure historical data remains accessible in read-only mode for audit. 
 

 *  Regression Testing: 

 *  Test ASA across Water and F&B divisions to verify continued compatibility with Ship-To and Sold-To associations. 
 *  Include LIMS sync, sample creation, and billing workflow validation in test scope. 
 

 

 
Out of Scope 

 *  No ASA UI refactoring. 
 *  No rework of LIMS integration or CDM key logic. 
 *  No functional change to sampling workflows or calculation logic. 
 

 
Dependencies 

 *  Snowflake view readiness for EBS billing data. 
 *  EBS-to-CRM data flow activation. 
 *  Data conversion completion for NSAP billing arrangement deactivation. 
 

 

 

 

 

 

 
Expected Outcome
 

 

 
ASA remains functionally stable and aligned with the unified One Customer data model. EBS billing arrangements are integrated seamlessly, ensuring accurate billing linkage while legacy NSAP arrangements are cleanly deactivated without impacting user experience.

The 1C FBU Canada Release EPIC encompasses all foundational capabilities required to support the launch of the One Customer model for Food & Beverage (F&B) United Canada accounts, as part of the global customer unification program. This release focuses on enabling a centralized Base Customer Account (BCA) structure with aligned sales skill records (e.g., Water and Hygiene), standardizing CRM processes, and ensuring system readiness across CRM, CDM, EBS, PowerApps, and reporting platforms.

 
Key objectives include: 

 *  Establishing a dedicated Base Customer Account entity in CRM (Option 1 model) 
 *  Aligning Water and Hygiene sales skill records under BCA with proper security, filtering, and metadata visibility 
 *  Updating integrations between CRM, CDM, and Ecolab 3D to support new customer hierarchy and merged site logic 
 *  Enabling clean site/asset lineage and downstream compatibility with PowerApps and Power BI 
 *  Harmonizing business processes such as opportunity management, RTW, GTW, and contact handling across sales skills 
 *  Supporting critical regression testing for existing functionality affected by the structural changes 
 

 
This EPIC represents all business and technical requirements identified during the 10-day discovery workshops and stakeholder alignment sessions held in July 2025.

column6: Integration: Update CRM-CDM User Enablement Logic for One Customer Account Model
column11:
This feature addresses necessary updates to the user enablement integration between CRM and CDM as Ecolab transitions to the One Customer model, where both Nalco Water and Hygiene business units will share Base Customer Accounts (BCAs).

 
Key Business Context: 

 *  Today, when a CRM user clicks “Enable for Digital Tools”, the system checks if the account’s email domain is approved and if the site is eligible for E3D. 
 *  If criteria are met, CRM triggers a webhook to CDM to create a user and assign roles aligned to a Sold-To account. 
 *  This process currently works for Nalco Water accounts only and assumes that each account number is unique. 
 

 
What is Changing: 

 *  After One Customer go-live, Water and Hygiene accounts may share the same account number, causing the current logic (which assumes account number uniqueness) to break or create duplicate records. 
 *  The integration must be updated to loop through and process multiple CRM accounts that share the same number, ensuring correct user role and site alignment in CDM. 
 *  The same enablement flow will be extended to Hygiene, requiring support for new division-based filters during alignment creation. 
 

 
Expected Enhancements: 

 *  Fix the contact/user alignment logic in CRM to properly handle multiple matching accounts after account merge. 
 *  Ensure alignment and role creation continues to work correctly even when duplicate account numbers exist (e.g., one for Water and one for Hygiene). 
 *  Begin supporting Hygiene accounts in the user enablement flow using the same webhook-triggered logic used today for Nalco Water. 
 

 
This feature ensures that the user setup and digital tool enablement process continues to work correctly after the account merge and prepares the system for enabling Hygiene users in CDM.

column6: Integration: MAP 2.0 to CRM Alignment Sync
column11:
Implement integration to consume alignment and account ownership data from MAP 2.0 into CRM using Azure Data Factory (ADF) pipelines. MAP 2.0 reads harmonized customer and user-role alignment data from Snowflake views (which are populated via ERP sources like EBS/NSAP) and publishes that data into CRM. This includes:
 

 *  Account-to-user alignment (e.g., SAM assignments, BDM/DM role alignments) 
 *  District Alignments 
 *  Sales Skill ownership by base customer and sold-to 
 *  Territory and hierarchy mapping logic for F&B and Nalco Water 
 *  Support for future extensions to include CAM/AVP roles if needed 
 

 
This integration enables CRM to serve as the downstream system for alignment logic already validated and published by MAP, reducing duplication and manual maintenance. The integration must be built to handle: 

 *  Scheduled ADF jobs pulling alignment data from MAP 2.0 Snowflake views 
 *  Field mapping and validation to ensure CRM record updates reflect MAP hierarchy 
 *  Merging logic for sold-to and base customer records 
 *  Role-based assignment via CRM access teams or other role modeling 
 

 
Regression testing is required to validate: 

 *  Alignments remain stable through BCA migration and CDM site merge scenarios 
 *  No duplicate alignments or conflicting ownerships occur 
 *  Existing manual assignments are not overwritten unintentionally

column7: 46. CDM and MAP Sync Validation for Sales Skill and SAM
45. CRM Field Mapping Validation Against MAP Views
column11:
Business Capability overview:  
The integration between MAP 2.0 and Microsoft Dynamics 365 Customer Relationship Management (CRM) requires robust validation of field mappings to ensure CRM record updates accurately reflect the MAP hierarchy under the One Customer model for Food and Beverage United (FBU) in Canada.  
MAP 2.0 aggregates harmonized alignment data from Snowflake views (sourced from ERP like EBS/NSAP), and this validation prevents data discrepancies during sync, supporting accurate account-to-user alignments, sales skill ownership, and territory mappings. The rationale is to maintain data integrity post-sync, reducing errors in role assignments and enabling reliable downstream processes like reporting in Power Business Intelligence, while aligning with the Base Customer Account (BCA) structure and Sales Skill designations (initially Hygiene and Water, subject to change). 
Business Requirements: 

 *  Validate field mappings between MAP 2.0 Snowflake views and CRM entities to ensure accurate data reflection. 
 *  Ensure mappings for account-to-user alignments (e.g., SAM, BDM/DM) are consistent and error-free. 
 *  Confirm mappings for sales skill ownership by Base Customer Account (BCA) and sold-to records align with MAP 2.0 data. 
 *  Validate territory and hierarchy mappings for Food and Beverage and Nalco Water divisions post-sync. 
 *  Provide capability to detect and flag mapping conflicts or mismatches during validation. 
 *  Support validation of future extensions (e.g., CAM/AVP roles) without requiring major redesign. 
 

Technical Considerations: 

 *  Validation must integrate with Azure Data Factory (ADF) pipelines pulling from MAP 2.0 Snowflake views. 
 *  A technical spike is required to assess mapping validation tools and logic for hierarchy consistency. 
 *  Spike output should include a validation framework and benchmarks for real-time vs. batch processing. 
 *  Coordination with MAP 2.0 team to define field schemas and validation thresholds is essential. 
 *  Consider impacts on CRM performance due to validation during large-scale data updates. 
 

Expected Deliverables: 

 *  Validated field mapping configurations between MAP 2.0 and CRM. 
 *  Documentation of mapping validation processes and rules. 
 

Acceptance Criteria 

 *  Develop (or update) field mapping document to align to recent metadata updates. 
 *  Given MAP 2.0 data with account-to-user alignments, when validated against CRM mappings, then all fields match without discrepancies. 
 *  Given sales skill ownership data from MAP 2.0, when mapped to BCA/sold-to, then validation confirms accuracy post-sync. 
 *  Given a territory hierarchy change in MAP 2.0, when validated, then CRM reflects the update correctly for F&B/Nalco Water. 
 *  Given conflicting MAP 2.0 data, when processed, then validation flags the issue and prevents invalid updates. 
 *  Given future role data (e.g., CAM), when added to mappings, then validation supports extension without errors. 
 

References 

 *  Recap: CRM Dynamics - Discovery Sessions Thursday, July 24 | Meeting | Microsoft Teams, Discovery Sessions 
 *  Recap: CRM Dynamics - Discovery Sessions Wednesday, July 23 | Meeting | Microsoft Teams, Discovery Sessions 
 *  "F&B United CRM.pdf" notebook, Discovery Sessions (MAP Views). 
 

This requirement ensures accurate field mapping validation for the MAP 2.0 sync, aligning with the feature's goal of reliable CRM updates. 
Questions for Clarification 

 *  Should Acceptance Criteria for this REQUIREMENT include data volume tests (e.g., high-volume mapping validation)? 
 *  Are there specific tools for mapping validation (e.g., ADF data flows) to note in Technical Considerations? 
 *  For #46, should we include CDM-specific sync aspects (e.g., site alignments)? 
 *  Any preferred naming for Acceptance Criteria (e.g., "AC1, AC2") or just bullets? 
 *  Should we generate all remaining Requirements in one message, or continue one at a time?

column8: TECHNICAL SPIKE: NSAP to EBS Ship-To to Sold-To Conversion Requirements
column11: ## Problem StatementPlaceholder for solutioning new approach...The Ecolab PZ Migration project requires converting eligible NSAP-based Ship-To accounts to EBS-based Sold-To accounts to enable seamless business operations in the One Customer solution, while ensuring data integrity, maintaining historical references, and supporting future alignment integrations through MAP 2.0.## Detailed Problem Explanation  The core challenge lies in migrating customer account structures from existing NSAP Ship-To configurations to modern EBS Sold-To configurations within Dynamics 365 CRM. This conversion is critical for Ecolab's Food & Beverage division to achieve a unified customer view, but it introduces complexities around data transformation, relationship preservation, and system integration.Key considerations include the need to establish proper linkages to Base Customer Accounts during migration. When converting a Ship-To account, the system must either connect it to an existing Base Customer Account or create a new one if none exists. This ensures hierarchical relationships are maintained and prevents orphaned account data that could disrupt business processes.Account deactivation represents another significant consideration. After successfully promoting a Ship-To to a Sold-To account, the old Ship-To account cannot simply be deleted—it must be properly deactivated. This deactivation process requires careful sequencing to avoid breaking existing business workflows and reporting dependencies.  Service History management emerges as a critical data integrity concern. Before deactivating any Ship-To account, all related Service History references must be cleaned up and restructured. Historical Service History entries should preserve their original linkages to the Ship-To account for audit and compliance purposes, while all future Service History entries must be directed to the new Sold-To account to maintain accurate operational records. The integration with MAP 2.0 adds another layer of complexity. MAP 2.0 serves as the authoritative source for customer alignment and ownership data, pulling from Snowflake views populated by ERP sources like EBS and NSAP. The CRM system must consume this alignment data through scheduled ADF pipelines, ensuring that account hierarchies, user assignments, and territory mappings remain synchronized without manual intervention.  Data transformation requirements demand careful attention to field mappings between NSAP and EBS schemas. Address structures, custom fields, and relationship data must be accurately converted while handling data type differences and validation rules. The transformation logic must account for both full migrations and incremental updates to support ongoing business operations. Performance and scalability considerations are paramount given the enterprise scale of Ecolab's operations. The conversion process must handle varying data volumes without impacting existing pipeline performance, while maintaining security standards and providing robust error handling and rollback capabilities for any conversion failures. Regression testing becomes essential to validate system stability through various migration scenarios. The solution must ensure that alignments remain stable during BCA migrations and CDM site merges, preventing duplicate alignments or conflicting ownerships that could disrupt sales and service operations.  Finally, the integration must support future extensibility. The system should be designed to accommodate additional roles like CAM and AVP as business needs evolve, while maintaining backward compatibility with existing manual assignments that should not be overwritten unintentionally.  ## User Stories  ### User Story 1: Data Extraction and Filtering**As a data analyst, I want to extract and filter the MAP 2.0 subset of ready NSAP Ship-To accounts so that only eligible accounts are processed.**  #### Tasks- Create a new data flow or modify existing ones to query MAP 2.0 data.- Implement filtering logic based on readiness criteria.- Add data validation steps to ensure data quality.  ### User Story 2: Data Transformation Mapping**As a data engineer, I want to map NSAP Ship-To fields to EBS Sold-To fields so that data is correctly transformed during conversion.**  #### Tasks- Develop field mapping specifications.- Implement transformation logic in ADF data flows (joins, derives, lookups).- Handle data type conversions and format changes.  ### User Story 3: Pipeline Integration**As a DevOps engineer, I want to integrate the conversion logic into the existing ADF pipeline so that it runs as part of the regular migration process.**  #### Tasks- Modify pipeline activities to include the new conversion steps.- Add conditional logic for processing only the eligible subset.- Implement error handling and logging for conversion failures.  ### User Story 4: Validation and Testing**As a QA engineer, I want to validate the converted data so that accuracy and completeness are ensured before loading to CRM.**  #### Tasks- Create validation rules and checks.- Develop test cases for various scenarios (e.g., partial data, edge cases).- Implement data comparison tools to verify transformations.  ### User Story 5: Deployment and Monitoring**As a system administrator, I want to deploy the changes and monitor the conversion process so that issues are identified and resolved promptly.**  #### Tasks- Set up monitoring dashboards for conversion metrics.- Implement alerting for failures or data quality issues.- Create rollback procedures for failed conversions.  ### User Story 6: Account Migration and Deactivation**As a data migration engineer, I want to handle the migration of Ship-To accounts to Sold-To accounts with proper Base Customer Account linkage and deactivation so that data integrity is maintained throughout the process.**  #### Tasks- Implement logic to link migrated Sold-To accounts to existing Base Customer Accounts or create new ones as needed.- Develop data cleanup procedures for Service History references before Ship-To account deactivation.- Ensure Service History preserves linkages to old Ship-To accounts for historical records.- Configure future Service History entries to reference the new Sold-To accounts.- Implement account deactivation logic for old Ship-To accounts after data cleanup is complete.  ### User Story 7: TECHNICAL SPIKE - Handle creation of Dynamics CRM accounts from Merging of EBS and NSAP data**As a data engineer, I want to investigate the technical feasibility and implementation approach for creating Dynamics CRM accounts from the merging of EBS and NSAP data so that we can design a robust solution for the Ship-To to Sold-To conversion process.**  #### Tasks- Analyze the data structures and schemas of EBS and NSAP systems to understand merging requirements.- Investigate CRM account creation APIs and upsert capabilities for handling merged data.- Evaluate data quality and deduplication strategies for merged EBS/NSAP records.- Assess the impact on existing CRM workflows and data relationships.- Prototype data flow logic for merging EBS and NSAP data into CRM account structures.- Document findings, recommendations, and potential challenges for the implementation team.  ## Closing StatementThis comprehensive approach to the NSAP to EBS Ship-To to Sold-To conversion addresses the critical business need for unified customer data while maintaining operational continuity and data integrity. By systematically breaking down the problem into manageable user stories and considering all technical and business implications, we can deliver a robust solution that supports Ecolab's transition to the One Customer model and enables future scalability through MAP 2.0 integrations.

column8: TECHNICAL SPIKE: Document field mappings between MAP 2.0 Snowflake views and CRM for EBS SoldTo and ShipTo

column7: 44. ADF Pipeline Definition for MAP-to-CRM Alignment Data
column11:
Business Capability overview:  
The integration requires defined Azure Data Factory (ADF) pipelines to consume and sync alignment and account ownership data from MAP 2.0 into Microsoft Dynamics 365 Customer Relationship Management (CRM), supporting the One Customer model for Food and Beverage United (FBU) in Canada. MAP 2.0 aggregates harmonized data from Snowflake views (sourced from ERP like EBS/NSAP) and publishes it to CRM, covering account-to-user alignments (e.g., SAM, BDM/DM), sales skill ownership by Base Customer Account (BCA) and sold-to, territory hierarchies for F&B and Nalco Water, and future extensions (e.g., CAM/AVP). The rationale is to make CRM a reliable downstream consumer of validated alignments, reducing manual maintenance, ensuring data consistency, and enabling stable territory management post-BCA migration and CDM site changes. 
Business Requirements: 

 *  Define new additions to existing ADF pipelines to pull alignment data from MAP 2.0 Snowflake views on a scheduled basis. 
 *  Ensure pipelines support ingestion of account-to-user alignments, sales skill ownership, and territory/hierarchy mappings. 
 *  Provide capability to handle merging logic for sold-to and BCA records during data sync. 
 *  Enable role-based assignment updates in CRM based on MAP 2.0 data, using access teams or role modeling. 
 *  Validate that pipelines do not overwrite existing manual alignments unintentionally. 
 *  Support future role extensions (e.g., CAM/AVP) without major pipeline redesign. 
 

Technical Considerations: 

 *  Pipelines must integrate with Snowflake views populated by ERP sources (EBS/NSAP), using ADF for ETL processes. 
 *  A technical spike is required to assess ADF job scheduling, data volume handling, and validation logic for hierarchy mappings. 
 *  Spike output should include a recommended pipeline architecture and performance benchmarks for real-time vs. batch syncs. 
 *  Coordination with MAP 2.0 and CRM teams is essential to define data schemas and update frequencies. 
 *  Consider potential impacts on CRM performance due to large-scale alignment updates. 
 

Expected Deliverables: 

 *  Defined ADF pipelines for MAP 2.0 to CRM data sync, with scheduled jobs and mapping configurations. 
 *  Documented merging and role assignment logic for sold-to/BCA records. 
 *  Validation framework to prevent duplicate or conflicting alignments. 
 *  Technical spike report with pipeline prototypes and recommendations. 
 

Acceptance Criteria 

 *  Given a scheduled ADF job, when triggered, then alignment data from MAP 2.0 Snowflake views is pulled and synced to CRM without errors. 
 *  Given MAP 2.0 data with sales skill ownership, when processed, then BCA and sold-to records in CRM reflect the mappings accurately. 
 *  Given a merge scenario for sold-to records, when syncing, then CRM updates without data loss or duplication. 
 *  Given existing manual alignments in CRM, when MAP 2.0 sync runs, then manuals are preserved and not overwritten. 
 *  Given future role data (e.g., CAM), when added to MAP 2.0, then pipeline supports extension without reconfiguration. 
 

References 

 *  Recap: CRM Dynamics - Discovery Sessions Thursday, July 24 | Meeting | Microsoft Teams, Discovery Sessions 
 *  Recap: CRM Dynamics - Discovery Sessions Wednesday, July 23 | Meeting | Microsoft Teams, Discovery Sessions 
 *  "F&B United CRM.pdf" notebook, Discovery Sessions. 
 

This requirement ensures the ADF pipeline is defined to support the integration's core data flow, aligning with the feature's goal of making CRM a reliable consumer of MAP 2.0 alignments.  
Outstanding Questions 

 *  Should Acceptance Criteria include performance metrics (e.g., sync time for high-volume data)? 
 *  Are there specific ADF pipeline constraints (e.g., batch size, error thresholds) to include in Technical Considerations?

column8: TECHNICAL SPIKE: Special case data handling
column11: As an ADF Pipeline Engineer, I require a technical spike to assess the feasibility and necessity of handling special cases in ADF pipelines, including merging logic for the BCA structure, validating no overwrite of existing manual BCA and Division data, and supporting future Division and Sales Skill extensions from MAP 2.0 Snowflake views, so that we can determine if these activities are required to ensure CRM accurately reflects the One Customer model, prevent data loss, and maintain flexibility without major redesign.
column22: ### Locate and Document Current State of Special Case Handling*   Given the existing ADF pipelines, when analyzed with MAP 2.0 Snowflake views, then the current approach to merging BCA data, BCA/Division data, and supporting Division/Sales Skill extensions are detailed, including any existing validation or error handling.*   When assessed, then the impact of null or missing fields from MAP 2.0 on manual data and the feasibility of dynamic extension support are evaluated.*   During discovery, when captured, then findings on current performance (e.g., merge times, overwrite incidents) and potential bottlenecks are noted for a shared repository.### Pipeline Configuration*   Given the development environment, when configured, then a prototype ADF pipeline is set up to test merging BCA data, validate no overwrite of manual data, and explore extension parameters for Division/Sales Skill.*   When tested, then at least two related activities are prototyped: one for merging BCA logic and one for overwrite validation, with configurations for extension support.*   When applied, then environment variables for authentication (e.g., Snowflake credentials) and dynamic data (e.g., then areas impacted (e.g., data flows for BCA merges, validation logic for manuals, extension parameters) are listed.*   When documented, then potential changes to pipeline architecture for special support requirements, with pseudocode and risks.*   Given the prototype, when tested, then a working ADF pipeline section for BCA merging, manual data validation, and extension support is provided in development.*   Given the assessment, when finalized, then an effort estimate and coordination prerequisites with MAP 2.0/CRM teams are documented.

column22:
Locate and Document Current State of ADF Pipeline 

 *  Using attached system architecture diagrams for L2: Map 2.0 (Analytics) and the L3: D365-Snowflake-D as a starting point, develop understanding of how the D365-SNOWFLAKE-D pipeline supports the existing MAP-to-CRM alignment data flow from Snowflake views (sourced from ERP like EBS/NSAP) to Dynamics 365 CRM. 
 *  During exploration, start to develop a future state approach for the pipeline that incorporates merging logic for sold-to and BCA records, Sales Skill ownership mappings (e.g., Hygiene, Water), District handling, market and SINC attributes, and role-based assignments using access teams or role modeling in CRM. (future task)  
 *  Document where the pipeline is located in Azure (e.g., resource group, factory name) and which environments are supported (Development, Quality Assurance, Production). 
 

Analyze Current Logic 

 *  Document how the D365-SNOWFLAKE-D pipeline works today, including required and optional activities (e.g., copy, data flow, lookup), data sources (Snowflake views), linked services (Snowflake, Dataverse/CRM connectors), and staging areas in Azure Data Lake. 
 *  Understand the required schemas, mappings, and transformations for alignment data (e.g., account-to-user alignments like SAM/BDM/DM, territory hierarchies), including any current handling of sales skill or similar fields. 
 *  During discovery and research, capture each activity, dataset, and trigger in the pipeline for a shared documentation repository (e.g., wiki or Confluence page).  
 *  Identify and document Subject Matter Experts (SMEs), including Technical Lead, ADF developer, MAP 2.0 team, and CRM integration specialists. 
 *  Assess current performance impacts on CRM due to large-scale updates, including batch sizes, error thresholds, and data volume handling. 
 

Pipeline Configuration 

 *  Define and locate the existing ADF pipeline D365-SNOWFLAKE-D in Azure portals for Development, Quality Assurance, and Production environments. 
 *  Replicate the pipeline in a development ADF instance, configuring linked services for Snowflake and CRM/Dataverse connectors with sample credentials. 
 *  Add test runs for key activities (e.g., data pull from Snowflake views, transformation for alignments, sync to CRM), with working configurations for each. 
 *  Create a prototype pipeline flow with at least two chained activities: one for data ingestion and validation (e.g., check duplicates or conflicts), and one for submission/sync to CRM. 
 *  Configurations use parameters or variables for pipeline base settings, authentication (e.g., service principals or managed identities), and dynamic data passing (e.g., spike output for performance metrics). 
 

Data Flow Structure  

 *  The ingestion activity uses copy or data flow with schemas matching current MAP 2.0 formats, including required fields: account number, user alignments (SAM, BDM/DM), territory hierarchies.  
 *  Optional fields are supported: sales skill ownership (if present), future extensions like CAM/AVP.  
 *  All mappings align with no-overwrite rules for manual alignments in CRM, as per existing integration constraints. 
 

Successful Execution 

 *  On valid data, the ingestion activity completes with success status, pulling alignment data from MAP 2.0 Snowflake views. 
 *  The sync activity completes, updating CRM with mappings, including confirmation of population in Dataverse (e.g., BCA and sold-to records reflect accurately). 
 

Response Verification 

 *  ADF monitors and tests assert activity success codes, schema validation against expected formats, and ensure no unintended overwrites of manual alignments in CRM. 
 

Authentication Handling 

 *  Document pipeline linked services to include authentication methods (e.g., OAuth for CRM, Snowflake account keys), succeeding with valid credentials. 
 *  Unauthorized or failed connections (e.g., invalid token) trigger ADF error handling, with logging in Azure Monitor. 
 

Data Validation Errors 

 *  Invalid data (e.g., missing required alignment fields) triggers ADF validation activities, rejecting the batch with error codes.  
 *  Merge failures (e.g., conflicting sold-to records) halt the pipeline and log error messages from activities. 
 

Impact Assessment 

 *  ?List areas that may be impacted (e.g., activities, datasets, linked services, transformations, parameters for BCA/Sales Skill/District/market/SINC).   
 *  Document changes required, including additions to system architecture diagrams for integrations. 
 

Duplicate Detection (optional - not sure this is required) 

 *  If duplicates are found (e.g., existing alignments in CRM), validation activity handles merging, preventing overwrites and prompting review if needed.  
 *  Assess how duplicates are handled today; if moving detection upstream, determine if new activities or Snowflake queries are required. 
 

Testing Approach 

 *  Define scenarios to confirm current behavior (e.g., full sync, partial updates) and future behavior (e.g., with Sales Skill extensions).   
 *  Develop a test suite within ADF (e.g., debug runs, sample datasets) for rigorous testing against Development instance. 
 

Integration Runtime Configuration 

 *  Document the type of Integration Runtime (IR) used (e.g., Azure IR, Self-hosted IR, Shared IR), including auto-scaling settings, connectivity to data sources (Snowflake, CRM/Dataverse), and any custom configurations for zone redundancy in the Provisioning Zone context.   
 *  Assess for future state: Recommend IR adjustments for handling increased data volumes from BCA aggregations and Sales Skill mappings, ensuring high availability during migrations. 
 

Triggers and Scheduling 

 *  Analyze current pipeline triggers (e.g., schedule-based, event-based, tumbling window), execution frequencies, dependencies on upstream processes (e.g., Snowflake view refreshes from ERP), and any manual overrides.   
 *  Plan for future: Suggest hybrid scheduling (batch for daily alignments, near-real-time for critical changes like territory hierarchies), including performance metrics for sync times in high-volume scenarios. 
 

Monitoring and Alerting 

 *  Review integration with Azure Monitor, key metrics tracked (e.g., pipeline run duration, activity failures, data throughput), custom logs, and alerting setups (e.g., email notifications for errors). 
 *  Recommend enhancements for future: Custom dashboards for monitoring BCA merge successes, alert thresholds for error rates exceeding defined limits (e.g., 5% failure rate), and integration with Azure Sentinel for anomaly detection. 
 

Security and Compliance (optional) 

 *  Document security features, including authentication mechanisms (managed identities, key vaults for secrets), role-based access control (RBAC) for pipeline execution, data encryption in transit/rest, and compliance with standards (e.g., GDPR for customer data). 
 *  For future state: Evaluate impacts of new fields like market/SINC on PII handling, recommend auditing for role assignments, and ensure zone-redundant setups maintain security postures. 
 

Performance and Cost Optimization (optional)  

 *  Capture current performance details, such as Data Integration Units (DIU) usage, degree of parallelism, write batch sizes for D365 datasets, pipeline run costs, and bottlenecks (e.g., transformation latencies).   
 *  Benchmark and suggest optimizations for future: Tuning for Sales Skill mappings (e.g., reduce DIU for low-volume, scale for peaks), cost estimates for extended roles like CAM/AVP, and recommendations for partitioning in Azure Data Lake staging. 
 

Data Lineage and Dependency Analysis 

 *  Map end-to-end data lineage from ERP sources through Snowflake views, ADF transformations, to CRM entities, identifying dependencies on other pipelines or services (e.g., linked to CDM messages).  
 *  Analyze for future: Document how changes for District/market/SINC affect lineage, recommend tools like Azure Purview for automated tracking, and assess cascading impacts on downstream systems (e.g., Ecolab 3D integrations). 
 

Deliverables 

 *  Technical documentation (memo or wiki) including summary of pipeline analysis, current logic summary, proposed future logic, pseudocode for modifications, risks (e.g., performance on high-volume data), and test outline. 
 *  Create (or update) existing Mapping document used for D365-Snowflake-D. 
 *  Updated prototype pipeline in development ADF that exercises required activities and succeeds (e.g., green run status). (optional) 
 *  Updated prototype for optional extensions (e.g., future role data) that succeeds in development. (optional) 
 *  Effort estimate and prerequisites for implementing changes, including coordination with MAP 2.0 and CRM teams. 
 *  Validation report with performance benchmarks (e.g., sync time for high-volume data, batch size recommendations, error thresholds). (optional)

column8: Support Organizational Account (H5 Accounts) in existing EBS Integration (D365-Snowflake-D)
column11: As a data engineer working on the Ecolab Snowflake Integrations project, I want to support Organizational Accounts (also known as H5 accounts) in the ADF pipelines and dataflows, so that these account types are properly handled in the EBS and MAP 2.0 integrations without data loss or misalignment.Organizational Accounts (H5) represent a specific account type in Ecolab's hierarchy, requiring dedicated handling in ADF to ensure they are included in Sold-To alignments and CRM updates. This involves updating sources, joins, and sinks in relevant pipelines/dataflows, with potential new lookups for H5-specific attributes. The Field Mapping sheet should be used for setting EBS Account Number, Market Segment, Market Sub-Segment, and set ERP Status to Active.Coordinate with business stakeholders to define H5 requirements and test with sample data.
column22: 1. Validate that the ADF pipeline is created to read EBS Organization (H5) Accounts from Snowflake2. Validate that ADF pipeline should use the mapping mentioned in the Sheet. [Field Mapping Document](https://ecolab.sharepoint.com/sites/IndustrialSS/Shared%20Documents/General/1%20FBU/Raw%20Notes/ADF_ECOLAB_FIELD_MAPPING/Ecolab-Field-Mapping-FB-OneCustomer-002.xlsm?web=1) 3. Validate that the ADF should be able to create and update the Organization Record in CRM4. Validate that the ADF should also be able to Set the Sales skill for 1C organization Account.5. Validate that the ADF should be able to Set the CAM in case of corporate organization Account (where Primary owner is a CAM)6. Validate that the ADF should not populate the CAM field in case of Primary owner is not a CAM.7. Validate that NO CHANGES to be done for Non-1C Organization Accounts.

Src - Excel target - CRM

2. Validate that the ADF should be able to create and update the Organization Record in CRM
 
3. Validate that the ADF should also be able to Set the Sales skill for 1C organization Account.
 
4. Validate that the ADF should be able to Set the CAM in case of corporate organization Account (where Primary owner is a CAM)

column8: Enhance EBS SOLD TO Integration Pipeline to Map Market, Submarket for 1C customers
column11:
As a consumer of customer master data through the SOLD To pipeline
I want the SOLD To pipeline to populate CRM Market Segment and Subsegment using the correct field set based on whether the customer is 1C or non-1C
 
So that CRM maintains consistent harmonized values during and after 1C adoption, without breaking existing logic for legacy customers.
 

 
Business Context / Rationale

 *  The Sold To pipeline currently pulls legacy fields (Customer Business Unit Description, NAI Description) from MDM for Market Segment and Subsegment. 
 *  Under the 1C program, MDM is introducing harmonized classification fields: Industry ? Market ? Submarket. 
 *  CRM must now support both schemas, because: 
 *  1C customers exclusively use the new harmonized fields. 
 *  Non-1C customers will continue using legacy fields until global harmonization completes. 
 *  The Sold To pipeline must dynamically switch between these sources using the 1C flag provided by MDM. 
 

 
Business Requirements  

 *  The Sold To pipeline must determine the correct source fields using the 1C flag delivered by MDM. 
 *  For 1C = Yes, the Sold To pipeline must populate CRM using: 

 *  Market ? CRM Market Segment 
 *  Submarket ? CRM Subsegment 
 

 *  For 1C = No, the Sold To pipeline must continue using legacy values: 

 *  Customer Business Unit Description ? CRM Market Segment 
 *  NAI Description ? CRM Subsegment
column19: Moved out of state Sprint Ready
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria: 

 *  Sold To pipeline uses harmonized fields for 1C customers 

 *  Given MDM sends customer data with 1CFlag = Yes through the Sold To pipeline 
 *  When CRM receives the transformed payload 
 *  Then CRM must populate Market Segment using the “Market” field 
 *  And Subsegment using “Submarket” 
 

 *  Sold To pipeline uses legacy fields for non-1C customers 

 *  Given MDM sends customer data with 1CFlag = No 
 *  When the Sold to pipeline processes the record 
 *  Then CRM must continue populating Market Segment from “Customer Business Unit Description” 
 *  And Subsegment from “NAIC Description.”

column8: Create/Update OneCustomer ShipTo Accounts from EBS (Through MAP2.0)
column11: As an Azure Data Factory Specialist working on the Ecolab Snowflake Integrations project, I need to enhance the existing Sold-To Integration for Account Creation and Updates to support Ship-To's. AS in the other pipeline we will use the approved MAP 2.0 data views as represented in the Field Mapping Document, so that new or existing Ship-To Accounts field-level data can be appropriately updated in Dynamics CRM.**Note:** All required mappings are defined in the Field Mapping Document. This is a placeholder User Story for future Ship-To integration enhancements.## User Story**As a** Dynamics 365 Functional Consultant and ADF Integration Specialist**I want to** extend the existing D365-Snowflake-D pipeline to support Ship-To account processing alongside Sold-To accounts**So that** Ship-To accounts in Dynamics CRM are created or updated with unified customer IDs, roles, and skills from the MAP 2.0 alignments### Business ContextShip-To accounts represent delivery addresses and billing locations for customers. Unlike Sold-To accounts (organizational accounts with BCA linkage), Ship-To accounts are location-specific and may have different alignments, territories, and sales skills than their parent Sold-To accounts. The integration must handle these differences while maintaining data consistency.### Scenarios#### Scenario 1: Brand New Ship-To Account- **Given** a new Ship-To account arrives from EBS with MAP 2.0 alignments- **When** the integration pipeline processes the account- **Then** a new Ship-To account is created in Dynamics CRM with all mapped attributes#### Scenario 2: Existing Ship-To Account Update- **Given** an existing Ship-To account needs updates from MAP 2.0 data- **When** the integration pipeline processes the account- **Then** the Ship-To account is updated with all attributes from the mapping document#### Scenario 3: Ship-To with Different Territory than Sold-To- **Given** a Ship-To account has different territory alignment than its parent Sold-To- **When** the integration processes the account- **Then** the Ship-To maintains its specific territory assignments while inheriting appropriate organizational data### Technical Considerations- Ship-To accounts may require different field mappings than Sold-To accounts- Territory and sales skill inheritance logic needs careful design- Performance impact of processing Ship-To accounts alongside Sold-To accounts
column19: Moved out of state In QA
column22: 1. **MAP 2.0 Data Integration for Ship-To**   - The integration pipeline must incorporate MAP 2.0 data views for Ship-To accounts   - All fields specified in the Field Mapping Document ([Ecolab-Field-Mapping-FB-OneCustomer.xlsm](https://ecolab.sharepoint.com/:x:/r/sites/IndustrialSS/Shared%20Documents/General/1%20FBU/Raw%20Notes/ADF_ECOLAB_FIELD_MAPPING/Ecolab-Field-Mapping-FB-OneCustomer-002.xlsm?d=wddcf4b53604348619592a0f1f5a8aa64&csf=1&web=1&e=TMTa8H&nav=MTVfezg4NUJEMTM1LUFGMjYtNEUzMC1CMkZDLTEzNjQ3NTZCMjcyQn0)) must be correctly mapped   - Sales Skill values must be set appropriately2. **Ship-To Account Creation/Update Logic**- For new Ship-To accounts: Create account with all mapped attributes including address- Separate ShipTo Account should be created for both the Water and Hygiene Sales Skill Accounts with the respective ERP Sales Skill- The ShipTo Accounts should be linked to the respective Sales Skill Customer Accounts- For existing Ship-To accounts: Update account attributes appropriately while preserving existing relationships- When a new Sales Skill is added for SoldTo, then the Sales Skill ShipTo Account should be created in CRM if its not present in CRM- The ADF pipeline should only create/update Ship To Accounts for OneCustomer EBS Accounts- The mapping logic mentioned in Column AA (Destination Comments) should be followed while creating/updating records in CRM- Handle scenarios where Sales Skills exist or don't exist for the specific Ship-To location3. **Data Integrity and Validation**   - No data loss or duplicates during processing   - Existing EBS-only workflows must remain unaffected   - Ship-To to Sold-To relationship integrity must be maintained   - Successful validation by business stakeholders for Canadian market requirements4. **Relationship Management**   - Ship-To accounts must maintain proper linkage to parent Sold-To accounts### Non-Functional Requirements1. **Performance**   - Integration pipeline execution must not exceed timeout limits   - Processing must scale to handle Canadian customer data volume   - Minimal impact on existing Sold-To account processing performance2. **Reliability**   - Pipeline must handle errors gracefully with appropriate logging   - 99.9% success rate for account processing   - Comprehensive error handling for missing or invalid MAP 2.0 data3. **Maintainability**   - Code must be well-documented and follow established patterns   - Configuration-driven approach for field mappings and business rules   - Clear separation of concerns between Sold-To and Ship-To processing logic

column11:
User Story - 864037 

 

 
Source - MAP 2.0 
Target - CRM Environment (Ecolab Test) 

 
Scenario 1 

 
1. Precondition - A new Ship-to account arrives from EBS with MAP 2.0 alignments.
2. Post the processing of account through integration pipeline, a new Ship-to account along with all the mapped attributes is created in Dynamics 365 CRM.
 
3. Separate Ship-to accounts should be created for Hygiene and Water and the respective ERP Sales Skill should be tagged to the account.
4. The Ship-to accounts should be linked to the respective Sales Skill Customer Accounts.
 

 
Scenario 2 

 
1. Precondition - An already existing Ship-to account needs updates from MAP 2.0 data.
2. Post the processing of account through integration pipeline, all the required information is updated to the Ship-to account from mapping document.
 
3. If new sales skill is added to a Sold-to account, then a corresponding Ship-to account must be created in Dynamics if it was not existing  	previously.
 

 
Scenario 3  

  
1. Precondition - A Ship-to account has different territory alignment than it's parent Sold-to.
2. Post the processing of account through integration pipeline, the Ship-to account inherits all the appropriate organizational data but retains it's specific territory assignments.
  

 
Scenario 4 

 
1. Precondition - A new Ship-To account is created in Dynamics 365 based on mapping document. 
2. Verify that the Ship-to accounts are properly parented to the Sold-to accounts (The Billing Account on the ShipTo will point to the Sold-To Account) 
3. Verify that the Ship-To Owner and Primary Owner is set as the associated Sold-To Owner and Primary Owner respectively 

 
Scenario 5 

 
1.Precondition - A new Ship-To account is created in Dynamics 365 based on mapping document. 
2.Verify that Ship-To are only created for Sold-To Account associated to Districts with 1C flag as 'Yes'. 
3.Verify that Ship-To accounts in EBS with Deletion Flag updated as 'Yes' is not created/updated in CRM.

column8: ADF: Update SHIP-To ADF Pipeline to Populate Site from Sold-To Account for 1C (FBU) and Water Accounts
column11:
As an Integration Engineer I want the ADF SHIP-To pipeline to derive and populate the Site value from the Sold-To account So that 
 all 1C (FBU) Hygiene and Water accounts consistently use the same Site reference and stay aligned with Hygiene accounts.

 
Context and Background: 

 *  Under the One Customer (1C) program, Hygiene (EBS) and Water (NALCO/NSAP) accounts that belong to the same global customer must share a single unified Site in CRM. 
 *  Today: 

 *  Hygiene accounts (FBU) store the Site directly on the Sold-To account. 
 *  Water accounts store multiple SHIP-To records, and each SHIP-To stores its own Site reference independently. 
 

 *  With 1C merging, Water SHIP-To records must inherit the same Site that Hygiene accounts already use, ensuring: 

 *  Consistent Site alignment across divisions 
 *  Site Lookup needs to have the same value for Water Accounts on the Customer Account Record and the Ship To Account Record 
 

 

 
 
Why the ADF SHIP-To Pipeline Must Change?

 *  When a SHIP-To is created or updated via ADF: 

 *  It must inspect the parent Sold-To (Customer) account. 
 *  It must determine if the Sold-To is a 1C account 
 *  (i.e., linked to a District where the 1C Flag = Yes). 
 *  If yes ? it must copy the Site from the Sold-To account onto the SHIP-To. 
 *  If no ? follow existing Water/NSAP logic (do not populate Site via CRM).
column19: Moved out of state Sprint Ready
column22:
*  Identify When the Pipeline Must Populate Site 

 *  Given a SHIP-To record is being created or updated 

 *  And the parent Sold-To is linked to a District where 1C Flag = Yes 
 *  Then the pipeline must populate the Site field on the SHIP-To. 
 

 *  Given the parent Sold-To is not part of an FBU/1C district 

 *  Then the pipeline must not modify the Site reference. 
 *  (Maintain current Water account behavior.) 
 

 

 *  Logic to Determine Correct Site  

 *  Given the parent Sold-To has a Site populated  

 *  When the SHIP-To pipeline runs  
 *  Then the same Site GUID must be copied to the SHIP-To record.  
 

 *  Given the Sold-To is 1C but the Site field on Sold-To is empty  

 *  Then the pipeline must leave the SHIP-To Site empty   
 

 

 *  Support for Both Hygiene-Origin & Water-Origin Accounts  

 *  Given the SHIP-To belongs to a Water account  

 *  And the same customer exists as a Hygiene Sold-To  
 *  Then the pipeline must fetch the Site from the Hygiene Sold-To record  
 *  (this ensures alignment after merging Water + Hygiene).  
 

 *  Given the SHIP-To belongs only to Water and has no corresponding Hygiene account  

 *  And the Water Sold-To account already has a Site populated (post-1C conversion)  
 *  Then the pipeline must copy this Site onto the SHIP-To.  
 

 

 *  Mapping Requirements 

 *  The ADF job must map the following new field: 
 *  SHIP-To.Site ? Sold-To.Site 
 *  Mapping must occur in both CREATE and UPDATE flows:

column6: Integration: CRM Integration with CDM – Account and User Alignment Sync
column11:
This feature supports the flow of Account and User alignment data from CDM into CRM to keep customer structures accurate and up to date.
 
 

 
 
Today’s Setup:
 

 *  CDM sends account and user alignment data to CRM using Azure Service Bus (event-driven). 
 *  Manual API pull option is available in CRM when messages are skipped or out-of-sync. 
 *  CRM uses a combination of site ID and account number to match records. 
 

 

 
What’s Changing / Key Enhancements:
 

 *  CDM may send multiple records (arrays) sharing the same account number — CRM must handle these properly. 
 *  New fields like Sales Skill are being introduced (or renamed), replacing older fields like Global Business Unit. 
 *  Some fields in CDM may be null or missing — CRM should avoid overwriting existing values in such cases. 
 *  CDM site messages may still arrive out of order with asset messages — CRM should handle thin site creation and enrichment. 
 *  Manual pull and retry handling for failed messages (dead-letter logic) must remain intact and be revalidated. 
 

 
Areas That Will Require Code Changes or Attention: 

 *  CRM integration logic needs updates to support renamed/new fields like Sales Skill. 
 *  CRM must support upsert logic that protects CRM-specific fields when CDM doesn’t send values. 
 *  Handle array-based messages in change feed payloads gracefully. 
 *  Ensure thin site handling and enrichment logic remains valid. 
 *  Reconfirm manual pull mechanism functions reliably and avoids duplication. 
 

 
Regression and Testing Needed In: 

 *  Site create and update flows from CDM ? CRM. 
 *  Manual site data pull functionality in CRM UI. 
 *  Partner role assignment: Sold-To, Ship-To, etc. 
 *  Handling missing or skipped messages (retry logic). 
 *  Scenarios where assets are received before sites. 
 *  Message processing for shared account numbers. 
 *  Message purging after 90-day retry window (dead-letter validation). 
 

 
Why This Matters: 

 *  Keeps CRM aligned with CDM as the system of record for site and sales alignment. 
 *  Ensures reliable setup of customer hierarchy and sales visibility in CRM. 
 *  Prevents data quality issues that could disrupt service, reporting, or integration with downstream apps like Ecolab 3D.

column7: Investigate existing MDM API endpoints for Customer Setup Process
column11: The existing Customer Setup Process (v1) provide by the Mulesoft team requires updates to support the new BCA concept and the introduction of Sales skills. This requires current modification and the inclusion of an integration test harness to ensure v1 and v2 support.

column8: TECHNICAL SPIKE: Understand current state (and future state) MDM API Endpoints for Customer Setup Process
column11: As an Integration Specialist, I need to re-create the existing customer setup submission process by calling one or more MDM API endpoints in a chained Postman sequence, submitting data in the current Account JSON format, so that new Base Customer Accounts are created and populated consistently in the master data system without manual intervention or reliance on Dynamics 365 forms, plugins, or JavaScript code.
column19: Moved out of state In Development
column22:
Locate and Document Current State of MDM API 

 *  Using ATTACHED System Architecture diagram for Master Data Management as a starting point, develop your understanding of how MDM supports the existing Customer Setup process from a Web API perspective against the EXISTING Customer Setup Process. (Look at existing Flow to understand where and when the API's are getting called). 
 *  During your exploration, start to develop a future state approach to Customer Setup that supports new Sales Skill and "special" handling of Accounts that have the 1C customer flag set that will require modifications to the existing MDM API (v2) and corresponding payloads. 
 *  Document where the API is located and which environment are supported 
 

Analyze Current Logic 
 

 *  Document how Customer Setup Process works with MDM API today, including the required (and optional) calls used. Leverage existing MDM Diagram attached to this ticket. 
 *  Understand the required payload and JSON format required for each endpoint 
 *  During discovery (and research) capture each endpoint, we will use for shared Postman Collection 
 *  Leverage provide Postman Collection environment to setup additional Client Id and Client Secret to call live 
 *  Identify (and document) Subject Matter expert to include Technica Lead and MDM API developer 
 

 
API Configuration 

 *  Define and locate the existing MDM API for Development? Quality Assurance? Production? 
 *  Add (or Update) a Postman Request for each of the defined endpoints, Address Verification, Duplication Check and Submit (Prospect) with working payloads for each endpoint 
 *  Add (or Update) a Postman request for existing optional, with working payloads for each 
 *  A Postman collection is created with at least two chained requests: one for validation (e.g., check duplicates and address) and one for submission to the MDM create endpoint. 
 *  Requests use environment variables for API base URL, authentication tokens, and dynamic data passing (e.g., validation response ID used in create request). 
 

 
JSON Payload Structure 

 *  The submission request uses a POST method with a JSON body matching the current Account format, including required fields: baseCustomerAccountNumber (text), customerName (text). 
 *  Optional fields are supported: mdmSiteId (text), erpAccountStatus (option set: Active/Inactive). 
 *  All fields align with read-only constraints post-creation, as per existing integration rules. 
 

 
Successful Submission
 

 *  On valid data, the validation request returns 200 OK with confirmation (no duplicates, valid address). 
 *  The create request returns 201 Created, with response including the new account ID and confirmation of population in MDM (e.g., Snowflake or Dataverse). 
 

 
	
Response Verification 

 *  Postman tests assert response codes, JSON schema validation against expected format, and ensure no manual edit fields are returned as editable in the response. 
 

 
 
Authentication Handling 

 *  Document requests to include API key or OAuth token in headers, succeeding with valid credentials. 
 *  Unauthorized requests (e.g., invalid token) return 401 Unauthorized, with logging in Postman console. Data Validation Errors 
 *  How is Invalid JSON handled for the Mulesoft-based API (e.g., missing required field like customerName) returns 400 Bad Request from the API. 
 *  When the call fails, how do we address validation failure (e.g., invalid format) halts the chain and displays error message from response. 
 

 
Impact Assessment 

 *  List areas that maybe be impacted (forms, plug-in, javascript, endpoint addition, json payload, parameters)  
 *  Document changes required we will add to existing System Architecture for Integrations 
 

Duplicate Detection  

 *  If duplicates are found (e.g., existing accountNumber), validation request returns 409 Conflict, preventing submission and prompting user review. 
 *  How are these handled today, if we moved the duplicate detection upstream can we leverage the existing logic or will we need a new MDM endpoint 
 

Testing Approach 

 *  Define scenarios to confirm current behavior? future behavior?  
 *  Develop Integration Test Suite within Postman Collection for more rigorous testing against DEVELOPMENT instance of MDM API. 
 

 
Deliverables 

 *  Technical documentation (memo or wiki) including, summary of Postman Updates, current logic summary, proposed logic, pseudocode, risks, and test outline.  
 *  Updated (working) endpoint that we can call against development that exercises the REQUIRED endpoints and returns a 200 result in Postman.

column7: 43. Handle Sales Skill Logic in the CDM to CRM integration
column11:
Business Requirements: 

 *  Process Sales Skill data from CDM messages to update corresponding CRM records 
 *  Map Sales Skill designations from CDM to CRM, replacing Global Business Unit 
 *  Validate Sales Skill updates against CDM data to maintain consistency 
 

Technical Considerations: 

 *  Integration uses Azure Service Bus for event-driven CDM message delivery 
 *  Coordination with CDM team needed for message formats 
 *  Consider performance impacts due to array processing 
 *  Documented Sales Skill logic for processing CDM messages in CRM

column11: As an Integration Specialist (Developer), I need to document the sales skill contact creation feature so that support teams and future developers understand the new functionality.## User Story**As an** Integration Specialist (Developer)**I want to** document the sales skill contact creation feature**So that** support teams and future developers understand the new functionality### Scenarios#### Scenario 1: System Documentation Update- **Given** the sales skill contact creation feature is implemented- **When** documentation updates are needed- **Then** update system documentation reflecting sales skill account behavior- **And** explain how contacts are created for each sales skill- **And** document account association logic#### Scenario 2: Code Comments Addition- **Given** new code has been implemented for sales skill processing- **When** code comments are needed- **Then** add inline code documentation explaining account establishment logic- **And** document contact creation processes- **And** explain error handling and monitoring procedures#### Scenario 3: Troubleshooting Guide Creation- **Given** support teams need to troubleshoot sales skill issues- **When** troubleshooting documentation is requested- **Then** create troubleshooting guide for account establishment issues- **And** document common error scenarios and resolutions- **And** include monitoring and alerting procedures#### Scenario 4: API Documentation Update- **Given** APIs or interfaces have changed- **When** API documentation needs updating- **Then** update API documentation if applicable- **And** document new configuration parameters- **And** explain integration points and dependencies
column22: ### Functional Requirements1. **System Documentation Updates**   - Updated system documentation reflecting sales skill account behavior   - Clear explanation of how contacts are created for each sales skill   - Documentation of account association logic and Parent Account (parentcustomerid) usage   - Coverage of error handling and recovery procedures2. **Code Documentation**   - Inline code comments explaining account establishment logic   - Documentation of contact creation processes   - Comments explaining error handling and monitoring procedures   - Clear documentation of configuration parameters and their effects   - Code examples and usage patterns for future developers3. **Troubleshooting and Support Materials**   - Troubleshooting guide for account establishment issues   - Documentation of common error scenarios and their resolutions   - Step-by-step procedures for diagnosing contact creation problems   - Monitoring and alerting procedures for operations teams   - Escalation paths for complex issues4. **API and Integration Documentation**   - Updated API documentation reflecting new functionality   - Documentation of configuration parameters and settings   - Explanation of integration points with CDM and CRM systems   - Data flow diagrams and sequence diagrams   - Dependency documentation and version requirements### Non-Functional Requirements1. **Documentation Quality**   - Documentation must be accurate and up-to-date   - Content must be clear and understandable by target audiences   - Documentation must follow organizational standards   - Content must be searchable and easily navigable2. **Maintenance and Updates**   - Documentation must be maintained as features evolve   - Update procedures must be documented   - Version control for documentation changes   - Review cycles for documentation accuracy

Using Postman for Unit and Integration Testing of CDM Changefeed with Azure Service Bus
column11: # Architecture Decision Record: Using Postman for Unit and Integration Testing of CDM Changefeed with Azure Service Bus## StatusProposed## ContextThe Customer Data Management (CDM) system requires a robust testing strategy to validate its changefeed, a stream of events reflecting real-time updates to customer records (e.g., creates, updates, deletes). These events are published to Azure Service Bus queues or topics for downstream processing by various services, such as analytics or synchronization modules. Ensuring the reliability of this changefeed is critical, as it underpins data consistency across the platform. Testing must verify both the generation of correct event messages and their successful delivery and retrieval through Service Bus.Azure Service Bus uses Shared Access Signatures (SAS) for authentication in its REST API, which requires generating time-bound tokens based on a Shared Access Policy. Manual testing of these interactions is error-prone and time-consuming, especially for validating complex workflows like sending and consuming changefeed events. Automated testing is essential to ensure scalability and repeatability, particularly in development and CI/CD environments.We need a tool that supports both unit testing (e.g., validating SAS token generation or message format) and integration testing (e.g., end-to-end message flow through Service Bus). The tool should be accessible to developers with varying expertise, support rapid iteration, and integrate with existing workflows. Postman, a widely-used API testing platform, offers a visual interface, JavaScript-based scripting for automation, and collection-based test suites that can be shared and run in CI pipelines via Newman. This ADR evaluates Postman as the primary tool for these testing needs.## DecisionWe will use Postman to conduct unit and integration testing for the CDM changefeed with Azure Service Bus. The approach involves:1. **Environment Configuration**: Set up a Postman Environment to store Service Bus configuration variables (namespace, queue/topic, key name, key), enabling flexible switching between test contexts (e.g., dev vs staging).2. **SAS Token Generation**: Implement a pre-request script to dynamically generate SAS tokens using JavaScript and Postman’s built-in CryptoJS library, ensuring secure and automated authentication for API calls.3. **Unit Testing**: Use Postman’s test scripts to validate isolated components, such as the correctness of SAS tokens and event message structures, through assertions.4. **Integration Testing**: Create Postman collections to simulate changefeed workflows, chaining requests to send customer events to a queue and retrieve them, with assertions to verify successful delivery and content.5. **Reusability**: Develop a Node.js library to encapsulate SAS token generation logic, reusable in Postman scripts and external test frameworks, enhancing maintainability.This decision leverages Postman’s strengths in rapid prototyping, team collaboration, and CI integration while addressing the specific needs of testing the CDM changefeed’s interaction with Service Bus.### Implementation Details#### Postman Environment SetupCreate an environment named “CDM Changefeed Test” with the following variables:- `sb_namespace`: Service Bus namespace (e.g., “cdm-servicebus”), type “default”.- `sb_queue`: Queue name for changefeed events (e.g., “customer-updates”), type “default”.- `sb_keyname`: Shared Access Policy name (e.g., “ChangeFeedPolicy”), type “default”.- `sb_key`: Primary key string, type “secret” for security.Select this environment in Postman to make variables accessible via `pm.environment.get()`.#### SAS Token Generation ScriptFor both unit and integration tests, use a pre-request script to generate SAS tokens. Place this at the collection level for unified testing:```javascript// Generate SAS token for Azure Service Busconst namespace = pm.environment.get('sb_namespace');const queue = pm.environment.get('sb_queue');const keyName = pm.environment.get('sb_keyname');const key = pm.environment.get('sb_key');// Validate inputsif (!namespace || !queue || !keyName || !key) {    console.error('Missing environment variables');    pm.environment.set('sb_token', null);    return;}// Resource URIconst uri = `https://${namespace}.servicebus.windows.net/${queue}`;// Expiry (1 hour)const ttl = 3600;const expiry = Math.floor(Date.now() / 1000) + ttl;// String to signconst encodedUri = encodeURIComponent(uri);const stringToSign = encodedUri + '\n' + expiry;// Compute HMAC-SHA256const hmac = CryptoJS.HmacSHA256(stringToSign, key);const signature = hmac.toString(CryptoJS.enc.Base64);const encodedSignature = encodeURIComponent(signature);// Build tokenconst token = `SharedAccessSignature sig=${encodedSignature}&se=${expiry}&skn=${keyName}&sr=${encodedUri}`;pm.environment.set('sb_token', token);```#### Unit Testing in PostmanUnit tests validate isolated logic, such as SAS token format or message structure. Add tests in the “Tests” tab of a request or use a dedicated “Unit Test” request with no HTTP call:```javascript// Unit test: Validate SAS token formatpm.test("SAS token has correct structure", () => {    const token = pm.environment.get('sb_token');    pm.expect(token).to.match(/^SharedAccessSignature sig=.+&se=\d+&skn=.+&sr=.+$/);});// Unit test: Validate changefeed event formatconst sampleEvent = { customerId: "123", action: "update", data: { name: "John Doe" } };pm.test("Event JSON is valid", () => {    pm.expect(sampleEvent).to.have.property('customerId').that.is.a('string');    pm.expect(sampleEvent).to.have.property('action').that.is.oneOf(['create', 'update', 'delete']);    pm.expect(sampleEvent).to.have.property('data').that.is.an('object');});```#### Integration TestingCreate a collection “CDM Changefeed Tests” with requests to simulate the changefeed workflow. Use the collection-level pre-request script above.**Example 1: Sending a Changefeed Event**- Request: POST `https://{{sb_namespace}}.servicebus.windows.net/{{sb_queue}}/messages`- Headers:  - Authorization: `{{sb_token}}`  - Content-Type: `application/json`- Body (raw JSON): `{"customerId": "123", "action": "update", "data": {"name": "Jane Doe", "email": "jane@example.com"}}`- Tests:```javascriptpm.test("Event sent successfully", () => {    pm.response.to.have.status(201);});```Run and verify in Azure portal: Queue’s active message count increases.**Example 2: Receiving a Changefeed Event (Peek-Lock)**- Request: GET `https://{{sb_namespace}}.servicebus.windows.net/{{sb_queue}}/messages/head?timeout=30`- Headers: Same as above.- Tests:```javascriptpm.test("Event received successfully", () => {    pm.response.to.have.status(200);    const message = pm.response.json();    pm.expect(message).to.have.property('customerId').that.is.a('string');});```Chain these in Postman’s Collection Runner to simulate end-to-end flow.#### Reusable LibraryTo extend beyond Postman, create a Node.js package `cdm-sas-token`:1. Initialize: `mkdir cdm-sas-token && cd cdm-sas-token && npm init -y`2. Create `index.js`:```javascriptconst crypto = require('crypto');/** * Generates SAS token for Azure Service Bus. * @param {string} uri - Service Bus resource URI * @param {string} keyName - Policy name * @param {string} key - Shared access key * @param {number} [ttl=3600] - Expiry in seconds * @returns {string} SAS token */function generateSasToken(uri, keyName, key, ttl = 3600) {    const encodedUri = encodeURIComponent(uri);    const expiry = Math.floor(Date.now() / 1000) + ttl;    const stringToSign = encodedUri + '\n' + expiry;    const hmac = crypto.createHmac('sha256', key);    hmac.update(stringToSign);    const signature = hmac.digest('base64');    return `SharedAccessSignature sig=${encodeURIComponent(signature)}&se=${expiry}&skn=${keyName}&sr=${encodedUri}`;}module.exports = { generateSasToken };```3. Update `package.json`: Set `"main": "index.js"`, `"description": "SAS token generator for CDM changefeed testing"`.4. Add `README.md` with usage example:```javascriptconst { generateSasToken } = require('cdm-sas-token');const token = generateSasToken('https://cdm-servicebus.servicebus.windows.net/customer-updates', 'ChangeFeedPolicy', 'your-key', 7200);console.log(token);```## Consequences**Benefits**:- **Rapid Prototyping**: Postman’s UI and scripting enable quick test setup without coding full applications.- **Team Collaboration**: Collections and environments are shareable, supporting team workflows.- **CI Integration**: Newman CLI allows running tests in pipelines, ensuring continuous validation.- **Reusability**: The Node.js library extends SAS generation to other tools, reducing duplication.**Drawbacks**:- **Limited Unit Testing**: Postman’s scripting is less robust than dedicated frameworks like Jest for complex logic.- **Learning Curve**: Teams unfamiliar with Postman may need training.- **Dependency**: Relies on Postman’s ecosystem, potentially limiting if the tool changes.**Mitigations**:- Supplement with Jest for deeper unit tests if needed.- Provide team onboarding with Postman tutorials.- Encapsulate logic in the library to decouple from Postman long-term.## StatusProposed. Awaiting team feedback and validation through pilot testing with the CDM changefeed.## Additional Notes- **Testing**: Validate setup with a test queue in Azure. Use Newman for CI runs: `newman run cdm-changefeed-tests.json -e cdm-env.json`.- **Next Steps**: Integrate into CI/CD, explore Azure AD for production auth, and document in a support article for broader dissemination.---This ADR captures the decision to use Postman, detailing setup, testing strategies, and a reusable library, tailored to the CDM changefeed’s needs with Service Bus. It balances rapid iteration with scalability, addressing both unit and integration testing requirements.
