column7: 28. Deactivate Outdated Hub Notifications for FB United 1C Cutover
column11:
Business Objective
 
 
Ensure Hub users only receive valid and actionable notifications after the FB United 1C cutover. Any notifications tied to deactivated, merged, or migrated records (e.g., legacy NSAP billing arrangements, merged SOWs, or closed escalations) must be deactivated so users are not confused by outdated alerts. By proactively cleaning up these notifications, we maintain trust in Hub alerts and prevent unnecessary rework.

 

 
Business Requirements 

 *  Deactivate notifications tied to Scopes of Work once inactive or merged. 
 *  Deactivate notifications tied to Service Plans once inactive or merged. 
 *  Deactivate notifications tied to legacy NSAP Billing Arrangements when migrated to EBS. 
 *  Deactivate notifications tied to open Order Escalations at cutover. 
 *  Retain deactivated notifications for 30 days for fallback, then allow the system job to delete. 
 *  Validate that no new notifications are generated for inactive or migrated records post-cutover. 
 *  Regression-only validation required for notifications where no system change is needed (Opportunities, TSRs, Order Tracking). 
 

 
Technical Considerations 

 *  Hub notifications live in CRM’s Hub Notifications table, linked to entities like opportunities, accounts, billing arrangements, and service plans. 
 *  Nightly notification jobs must reference only active records; deactivation ensures orphaned notifications are excluded. 
 *  Deactivation should be triggered as part of cutover/migration events (e.g., NSAP ? EBS billing arrangement switch). 
 *  Standard practice: deactivate ? retain 30 days ? auto-delete. 
 *  Must align notification clean-up timing with EBS migration milestones. 
 

 
Expected Deliverables 

 *  Notification deactivation rules configured for SOW, Service Plans, Billing Arrangements, and Order Escalations. 
 *  Consolidated regression test results proving Opportunities, TSRs, and Order Tracking notifications continue to work as expected. 
 *  Documented deactivation process for support and fallback. 
 *  Updated functional and technical design docs reflecting deactivation scope.

column8: Regression Validation of Opportunity, TSR, and Order Tracking Notifications
column11:
As a QA tester,
I want to validate that notifications for opportunities, TSRs, and order tracking continue to function as expected post-cutover,
 
So that users can rely on timely alerts without disruptions, even though no new build changes are required for these scenarios.
column19: Moved out of state In Test
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria:

 *  Given opportunity notifications (e.g., reminders at 0, 5, and 15 days before estimated close), 

 *  When opportunities remain active in CRM after cutover, 
 *  Then Hub must continue generating and managing these notifications as it does today. 
 

 *  Given TSR (Technical Service Request) notifications exist in CRM, 

 *  When TSRs are created, updated, or awaiting approval, 
 *  Then the corresponding Hub notifications must still be triggered and deactivated according to current rules. 
 

 *  Given order tracking notifications exist (ETA changes, credit/pricing issues), 

 *  When the nightly order tracking jobs run post-cutover, 
 *  Then Hub must generate these notifications exactly as in the pre-cutover state, without regression. 
 

 *  Given no changes are planned for opportunity, TSR, or order tracking logic, 

 *  When regression testing is performed, 
 *  Then testers must confirm that notification generation, deactivation, and deletion lifecycle remain unchanged. 
 

 

 
Business Requirements: 

 *  No build changes are required for opportunity, TSR, or order tracking notifications. 
 *  Regression testing must validate that: 

 *  Opportunities: Notification triggers and deactivation rules work as-is. 
 *  TSRs: Approval and status-change notifications are unaffected by cutover. 
 *  Order Tracking: ETA and credit/pricing issue notifications continue to work for both NSAP and EBS accounts. 
 

 *  QA teams must build regression test scripts covering each notification type to ensure no unintended impacts.

column8: Deactivate Notifications for Service Plans when Inactive or Merged
column11:
As a Hub user,
I want notifications linked to Service Plans to be deactivated automatically when those plans are inactivated, replaced, or retired (e.g., during site merge/split activities),
 
So that I only see notifications tied to valid, active Service Plans and avoid confusion from outdated ones.
column19: Moved out of state In Test
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria:

 *  Given a Hub notification is linked to a Service Plan, 

 *  When that Service Plan record is marked inactive in CRM, 
 *  Then the associated Hub notification must be deactivated. 
 

 *  Given a site merge or split results in a Service Plan being deactivated and a new one created, 

 *  When the old Service Plan is no longer active, 
 *  Then all Hub notifications tied to that old Service Plan must also be deactivated. 
 

 *  Given a Service Plan remains active with no GUID changes, 

 *  When its details or ownership update, 
 *  Then Hub notifications should continue to function without disruption. 
 

 *  Given a Hub notification is deactivated for a Service Plan, 

 *  When 30 days have passed, 
 *  Then the standard Hub lifecycle process must delete the notification automatically. 
 

 

 
Business Requirements: 

 *  Notifications must be deactivated immediately if the linked Service Plan becomes inactive or replaced. 
 *  Service Plan deactivation can occur during site merges or splits, so Hub must handle these transition cases gracefully. 
 *  No changes to Service Plan GUIDs are expected in normal processes; however, any Service Plan deactivated through migration must trigger notification deactivation. 
 *  Deactivation ensures Hub users are not distracted by outdated or irrelevant Service Plan alerts. 
 *  Follow the standard deactivation + 30-day deletion lifecycle for all impacted notifications. 
 *  Ensure the nightly Hub job only evaluates active Service Plans when generating new notifications.

column8: Deactivate Notifications for Scopes of Work when Inactive or Merged
column11:
As a Hub user,
I want notifications related to Scopes of Work (SOWs) to be automatically deactivated when the underlying SOW record becomes inactive or is merged,
 
So that I am not presented with outdated or irrelevant notifications after account migrations or cutover activities.
column19: Moved out of state In Test
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria:

 *  Given a Hub notification is linked to a Scope of Work record, 
 *  When that SOW is marked as inactive, 
 *  Then the associated Hub notification must be deactivated within CRM. 
 *  Given a Hub notification is linked to a Scope of Work record, 
 *  When that SOW is merged into another record, 
 *  Then all Hub notifications tied to the original (merged) record must be deactivated. 
 *  Given a Hub notification tied to a Scope of Work is deactivated, 
 *  When 30 days have passed, 
 *  Then the automated Hub job should permanently delete the notification. 
 *  Given the nightly Hub notification job runs, 
 *  When evaluating records for new notifications, 
 *  Then it must only consider active SOWs and must not generate notifications for inactive or merged ones. 
 

 
Business Requirements: 

 *  Hub must deactivate notifications for SOWs that become inactive or are merged as part of cutover or ongoing processes. 
 *  Deactivation ensures that users do not see orphaned or irrelevant notifications tied to historical SOWs. 
 *  The standard notification lifecycle (deactivate ? retain 30 days ? auto-delete) must be followed for consistency. 
 *  Ensure the nightly notification job logic only references active SOW records when generating new notifications. 
 *  Business users must trust that notifications in the Hub are timely, relevant, and actionable — outdated SOW notifications erode confidence in the system.

column8: Deactivate Notifications for Order Escalations on NSAP Accounts Migrated to EBS
column11:
As a Hub user,
I want all notifications related to order escalations from NSAP accounts to be deactivated once those accounts are migrated to EBS,
 
So that I do not see escalation alerts for accounts where escalation tracking is no longer relevant in the future state.
column19: Moved out of state In Development
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria:
 

 *  Given a Hub notification is tied to an order escalation on an NSAP account order, 

 *  When that account is migrated to EBS during cutover, 
 *  Then the Hub notification must be deactivated. 
 

 *  Given an NSAP account has been migrated to EBS,  

 *  When Hub nightly jobs run post-cutover, (This isn't a nightly job - notifications are created as the Supply Chain team works and updates these escalations. Post-migration, no new escalations will be created so there will be no new notifications.) 
 *  Then no new escalation notifications must be created for those accounts.  
 

 *  Given notifications have been deactivated at cutover, 

 *  When the 30-day retention period ends, 
 *  Then the Hub’s standard notification cleanup job must delete them automatically. 
 

 

 
Business Requirements: 

 *  All order escalation notifications tied to NSAP accounts must be deactivated as part of cutover. 
 *  Post-cutover, escalation notifications should not exist for FB United 1C accounts now under EBS. 
 *  Standard Hub notification lifecycle applies: 

 *  Deactivate first at cutover. 
 *  Auto-delete after 30 days. 
 

 *  Ensure EBS does not trigger escalation notifications since escalation is an NSAP-only concept.

column8: Deactivate Notifications for Legacy NSAP Billing Arrangements Migrated to EBS
column11:
As a Hub user,
I want notifications related to legacy NSAP billing arrangements to be deactivated once those arrangements are migrated to EBS and marked inactive,
 
So that I only see notifications tied to valid, active billing arrangements and avoid confusion from outdated or retired ones.
column19: Moved out of state In Test
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria:
 

 *  Given a Hub notification is linked to a legacy NSAP billing arrangement, 

 *  When that NSAP billing arrangement is migrated to EBS and marked inactive in CRM, 
 *  Then all Hub notifications tied to the inactive NSAP billing arrangement must be deactivated. 
 

 *  Given a new EBS billing arrangement is created for the same account,  

 *  When the EBS billing arrangement becomes active,  
 *  Then Hub notifications should only be tied to the new EBS billing arrangement and not the inactive NSAP arrangement.  
 

 *  Given a Hub notification has been deactivated for a legacy NSAP billing arrangement, 

 *  When 30 90 days have passed, 
 *  Then the standard Hub lifecycle process must automatically delete the notification. 
 

 *  Given the nightly Hub notification job runs, 

 *  When it evaluates billing arrangements for notification generation, 
 *  Then for FBU1C accounts it must reference only active EBS billing arrangements and exclude NSAP arrangements marked inactive. 
 

 

 
Business Requirements: 

 *  All Hub notifications tied to inactive NSAP billing arrangements must be deactivated during the cutover to EBS. 
 *  Ensure new EBS billing arrangements are correctly tied to Hub notification logic so that users continue receiving valid alerts. 
 *  Notifications should not carry forward from NSAP to EBS arrangements; instead, they must align with the new arrangement records. 
 *  The deactivation + 30-day deletion lifecycle must apply to all NSAP notifications removed during cutover. 
 *  Prevent duplicate or misleading notifications by ensuring the Hub jobs only reference active arrangements going forward.

column7: 27. Hub Order Tracking Alignment with ERP Systems
column11:
Business Objective
 
 
 
 
To ensure Hub users can reliably view order tracking details regardless of whether the underlying account is managed in SAP, EBS, or FB United 1C (EBS-driven) systems. The goal is to harmonize order tracking logic in the Hub so that ERP differences do not cause confusion, gaps, or incorrect information for users managing their customer orders.
on correctly post-merge. Any issues identified during validation should be addressed appropriately to maintain seamless user experience.
 

 
Business Requirements 

 *  Hub must align order tracking logic to use the ERP System field on the account to determine whether to use SAP or EBS order APIs. 
 *  For FB United 1C accounts: 

 *  Use EBS Ship-To accounts for assembling the order tracking payload. 
 *  Replace legacy logic (which relied on customer account details for SAP). 
 

 *  Ensure order tracking details display consistently across: 

 *  Account Details view (user sees orders tied to that account’s Ship-To). 
 *  My Territory view (user sees orders for accounts where they are the primary owner, team member, or for accounts marked as favorites). 
 

 *  Logic should correctly differentiate Water vs Hygiene sales skills under a single customer (1C scenario). 
 *  Hub must support orders for: 

 *  Recently delivered orders, 
 *  Upcoming deliveries, 
 *  Credit block orders. 
 

 *  Favorite accounts must continue to display order tracking across multiple ERP systems (EBS and SAP). 
 *  Ensure no disruption to current SAP order tracking while adding EBS support. 
 

 
Technical Considerations 

 *  Hub must check the ERP System flag on accounts in CRM to route order tracking API calls appropriately. 
 *  For FB United 1C, Hub should: 

 *  Use EBS Ship-To data structures (provided via CRM ? EBS sync). 
 *  Assemble order tracking payloads using EBS Ship-To IDs instead of legacy customer-level IDs. 
 

 *  Adjust My Territory order tracking logic to reference EBS Ship-To accounts when ERP system = EBS. 
 *  Support hybrid/favorite accounts where orders may need to be pulled from both ERP sources. 
 *  Possible dependency on Billing Arrangement redesign (if BA types affect order visibility).  
 *  Regression testing needed for order tracking APIs (SAP and EBS). 
 

 

 

 
Expected Deliverables 

 *  Updated Hub logic to use ERP System field to determine order tracking payload assembly. 
 *  Correct order tracking data displayed for: 

 *  Account detail view (per-account orders). 
 *  My Territory view (primary owner/team member/favorites). 
 

 *  Harmonized order tracking for FB United 1C customers using EBS Ship-To records. 
 *  Regression-tested Hub integration with both SAP and EBS order tracking APIs. 
 *  Documentation of new logic and validation with Sales Ops and business stakeholders.

column8: Technical Spike: Investigate and Document ERP-aligned Order Tracking logic for Hub (FB United 1C)
column11:
As a technical architect, I need to investigate how Hub should assemble and route order-tracking API requests for FB United 1C accounts (vs. non-1C), so that we can define a single, correct approach for account details and My Territory views (self, team, favorites) that uses EBS SHIP-TOs when appropriate and preserves current behavior for NSAP/non-1C—enabling accurate orders, ETA, credit/pricing alerts, and consistent UX.

 
Background:
 
Today Hub builds order-tracking payloads differently for NSAP vs. EBS. With FB United 1C, CRM will hide SHIP-TO on UI but still store/maintain EBS SHIP-TOs. Hub must:
 

 *  Detect the ERP system per account and switch logic accordingly. 
 *  Use EBS SHIP-TOs for FB United 1C flows (account details + territory views) and keep existing NSAP behavior for non-1C. 
 *  Keep favorite/team/ITC scenarios working across mixed ERP footprints. 
 *  This spike defines the authoritative design and artifacts that downstream stories will implement.
column19: Moved out of state Pending PO Review
column22:
*  Functional/Logic Investigation 

 *  Document decision matrix for payload construction: 

 *  Inputs: ERP System (NSAP/EBS), Account Type (customer/prospect), FB United 1C flag, View context (Account Details / My Territory – Me / Team / Favorites). 
 *  Outputs: Account identifiers to use in the API (sold-to vs. SHIP-TO list), batching/limits, and fallback behavior. 
 

 *  Define how Hub detects ERP per account (field source, precedence, edge cases after merges). 
 *  Confirm which SHIP-TOs Hub must include for EBS (primary, all active, filtered by ownership/region?) and how to retrieve/cache them. 
 *  Specify behavior for mixed portfolios (user has NSAP & EBS accounts/favorites simultaneously). 
 *  Determine whether SHIP-TO/BA tiles are shown/hidden in Hub for FB United 1C, and any placeholder text if hidden. 
 

 *  Data & Integration Mapping 

 *  Map the data sources (CRM entities/fields, Snowflake views, APIs) needed to: 
 *  Resolve ERP system & FB United 1C flag. 
 *  Retrieve EBS SHIP-TOs tied to the account. 
 *  Build My Territory lists (self, team, favorites) with correct identifiers. 
 

 *  Define identifier mapping (sold-to, ship-to, account GUIDs, any legacy IDs) and normalization rules. 

 *  UX/Behavior Specs (implementation-ready) 
 *  For Account Details: exact conditions to call order API and which identifiers to send by ERP. 
 *  For My Territory – Me/Team/Favorites: rules for assembling account sets and mapping to API payloads by ERP. 
 *  Rules for empty states (no SHIP-TOs, no recent orders) and mixed-ERP messaging.

column8: Show Order Tracking for My Territory Accounts Where I Am Primary Owner
column11: As a Hub user, when I view the Order Tracking – My Territory screen, I want to see order tracking details for all SHIP-TO accounts where I am the primary owner, so that I can proactively monitor orders recently delivered or upcoming within my territory and take timely action when needed.
column19: Moved out of state Pending PO Review
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria:

 *  Display Orders for Primary Owner Accounts 

 *  Given I am logged into the Hub as a sales user, 
 *  When I open the Order Tracking – My Territory view, 
 *  Then I should see order tracking details for all SHIP-TO accounts where I am the primary owner, including recently delivered orders, upcoming deliveries, and credit block orders. 
 

 *  FB United 1C Logic (ERP-driven) 

 *  Given I am a Hub user aligned with an FB United 1C district, 
 *  When I access the Order Tracking – My Territory screen, 
 *  Then the system should always use the EBS SHIP-TO logic to retrieve order details. 
 

 *  Non-1C Logic (No Change) 

 *  Given I am a Hub user aligned to a non-1C district, 
 *  When I access the Order Tracking – My Territory screen, 
 *  Then the system should continue using the current ERP-driven logic (NALCO Water ? SHIP-TO details, F&B ? customer account details). 
 

 *  Data Accuracy 

 *  Given order details are displayed, 
 *  When I drill into an order row, 
 *  Then the account, SHIP-TO, and ERP system references must be correct and consistent with backend order data. 
 

 

 
Business Requirements: 

 *  Provide visibility of all orders (delivered, upcoming, credit block) for SHIP-TO accounts where the logged-in user is primary owner. 
 *  For FB United 1C accounts, enforce use of EBS SHIP-TO logic for retrieving and displaying order data. 
 *  For non-1C accounts, retain current ERP-specific logic (no functional changes). 
 *  Ensure that order tracking results are displayed in a single consolidated view for easier user monitoring. 
 *  Maintain parity of fields shown in order tracking (order number, product, ETA/delivery date, SHIP-TO, status). 
 *  Support regression testing for non-1C scenarios to confirm no disruption of existing order logic.

column8: Show Order Tracking for My Territory Accounts Where a Team Member Is Primary Owner
column11: As a Hub user, when I view the Order Tracking – My Territory screen, I want to see order tracking details for all SHIP-TO accounts where one of my team members is the primary owner, so that I can stay informed about orders in my territory and assist or intervene when needed.
column19: Moved out of state Pending PO Review
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria:
 
 

 *  Display Orders for Team Member Accounts 

 *  Given I am logged into the Hub, 
 *  When I open the Order Tracking – My Territory view and select a team member that's aligned to an FBU1C district,  
 *  Then I should see order tracking details for all SHIP-TO accounts where a team member aligned to me is listed as the primary owner. 
 

 *  FB United 1C Logic (ERP-driven) 

 *  Given I am a Hub user  
 *  When I request order tracking for a team member aligned with an FB United 1C district, 
 *  Then the system should always use the EBS SHIP-TO logic for retrieving order details. 
 

 *  Non-1C Logic (No Change) 

 *  Given I am a Hub user aligned with a non-1C district, 
 *  When I request order tracking for team member accounts, 
 *  Then the system should continue using the current ERP-specific logic (NALCO Water ? SHIP-TO details, F&B ? customer account details). 
 

 *  Consolidated Territory View (I'm not quite sure what this is - we don't have a single view of orders across multiple territories. Orders are only viewed one primary owner at a time.)  

 *  Given I view My Territory data,  
 *  When order details are retrieved,  
 *  Then both my accounts and my team members’ accounts must appear in one consolidated list.  
 

 *  Data Accuracy 

 *  Given order details are displayed, 
 *  When I drill into an order, 
 *  Then the account, SHIP-TO, owner (team member), and ERP system references must be accurate and consistent with backend order data. 
 

 

 
Business Requirements: 

 *  Extend order tracking visibility to include SHIP-TO accounts where a team member is the primary owner. 
 *  For FB United 1C accounts, enforce EBS SHIP-TO logic for order retrieval. 
 *  For non-1C accounts, retain current ERP-specific logic (NALCO Water ? SHIP-TO, F&B ? customer account). 
 *  Display results for my accounts + team member accounts in one consolidated view. 
 *  Ensure the ownership field clearly identifies which team member is the primary owner for each order. (This would be a new requirement - we don't show per-order ownership. The team member is selected in the top filter then all orders are aligned to the selected team member.) 
 *  Maintain parity of displayed fields with the standard Order Tracking view (order number, product, ETA/delivery date, SHIP-TO, status). 
 *  Validate data through regression testing for both 1C and non-1C districts.

column8: Display Order Tracking Details in Account Details Screen using ERP System -Driven Logic
column11:
As a Hub user, when I view the Account Details screen for an FB United 1C customer, I want the order tracking details to be displayed based on the ERP system of the account so that I can accurately see customer order information without being confused by differences between EBS and NSAP logic.

 *  For EBS (FB United 1C accounts): Order tracking must use EBS SHIP-TOs that are tied to the customer. 
 *  For NSAP or non-1C accounts: The current state logic continues, using customer account identifiers. 
 *  Users should not be exposed to unnecessary SHIP-TO details if hidden in CRM (except where specifically required for EBS).
column19: Moved out of state Pending PO Review
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria:

 *  EBS / FB United 1C Customers 

 *  Given I am a Hub user viewing an Account Details screen for an account with ERP system = EBS and flagged as FB United 1C, 
 *  When I request order tracking details, 
 *  Then the system must build the order tracking API payload using EBS SHIP-TO identifiers, and return order status (recent deliveries, upcoming deliveries, credit issues) tied to those SHIP-TOs. 
 

 *  NSAP or Non-1C Customers 

 *  Given I am a Hub user viewing an Account Details screen for an account with ERP system = NSAP or not flagged as FB United 1C, 
 *  When I request order tracking details, 
 *  Then the system must continue using the existing NSAP logic (based on customer account info) without change. 
 

 *  Consistent UI Behavior 

 *  Given I am viewing the Account Details screen, 
 *  When order tracking details load, 
 *  Then I should see a consistent UI layout (order list with ETA, delivery status, credit flags) regardless of ERP system, but the backend logic is ERP-driven. 
 

 *  Hidden SHIP-TOs 

 *  Given FB United 1C accounts may hide SHIP-TOs in CRM UI, 
 *  When Hub retrieves order tracking info, 
 *  Then SHIP-TOs should still be used in the backend payload while remaining hidden in Hub UI unless explicitly required for the business. 
 

 

 
Business Requirements: 

 *  The Account Details screen in Hub must always show order tracking information for both FB United 1C and non-1C accounts. 
 *  ERP system field drives the logic: 

 *  EBS (FB United 1C): Use SHIP-TO identifiers from CRM/EBS integration. 
 *  NSAP/non-1C: Continue current state using customer account identifiers. 
 

 *  Order tracking details should include: 

 *  Recent deliveries. 
 *  Upcoming deliveries. 
 *  Credit or pricing block flags. 
 

 *  UI consistency: Users should see the same order-tracking layout regardless of ERP source. 
 *  SHIP-TO visibility rule: SHIP-TOs hidden in CRM remain hidden in Hub UI; however, the backend payloads must still leverage them. 
 *  Support mixed ERP portfolios: Users with accounts across both ERP systems should see correct tracking per account type. 
 *  No regression: Ensure that order tracking for NSAP/non-1C continues to work exactly as before.

column8: Configure SHIP-TO and Billing Arrangement Tile Display for FB United 1C vs Non-1C Accounts
column11:
As a Hub user, when I view the Billing Arrangement tile for an account, I want SHIP-TO references to be handled differently for FB United 1C accounts versus non-1C accounts, so that I only see relevant information on the screen while the backend logic still sets the correct SHIP-TOs for order tracking and billing integrity.

 *  For FB United 1C accounts (ERP = EBS): 

 *  SHIP-TO references must be set in the backend but hidden from user view. 
 *  Users should not be required to manually select a SHIP-TO when viewing billing arrangements. 
 *  The system must still tie billing arrangements correctly to the right SHIP-TOs in the backend for integration purposes. 
 

 *  For Non-1C accounts (ERP = NSAP, legacy, or others): 

 *  No changes to current behavior. 
 *  SHIP-TO references remain visible and selectable, as they are today.

column9: Configure SHIP-TO and Billing Arrangement Tile Display for FB United 1C(Mobile&Desktop)

column7: 26. Enhance Hub Experience with Clear Sales Skill Visibility and Ability to Manage Sales Skills for FBUnited1C Customers
column11:
Business Objective
 
 
Today, Hub users cannot easily distinguish whether they are working with a Water or Hygiene account, nor can they manage sales skill associations directly within the Hub. With the transition to the FBUnited1C model, both Water and Hygiene sales skill accounts may exist under the same customer number. Business users need clear visibility of sales skills in all Hub screens and the ability to add sales skills when missing. This will ensure accurate account selection, reduce confusion, and allow seamless management of customer business across divisions. 

 *  Background: Currently our HUB account list and account details screens show Account Name, Number, Account Type, Address, and the account ownership. In order for user to get to the right account or confirm they're on the right account, we'll need to add Sales Skill to each of these places within the mobile and desktop apps. 
 *  Current State: Examples:
  
 

 

[Image] 

 
  
 

 *  Future State: Sales Skill will need to be indicated in each of these places. 
 


 

 
Business Requirements 

 *  Sales Skill Visibility 

 *  Display sales skill information on the account list screen so users can differentiate accounts. 
 *  Display sales skill on the account details screen for each FBUnited1C customer. 
 *  Show sales skill on the Hub desktop home screen within the favorite accounts section. 
 

 *  Sales Skill Management 

 *  Enable users to add a new sales skill for an FBUnited1C customer directly from the Hub. 
 *  Align add sales skill functionality with CRM logic so Hub actions trigger the correct CRM/CLM processes. 
 

 *  Consistency Across Devices 

 *  Ensure visibility and management features are consistent across Hub mobile and desktop apps. 
 

 *  Ease of Use 

 *  Clearly differentiate between Water and Hygiene when multiple sales skills exist under one customer. 
 *  Prevent confusion or duplication by mirroring CRM’s validation rules and restrictions. 
 

 

 
Technical Considerations 

 *  Requires updates to Hub UI components on account list, account details, and favorites sections. 
 *  Integration with CRM must ensure sales skill values are accurate and synchronized. 
 *  “Add Sales Skill” action in Hub should invoke the same backend services or APIs used in CRM for sales skill creation. 
 *  Hub logic must align with FBUnited1C district rules — only accounts flagged as FBUnited1C should display these new fields and options. 
 *  Regression testing is needed to confirm no impact on non-FBUnited1C accounts. 
 

 
Expected Deliverables 

 *  Updated Hub account list, account details, and home screens with visible sales skill fields. 
 *  Working “Add Sales Skill” action from Hub, fully integrated with CRM/CLM workflows. 
 *  End-to-end tested flow showing sales skills synced between Hub and CRM for FBUnited1C customers. 
 *  Updated training and user guidance to help reps and managers adopt the new visibility and management process.

column8: Show Sales Skill in Favorites Section on Hub Home Screen (Desktop)
column11:
As a Hub desktop user,
 
I want to see the Sales Skill (Water or Hygiene) displayed alongside my favorite FBUnited1C accounts on the Hub home screen,
 
So that I can easily differentiate between Water and Hygiene versions of the same customer without confusion when selecting from my favorites.
column19: Moved out of state Pending PO Review
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria:
 
 
 

 *  Current State – Favorites Section (Non-1C Accounts) 

 *  Given I am viewing the Hub home screen favorites section(Desktop) for non-FBUnited1C accounts, 
 *  When the screen loads, 
 *  Then I currently see account information such as account name and account number only. 
 *  And the sales skill is not displayed (as it is not relevant). 
 

 *  Future State – Favorites Section (1C Accounts) 

 *  Given I am viewing the Hub home screen favorites section(Desktop) for FBUnited1C accounts, 
 *  When the screen loads, 
 *  Then I should see the sales skill displayed next to each account (e.g., “Hygiene” or “Water”) in addition to account name and number. 
 

 *  Multiple Sales Skills 

 *  Given a customer has both Water and Hygiene sales skills, 
 *  When both versions of the account are added to favorites, 
 *  Then the sales skill must clearly distinguish the two records.(Desktop) 
 

 

 

 
Business Requirements: 

 *  Add sales skill field to the favorites section on the Hub home screen(Desktop) for FBUnited1C accounts. 
 *  For non-FBUnited1C accounts, the favorites section remains unchanged. 
 *  Sales skill must be displayed next to account name and account number. 
 *  If both Water and Hygiene accounts are favorited, they must be visually distinguishable by sales skill. 
 *  Source sales skill directly from CRM to ensure real-time alignment.

column8: Show Sales Skill in Account List View (Mobile + Desktop) on the Hub
column11:
As a Hub user,
I want to see the Sales Skill (Water or Hygiene) displayed alongside the account name and number in the account list view (both mobile and desktop),
 
So that I can easily differentiate between accounts belonging to the same customer and select the correct one.
column19: Moved out of state Pending PO Review
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria:
 
 

 *  Given I am a Hub user viewing the account list screen, (Sales Skill Field will have a value ) 

 *  When I open the list of accounts under an FBUnited1C district, 
 *  Then the Sales Skill (e.g., Water, Hygiene) must be clearly displayed for each account next to the account name and number.  
 

 *  Given I am viewing the account list on Hub mobile, 

 *  When the list of accounts is loaded, 
 *  Then I must clearly see the sales skill field in the same row as the account number and type.  
 

 *  Given I am viewing the account list on Hub desktop, 

 *  When the list of accounts is loaded, 
 *  Then the sales skill must appear in the table columns and it should be clearly visible after the account number.  
 

 *  Given the account belongs to a non-FBUnited1C district, (Sales Skill Field will be Blank) 

 *  When I view it in the account list, 
 *  Then the sales skill field should not appear (business-as-usual). 
 

 *  Given multiple sales skills exist for the same customer, 

 *  When those accounts are displayed in the list, 
 *  Then each row should clearly show the corresponding sales skill so that the user can distinguish between them. 
 

 

 
Business Requirements: 

 *  Sales skill must be displayed in both mobile and desktop Hub account list views. 
 *  Sales skill should be shown next to account name and number for clear identification. 
 *  Display must apply only for FBUnited1C accounts. 
 *  Non-FBUnited1C accounts should not display the sales skill field. 
 *  Support for multiple sales skills under the same customer must be clear and unambiguous. 
 *  Ensure consistency with CRM sales skill field values.

column8: Show Sales Skill in Account Detail Screen on the Hub
column11:
As a Hub user,
 
I want to see the Sales Skill (Water or Hygiene) displayed alongside the account name and number on the account list details view (both mobile and desktop),
 
So that I can easily differentiate between accounts belonging to the same customer and select the correct one know which one I'm working on.
column19: Moved out of state Pending PO Review
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria:
 
 

 *  Given I am a Hub user viewing the account details screen (1C District Account), 

 *  When I open  an account aligned to an FBUnited1C district, 
 *  Then the Sales Skill (e.g., Water, Hygiene) must be displayed clearly for that account. 
 

 *  Given I am viewing the account details screen on Hub mobile (1C District Account), 

 *  When the account form is loaded, 
 *  Then I must see the sales skill field clearly for that account. 
 

 *  Given I am viewing the account details screen on Hub desktop  (1C District Account), 

 *  When the account form is loaded, 
 *  Then the sales skill must appear clearly for that account. 
 

 *  Given the account belongs to a non-FBUnited1C district, 

 *  When I view it on the account details screen, 
 *  Then the sales skill field should not appear (business-as-usual). 
 

 

 
Business Requirements: 

 *  Sales skill must be displayed in both mobile and desktop Hub account details screen. 
 *  Sales skill should be shown clearly for that account. 
 *  Display must apply only for FBUnited1C accounts. 
 *  Non-FBUnited1C accounts should not display the sales skill field. 
 *  Support for multiple sales skills under the same customer must be clear and unambiguous. 
 *  Ensure consistency with CRM sales skill field values.

column8: Create Prospect from Hub with Pending Approval Status for FB United 1C
column11:
As a Hub user,
I want the ability to create a new prospect account for an FB United 1C district,
 
So that the account enters CRM in a Pending Review status and Sales Ops can validate it before any further action.
column19: Moved out of state Pending PO Review
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria:
 

 *  Prospect Creation 

 *  Given I am a Hub user with create access, 
 *  When I create a new prospect for a district flagged as 1C, 
 *  Then the record should be created in CRM with Account Type = Prospect and Approval Status = Pending Approval. 
 

 *  Restriction on Add Sales Skill for Prospects 

 *  Given I am viewing a prospect account in the Hub, 
 *  When I look for options to manage sales skills, 
 *  Then the “Add Sales Skill” option should not be available. 
 *  And the only option should be to create a new prospect record. 
 

 *  Status Handling 

 *  Given a new prospect is created in CRM from the Hub, 
 *  When the district is flagged as 1C, 
 *  Then the system should default the record into Pending Approval status. 
 *  And the Sales Ops team should be able to review and approve/reject it in CRM. 
 

 *  Manual Sales Ops Validation (R1) 

 *  Given a prospect is created in CRM via Hub, 
 *  When the Sales Ops team reviews it, 
 *  Then they must manually check in CLM UI whether it is a true prospect or duplicate,  
 *  And update the status accordingly (Approved ? Prospect BCA created; Rejected ? record deactivated/merged). 
 

 

 
Business Requirements: 

 *  Hub users must be able to create new prospects for FB United 1C accounts. 
 *  All 1C prospects created via Hub should default into Pending Approval status in CRM. 
 *  Add Sales Skill functionality is not available for prospects in R1. 
 *  Sales Ops is responsible for reviewing, validating, and finalizing prospects in CRM/CLM. 
 *  For non-1C prospects, existing CRM rules continue to apply.

column9: Account creation form - Field behavior inconsistencies across Desktop and Mobile (Sales Skill/Market Segment/Subsegment)
column11:
Issue 1 - Upon removing the 'Sales Skill', the 'Country' and 'State' fields also set to blank in Mobile (this is not observed on Desktop) 

 
Steps - 

 *  Launch HUB Mobile as Sales Rep (user with create access) 
 *  Go to Accounts tab -> Click on 'Add New Account' button for a district flagged as 1C 
 *  Enter all the fields  
 *  Remove value in the Sales skill field 
 *   'Country' and 'State' fields also set to blank in mobile (this is not observed on Desktop) 
 

 
Issue 2 - Subsegment field retains its value even after Market Segment is changed in mobile (this is not observed on Desktop) 

 
Steps - 

 *  Launch HUB Mobile as Sales Rep (user with create access) 
 *  Go to Accounts tab -> Click on 'Add New Account' button for a district flagged as 1C 
 *  Enter all the fields (Sales Skill, Market segment and Subsegment) 
 *  Remove value in the Sales skill field ->  Market segment is set to blank, but not Subsegment  
 *  Select any Sales skill 
 *  Select other Market segment than the one selected in Step 3 
 *  Subsegment field still remains the same as selected in Step 3 
 *  Click on Save 
 *  The account is saved successfully. 
 

Issue 3 - For non-1C accounts, the SubSegment field is set to blank upon removing the Market Segment field on both Mobile and Desktop. The same behavior is observed for 1C accounts as well.  
But - when the user removes the Sales Skill, the SubSegment field retains its value, and only after reselecting the Sales Skill and Market Segment fields, the Sub-segment field become blank on Desktop (in Mobile, Issue 2 is observed) 

 
Steps - 

 *  Launch HUB Desktop as Sales Rep (user with create access) 
 *  Go to Accounts tab -> Click on 'Add New Account' button for a district flagged as 1C 
 *  Enter all the fields (Sales Skill, Market segment and Subsegment) 
 *  Remove value in the Sales skill field -> Market segment is set to blank, but not Subsegment  
 *  Select any Sales skill 
 *  Reselect Market segment  
 *  Subsegment field is now set to blank

Business Acceptance Criteria:
 
 
 
 

 *  Button Visibility – 1C Only 

 *  Given I open a Sales Skill account of type Prospect or Customer from the Hub, 
 *  When the district is flagged as 1C = Yes, 
 *  Then I should see the “Add Sales Skill” button in the command bar or form actions. 
 *  And if both Water and Hygiene Sales Skill accounts are already linked to the BCA, 
 *  Then the button must be hidden. 
 *  And for non-1C districts, the button must never be visible. 
 

 *  Dialog Launch & Owner Selection

 *  And it must display a dropdown of potential owners: 

 *  Default = logged-in user.

 *  Search must be supported.

column7: 25. Enhance GVID TVD Program Creation to Support Sales Skill Visibility and Filtering
column11:
Business Objective
 
 
 
 
To ensure users creating TVD (Total Value Delivered) programs in GVID can clearly identify and select the correct customer account when multiple sales skills (Water, Hygiene) are associated with the same Sold-To. Additionally, users must be able to filter projects by business unit or market segment after FBUnited1C changes so that TVD programs are aligned with the right type of business. This prevents errors, ensures accurate program attribution, and simplifies the user experience.

 
Business Requirements 

 *  When creating a TVD program in GVID, users must see both the Sold-To account details and its associated Sales Skill (e.g., Water or Hygiene) to distinguish between accounts with the same number. 
 *  The Sales Skill field must be displayed alongside account name and number during Sold-To selection. 
 *  Users must be able to filter recommended projects in GVID by Business Unit (BU) or Market Segment after FBUnited1C changes. 
 *  Filtering must ensure that only relevant projects tied to the selected Sales Skill/BU are displayed for program creation. 
 *  Logic should work seamlessly whether the TVD program is created from: 

 *  Marketer recommendations 
 *  Predictive recommendations 
 

 *  Current user flows (site-level TVD creation) should remain familiar, with enhancements layered in to reduce confusion. 
 

 
Technical Considerations 

 *  Investigate how GVID currently retrieves customer business unit information via Market Segment and identify gaps post-FBUnited1C changes. 
 *  A technical spike is required to confirm whether current BU/Market Segment logic can support new 1C structures or if new APIs/fields are needed. 
 *  Ensure consistency with CRM data model changes for Sales Skill and Sold-To alignment. 
 *  Validate downstream impact to reporting and ensure Snowflake/Power BI references reflect the enhanced logic. 
 *  Consider performance impacts when displaying multiple sales skill accounts tied to the same site during Sold-To selection. 
 

 
Expected Deliverables 

 *  Updated GVID UI to display Sales Skill alongside Sold-To account during TVD program creation. 
 *  Enhanced filtering capability in GVID to allow selection by Business Unit or Market Segment post-FBUnited1C. 
 *  Technical spike results documented with clear recommendations for filtering logic updates. 
 *  Updated functional design document outlining user flows for: 

 *  Standard TVD program creation 
 *  Sales Skill differentiation 
 *  BU/Market Segment filtering 
 

 *  Validation and testing to confirm correct program attribution when multiple sales skills exist.

column8: Update Filtering Logic for BU / Market Segment in TVD Program Creation (post-spike outcome)
column11:
As a GVID user creating or reviewing TVD programs for FBUnited1C sites,
I need the filtering logic for Business Unit (BU) and Market Segment to correctly reflect the new sales skill structure,
 
So that I can filter and view projects by the appropriate Water or Hygiene sales skills without confusion or overlap.
column19: Moved out of state In Development
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria :(To be refined after spike outcome; placeholders below) 

 *  Given I am a GVID user at an FBUnited1C site linked to multiple customers with multiple sales skills, 

 *  When I apply BU/Market Segment filters, 
 *  Then I should only see projects aligned with the chosen sales skill and market segment. 
 

 *  Given I am at a site with only one sales skill, 

 *  When I apply BU/Market Segment filters,  
 *  Then I should see all projects without unnecessary duplication or filtering errors.  
 *  When I view the list of filter options,
 
 *  Then the business unit filter should be disabled should have only one option 
 

 *  Given the technical spike delivers updated logic recommendations, 

 *  When this story is implemented, 
 *  Then the new filtering logic must match the design documented in the spike. 
 

 

 
Business Requirements: 

 *  Ensure that BU/Market Segment filtering logic is updated to support FBUnited1C scenarios. 
 *  Filtering must accommodate sites with multiple sales skills (Water + Hygiene). 
 *  Filtering must continue to work seamlessly for sites with only one sales skill. 
 *  End users must not experience duplicate projects or incorrect filtering outcomes. 
 *  All updates must align with the mappings and data structures identified in the technical spike. 
 

 
Notes: 

 *  The “how” (data source, logic implementation, technical dependencies) will be finalized based on the outcome of the technical spike. 
 *  Placeholder acceptance criteria will be updated once the spike deliverables are approved by the solution architect.

column8: Technical Spike – Investigate BU / Market Segment Filtering Logic Post-FBUnited1C
column11:
As a GVID user,
 
When I filter recommended projects at a site that has customers across multiple business units (e.g., Water and Hygiene),
 
I need the filtering logic to correctly reflect the new FBUnited1C account and sales skill structure,
 
So that I can filter projects by business type accurately after the transition.
 

 
Current State: 

 *  Filtering logic in GVID relies on market segment values tied to the global business field. 
 *  This approach works when each site is tied to a single business unit. since Nalco Water market segment values are tied to the Nalco Water "Light" business unit. With FBU1C changes that may not be the case.  
 *  However, for FBUnited1C sites, a single site may now have both Water and Hygiene customers under different sales skills.  (Our current logic handles this scenario. For sites tied to both Water and Hygiene customers, today GVID would show project types for both businesses. The filter functionality allows users to restrict results to just one business if they only want to see only Water-related or Hygiene-related recommendations. But to know whether we should show the filter, we need to determine all of the Businesses represented by the associated customer accounts.) 
 *  Using only global the market segment business unit for filtering will may not differentiate correctly in these cases.  
 

 
Future State (Target):
 

 *  Filtering logic should leverage the new district-to-sales skill and market segment-to-sales skill mappings. (TBD if this is the correct approach. Technical spike will determine how best to adapt filter logic) 
 *  Users should be able to filter recommended projects cleanly by sales skill/business unit at a site that may host multiple sales skills. 
 *  Any new logic must remain aligned with CRM/MDM master data.
column19: Moved out of state Pending PO Review
column22:
*  Investigate and document: 

 *  How current BU/market segment filtering logic works in GVID. 
 *  How sales skill data is stored and retrieved for FBUnited1C accounts. 
 *  The dependencies on CRM, MDM, and Snowflake views (if any). 
 

 *  Propose a future-state filtering approach that accommodates multiple sales skills per site. 

 *  Define whether filtering should be driven by: 
 *  Sales skill ? market segment mapping (preferred), or 
 *  Another mechanism (if identified during investigation). 
 

 *  Document data flow impacts and confirm feasibility with CRM/MDM data models. 

 *  Provide updated logic flow and recommendations in a design note. 
 *  Deliverables must be reviewed and approved by the Solution Architect.

column8: Display Sales Skill on Sold-To Selection for TVD Program Creation in GVID
column11:
As a GVID user,
When I am creating a new TVD program for an FBUnited1C site from either a marketer recommendation or a predictive recommendation,
 
I want the system to display the Sales Skill (Water or Hygiene) alongside the Sold-To account name and number,
 
So that I can correctly identify and select the right account for my program.

column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria:
 
 

 *  Scenario 1: Displaying Sales Skill during Sold-To Selection 

 *  Given I am creating a new TVD program in GVID, 
 *  When I am prompted to select a Sold-To account for my program, 
 *  Then I should see the Sales Skill (Water/Hygiene) displayed alongside the Sold-To name and number. 
 

 *  Scenario 2: Multiple Sales Skills Linked to the Same BCA 

 *  Given multiple Sales Skill accounts are tied to the same BCA,  
 *  When I am choosing the Sales Skill Account(Sold To) for my program,  
 *  Then I should clearly able to pick the right sales skill account.  
 

 *  Scenario 3: Single Sales Skill Linked to the Sold-To 

 *  Given only one Sales Skill is tied to the Sold-To, 
 *  When I am selecting that account, 
 *  Then the Sales Skill should still be displayed for clarity. 
 

 

 
Business Requirements: 

 *  Display Sales Skill (Water/Hygiene) alongside Sold-To account name and number in GVID. 
 *  Differentiate Sold-To accounts where multiple Sales Skills exist for the same number. 
 *  Ensure Sales Skill displays consistently across all creation flows (marketer recommendation and predictive recommendation). 
 *  Always show Sales Skill, even when only one Sales Skill is tied to the Sold-To.

column6: CRM: Opportunity Field Harmonization and Unified Experience across sales skills
column11:
This feature ensures consistent and harmonized opportunity management across all Sales Skills (Water, Hygiene, etc.) within the CRM system by aligning required fields, data entry logic, and notification rules. Currently, opportunity records vary in field requirements, validation stages, and user experience between different Sales Skills, leading to confusion, incomplete data, and misaligned reporting.
 

 
Key components of this feature include:
 

 *  Standardization of mandatory fields across Water and Hygiene Sales Skill opportunities, such as: 

 *  Win Probability 
 *  Estimated Revenue 
 *  Estimated Close Date 
 *  Innovation/Technology indicators 
 *  Opportunity Type and Product Line 
 

 *  Stage-based enforcement of required fields (e.g., certain fields becoming mandatory at Qualify, Develop, or Propose stages) to guide sales users through a consistent progression path and reduce incomplete or non-actionable opportunities. 
 *  Unified business rules and validation logic regardless of Sales Skill, while still preserving any field values that are unique to a specific product line. 
 *  Elimination of redundant or inconsistent field configurations by leveraging a centralized opportunity form structure that supports both Sales Skills, with conditional logic where necessary. 
 *  Harmonization of email notification logic to ensure both Water and Hygiene follow consistent trigger rules—for example, sending alerts for Closed/Won opportunities above a specified revenue threshold or triggering RTW (Retain to Win) notifications based on lost opportunity scenarios. 
 *  Security and user experience improvements to ensure all account-aligned users (e.g., AMs, DMs, CAMs, BDMs) have the correct level of access to create, edit, and view opportunity records across both GTW (Grow to Win) and RTW use cases. 
 

 
This harmonization is a foundational step in supporting the One Customer model, enabling a unified and scalable opportunity management experience across all Sales Skills, and paving the way for better analytics, automation, and cross-sell tracking.

column7: 17. Enable Consistent Availability and Regression Validation of Opportunity Accelerator and Team Member Features Across Sales Skills
column11:
Business Capability Overview
Opportunity Team Members and Opportunity Accelerators are both existing CRM features used to capture participants involved in an opportunity. Their usage patterns differ across divisions: Water frequently uses Opportunity Accelerators to involve cross-functional SMEs, while Hygiene typically does not. However, both features must remain consistently available to all users, regardless of sales skill, without any conditional show/hide logic or differentiated UI experience. 

 
This requirement ensures the features are exposed uniformly in the CRM UI, enabling each division to continue using the functionality they need without disrupting the other — while preserving process fidelity and enterprise capability. 

 
Maintain consistent availability of the Opportunity Accelerator and Team Member features across Water and Hygiene sales skills without altering current business behavior. Ensure users in both divisions have visibility and access to both features, even if one is not used by default. Prevent conditional logic that customizes or hides features by sales skill. Execute comprehensive regression testing to confirm no loss of functionality or unexpected side effects from the One Customer changes. 

 
Business Requirements 

 *  Do not introduce conditional logic (e.g., dynamic show/hide) for Opportunity Accelerators or Team Members based on sales skill. 
 *  Both Water and Hygiene sales reps must continue to see and access both components on the opportunity form. 
 *  Preserve existing business behavior — no harmonization of process is intended. 
 *  Ensure any opportunity-related enhancements under the One Customer initiative do not negatively impact usage of these features. 
 *  Execute comprehensive regression test scenarios to confirm: 
 *  Records can be created and edited with either or both contributor types. 
 *  Security roles (AM, DM, CAM, PDM, etc.) retain correct access. 
 *  Reporting logic and compensation workflows tied to these contributors remain functional. 
 

 
Technical Considerations 

 *  Validate form layout includes both Opportunity Team Member and Accelerator components for all opportunity records. 
 *  Confirm that business rules or JavaScript logic does not prevent display or editing of these components in either Water or Hygiene contexts. 
 *  Evaluate current role-based access — ensure all necessary personas (sales, managers, SMEs) retain appropriate CRUD permissions. 
 *  If there is logic impacting visibility or lookup filtering based on sales skill, it must be neutralized. 
 *  Regression testing should include creation, update, and reporting validations for both components. 
 

 
Expected Deliverables 

 *  Updated opportunity forms with consistent and unfiltered display of both features. 
 *  Regression test plans and execution results validating no behavioral changes in Water or Hygiene. 
 *  Confirmation of access and edit rights for all relevant security roles. 
 *  Validation that reporting pipelines and downstream data flows (e.g., compensation, dashboards) continue to work as before. 
 *  No development changes to behavior or business rules unless required for bug fixes uncovered during regression.

column7: 16. Harmonize Opportunity Management Across Water and Hygiene Sales Skills
column11:
Business Capability Overview
Opportunity management workflows in CRM differ between Water and Hygiene sales divisions today. These inconsistencies include varied required fields, form behaviors, and role-specific access controls. This lack of standardization leads to confusion for users, fragmented reporting, and increased system maintenance effort. As part of the One Customer initiative, this requirement aims to align the opportunity creation and tracking experience across sales skills to ensure a unified, scalable sales process. 

 
Business Objective 
Deliver a consistent and harmonized opportunity experience in CRM for all divisions — enabling AMs, DMs, CAMs, and PDMs to collaborate and manage deals more effectively. The unified experience should eliminate confusion caused by sales-skill-specific logic, reduce the need for custom code, and improve end-to-end pipeline visibility across Water and Hygiene businesses. 

 
Business Requirements 

 *  Consolidate Water and Hygiene opportunity forms into a single harmonized form with consistent layout, logic, and validations. 
 *  Ensure the same fields are presented to users across all sales skill types with no dynamic hiding or conditional display logic based on sales skill. 
 *  Align required fields, validations, and business rules across all Opportunity BPF stages, especially during Qualify and Develop. 
 *  Enforce common user experience and security behavior across roles such as Account Managers, District Managers, CAMs, and PDMs. 
 *  The following fields were discussed during the workshop as potential candidates for harmonization: 

 *  Win Probability 
 *  Estimated Revenue 
 *  Estimated Close Date 
 *  Innovation/Technology Platform Indicator 
 *  Opportunity Type 
 *  Product Line 
 

 *  Additional fields or rules may also require harmonization. The exact field list and business logic will be provided by the business team as part of their ongoing harmonization analysis. Implementation and prioritization will occur only after the finalized list is received from business. 
 

 
Technical Considerations 

 *  Unify opportunity forms and remove duplicate forms by division. 
 *  Refactor or eliminate JavaScript logic currently used to show/hide fields based on sales skill. 
 *  Update BPF stages and required field logic based on the finalized business-aligned harmonization list. 
 *  Update field-level security roles and user access based on harmonized design. 
 *  Conduct full regression testing for existing automation and workflows tied to opportunity records. 
 *  Validate any downstream impact on Power BI, dashboards, reporting views, and external integrations. 
 

 
Expected Deliverables 

 *  One harmonized opportunity form for all sales skill accounts. 
 *  Updated field requirement logic and validations per unified business process. 
 *  Updated BPF stages and harmonized experience across both divisions. 
 *  Revised user security and access rules per role. 
 *  Updated views, filters, and dashboards to support unified reporting. 
 *  Regression-tested automation and process flows. 
 *  Documentation of changes and business sign-off post-delivery.

column8: Technical Spike – Analyze Current State of Opportunity Management Across F&B Water and Hygiene Divisions
column11:
As a technical architect / solution lead,
I need to investigate the current state of opportunity forms, fields, controls, and logic in CRM for both F&B Water and Hygiene sales skills,
 
so that we can document the differences, identify harmonization needs, and prepare for alignment of opportunity management under the One Customer Initiative.
column19: Moved out of state In Development
column22:
Objectives of the Spike:

 *  Capture the full inventory of all opportunity form controls (fields, tabs, subgrids, buttons). 
 *  Document their current visibility, required/optional state, and behavior separately for Water (Nalco Water) and Hygiene (F&B Hygiene) sales skills. 
 *  Identify which controls are impacted by PPF (Process Flow) stages (Qualify, Develop, Propose, Close, etc.). 
 *  Capture any conditional logic, field dependencies, or role-based behaviors that differ between Water and Hygiene opportunities. 
 *  Identify JavaScript methods, business rules, workflows, or plugins that drive this conditional behavior. 
 *  Produce a consolidated comparison for each control showing: 
 *  Control Name & Type (Field, Tab, Subgrid, Button, etc.) 
 *  Relevant BPF Stage(s) 
 *  State for F&B Water (Visible, Hidden, Required, Optional) 
 *  State for F&B Hygiene (Visible, Hidden, Required, Optional) 
 *  Comments (summary of logic, dependencies, special notes) 
 *  Technical Reference (e.g., JS method names, business rule names) 
 

 
Deliverables:

 *  A detailed Excel/CSV or table with the following columns: 

 *  Control Type (Field, Tab, Button, etc.) 
 *  Control Name (logical + display name) 
 *  Relevant PPF Stage(s) 
 *  F&B Water Behavior (Visible/Hidden/Required/Optional) 
 *  F&B Hygiene Behavior (Visible/Hidden/Required/Optional) 
 *  Comments / Notes (description of conditional logic or differences) 
 *  Technical Reference (JavaScript method, Business Rule, Workflow, Plugin) 
 

 *  A short summary document (Word/OneNote) highlighting: 
 *  Key differences between Water vs. Hygiene opportunity management. 
 *  Areas of high complexity (multiple conditionals, duplicate logic, inconsistent rules). 
 *  Recommendations for harmonization (to be validated with business). 
 


 
 
Scope Boundaries:

 *  In scope: Documentation of current state for all opportunity-related forms and controls in CRM for F&B Water and Hygiene. 
 *  Out of scope: Making design changes, removing conditionals, or implementing harmonized form logic (this will come in future functional user stories after business finalizes requirements).

column6: CRM: Enable CRM Reporting Alignment for One Customer via Snowflake View Enhancements
column11:
This feature focuses on updating CRM-sourced Snowflake Views to support the new One Customer account structure, specifically the introduction of Base Customer Account (BCA) and Sales Skill fields. These enhancements will enable downstream reporting teams, including Power BI users, to accurately filter, group, and analyze customer and sales data under the new consolidated structure.

 
Today, reporting relies on legacy CRM account numbers and district naming conventions (e.g., “FP”) to distinguish Water and Hygiene divisions. These identifiers will no longer be valid post-migration, as multiple legacy accounts will be merged under a single BCA. The new reporting structure must support visibility and aggregation based on BCA ID, BCA Number, BCA Name, and Sales Skill assignments.
 

 
The CRM Development Team will be responsible for:
 

 *  Updating relevant Snowflake Views (e.g., account, user, district) to include new fields supporting the One Customer data model. 
 *  Maintaining backward compatibility by retaining legacy account references where required. 
 *  Coordinating schema changes across Snowflake environments (e.g., regional vs. enterprise instances). 
 *  Supporting a broad communications and documentation effort to ensure BI/reporting teams are informed of schema changes and usage guidelines. 
 

 
While Power BI report changes are not in scope for this release, the CRM team’s ownership of Snowflake View updates is a critical dependency for successful Power BI remediation and long-term reporting alignment.

column7: 34. Update CRM-Sourced Snowflake Views to Support One Customer Account and Sales Skill Structure
column11:
Business Objective:
 
 
To enable accurate and consistent reporting in Power BI and downstream analytics tools, CRM data must reflect the new One Customer account structure. This includes surfacing Base Customer Account (BCA) and Sales Skill information in the Snowflake reporting layer so that users can effectively filter, aggregate, and analyze data based on the new organizational model. 

 
Without these updates, reporting will remain reliant on deprecated identifiers (e.g., legacy account numbers, district names like “FP”) that will no longer uniquely or accurately represent accounts after CRM migration.
 

 
Business Requirements: 

 *  Ensure the Base Customer Account (BCA) entity in CRM is represented in Snowflake as a new view or included in an existing reporting structure. 
 *  Add the following new fields to existing Snowflake Views: 

 *  Account Table: 

 *  BCA ID (reference key) 
 *  BCA Name 
 *  Sales Skill ID (reference key) 
 *  Sales Skill Name 
 *  Lead Division Flag 
 

 *  District Table: 

 *  One Customer (1C) Flag 
 

 *  User Table: 

 *  Sales Skill ID 
 *  Sales Skill Name 
 

 *  Sales Skill table 

 *  Sales Skill Name 
 *  Sales Skill Description 
 *  ERP Sales Skill Code 
 *  Status Code 
 *  Global Business 
 

 *  District Sales Skill N:N Native Relationship Table 

 *  District Name 
 *  District ID 
 *  Sales Skill Name 
 *  Sales Skill ID 
 

 *  Market Segment Sales Skill N:N Native Relationship Table 

 *  Market Segment Name 
 *  Market Segment ID 
 *  Sales Skill Name 
 *  Sales Skill ID 
 

 

 

 *  Maintain backward compatibility by retaining legacy account number references (where necessary) to support transitional reporting. 
 *  Ensure field-level mapping and metadata are aligned with Snowflake schema documentation. 
 *  Follow the established Snowflake view update process coordinated through 5-TRAN, with ownership from Zahara and Siddharth. 
 *  Validate that downstream Power BI teams are made aware of schema changes through formal communication and updated mapping documentation. 
 

 
Technical Considerations: 

 *  All changes must be implemented via the FiveTran integration layer, which maps CRM tables and fields to Snowflake Views. 
 *  Collaboration with the FiveTran team is required to: 

 *  Identify affected tables and corresponding transformation logic. 
 *  Adjust mappings or create new transformations for BCA and Sales Skill–related fields. 
 

 *  New views or modified views must adhere to naming conventions and data refresh cycles defined in the enterprise Snowflake environment. 
 *  Synchronization across regional and enterprise Snowflake environments is critical to ensure consistency in global reporting. 
 *  Schema documentation must be updated to reflect newly added fields, including data types, descriptions, and example use cases. 
 

 
Expected Deliverables: 

 *  A new or updated Snowflake View for Base Customer Account (BCA) entity, with proper linking to existing account views. 
 *  Updated Snowflake Views for: 

 *  Account Table (with BCA references and Sales Skill) 
 *  District Table (with One Customer Flag) 
 *  User Table (with Sales Skill) 
 

 *  Coordination notes and mapping documentation with Zara and Siddharth to reflect all 5-TRAN adjustments made. 
 *  Summary report or change log detailing: 

 *  Affected views 
 *  Fields added or modified 
 *  Date of deployment 
 *  Backward compatibility checks 
 

 *  Internal test validation confirming that CRM data is accurately reflected in Snowflake post-deployment.

column8: Update Existing Snowflake User View with Sales Skill References
column11:
As a CRM reporting user,
I want the Snowflake User view to include sales skill references,
 
so that I can analyze user activities and account ownership in the context of their assigned sales skills.
column19: Moved out of state Pending PO Review
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria:
 

 *  Validate that the below column is added to the uvw_Users 

 *  ERP Sales Skill ID 
 *  ERP Sales Skill
 
 

 

 *  Given a CRM user has a sales skills assigned,  

 *  When data is refreshed into Snowflake,  
 *  Then the User view should display the corresponding sales skill(s).  
 

 *  Given a CRM user does not have a sales skill assigned,  

 *  When the User view is refreshed in Snowflake,  
 *  Then the sales skill fields should remain blank with no errors.  
 

 *  Given reporting teams query the User view,  

 *  When they filter by sales skill,  
 *  Then they should see accurate and consistent results aligned with CRM assignments.  
 

 

 
Business Requirements: 

 *  Update the existing Snowflake User view to include the following fields from CRM:

column6: CRM: CRM Retain-to-Win and Lost Business Notification and Access Harmonization
column11:
This feature focuses on ensuring consistent and reliable handling of Retain-to-Win (RTW), Grow-to-Win (GTW), and Lost Business workflows within CRM, particularly in the context of the unified “One Customer” model. The objective is to harmonize business rules for field usage, notification triggers, and user access across both Water and Hygiene divisions.

 
Currently, workflows for RTW and lost business opportunities are manually entered into CRM by field-aligned users, triggering targeted email notifications to appropriate leadership and sales teams. However, inconsistencies exist between Water and Hygiene in how required fields and email notifications are handled.
 

 
As part of this feature, the following enhancements and validations are in scope:
 

 *  Email Notification Logic Harmonization: Align trigger conditions (e.g., Closed-Won over $10K, RTW submissions) and standardize recipient distribution lists across both Water and Hygiene divisions. Existing rules apply only to Hygiene and must be expanded to cover Water opportunities. 
 *  Security Model Validation: Ensure all relevant CRM roles—AMs, ADMs, DMs, AVPs, CAMs, and CAM Leaders—retain the ability to initiate, edit, and track RTW, GTW, and Lost Business entries. Avoid over-restricting data entry by role to support flexibility in the field. 
 *  Process Continuity in Unified Model: Validate that existing CRM dashboards, views, and Power BI reports continue to function correctly post-BCA implementation for managing RTW and GTW pipelines at the consolidated account level.

column7: 36. Validate and Maintain Role-Based Access to RTW and Lost Business Entry Forms under One Customer Structure
column11:
Business Objective:
Ensure that only the appropriate roles across both Water and Hygiene divisions have the ability to create, edit, and view Retain-to-Win (RTW) and Lost Business entries in CRM, even after implementing the new One Customer structure. This will protect data integrity, support frontline ownership, and allow timely visibility for leadership teams without overexposing sensitive risk-related data. 

 
Business Requirements: 

 *  RTW and Lost Business forms are currently used by a variety of roles including: 

 *  Account Managers (AMs) 
 *  District Managers (DMs) 
 *  Area Vice Presidents (AVPs) 
 *  Customer Account Managers (CAMs) 
 *  CAM Leaders 
 

 *  All users who are aligned to the account should be able to: 

 *  Create a new RTW or Lost Business record 
 *  View any record submitted for accounts within their territory or assigned accounts 
 

 *  No restrictions should be added based on division (Water vs. Hygiene) — access should be based on account alignment and user role only. 
 *  Users not aligned to the account or role should not be able to create or view RTW/Lost Business records. 
 *  Existing access behavior should be regression-tested under the new Base Customer Account (BCA) structure to ensure: 

 *  Account alignment is respected 
 *  No unintended exposure of records 
 *  Proper visibility across merged accounts 
 

 *  Security roles or team-based access should not require any immediate changes unless regression identifies issues. 
 

 
Technical Considerations: 

 *  Review and validate existing security roles, field-level security, and record-level access rules related to RTW/Lost Business entities. 
 *  Confirm access behavior works as expected post-migration to 1C structure, especially for accounts with shared Water and Hygiene sales skills. 
 *  Reassess team ownership, user privileges, and security roles for: 

 *  Create, Read, Write, Append, and Append To privileges on RTW and Lost Business records. 
 

 *  Ensure that role-based forms, views, and dashboards continue to show only authorized data per user persona. 
 *  No new role creation or major access model change is expected, but a thorough regression test must be performed. 
 *  Security logic may rely on CRM’s access team templates, hierarchical security, or custom plugins/workflows—each must be reviewed. 
 

 
Expected Deliverables: 

 *  Confirmed list of personas and their current access rights to RTW and Lost Business forms. 
 *  Regression test results showing: 

 *  Users aligned to an account can create and view records 
 *  Non-aligned users cannot access these forms or records 
 

 *  Documentation of existing access logic with notes on how it functions under merged BCA accounts. 
 *  Sign-off from business owners confirming that current access model meets One Customer expectations. 
 *  Optional recommendation: Define and publish a matrix showing personas vs. permissions for clarity.

column7: 35. Standardize RTW and Lost Business Notification Rules Across Water and Hygiene Sales SKills
column11:
Business Objective:
Ensure consistent and accurate communication of at-risk accounts and lost business events across all divisions (Water and Hygiene) by standardizing the notification logic and email distribution rules within CRM. This supports proactive leadership engagement, timely intervention, and a unified experience under the One Customer model. 

 
Business Requirements: 

 *  When a user submits a Retain-to-Win (RTW) or Lost Business entry in CRM, a notification email should be sent automatically to a defined set of recipients. 
 *  Today, this email logic differs across divisions: 

 *  For example, Hygiene has notification rules triggered for deals >$10K, while Water may lack equivalent logic. 
 

 *  The distribution lists and notification criteria must be reviewed and standardized across both Water and Hygiene. 
 *  Business teams (e.g., Tracy, Bri) will need to: 

 *  Define the criteria that trigger notifications (e.g., opportunity stage, value threshold). 
 *  Define the recipients per region or role (e.g., AVPs, CAMs, DMs). 
 

 *  Until these inputs are received, no changes should be implemented. 
 *  CRM should support flexible configuration, so future updates to recipients or logic can be managed with minimal technical effort. 
 *  Once standardized, all RTW and Lost Business entries — regardless of originating division — should trigger a single, unified notification flow. 
 

 
Technical Considerations: 

 *  The current notification flows must be audited to understand what is implemented for Hygiene and Water. 
 *  If flows are built via Power Automate, plugins, or CRM workflows, their logic and triggers will need to be reviewed and aligned. 
 *  Dynamic distribution lists or email templates may need to be created or reused for better maintainability. 
 *  A technical spike may be required to: 
 *  Inventory current notification logic 
 *  Confirm notification trigger points (on form save, stage change, or field update) 
 *  Analyze whether separate flows exist or if shared ones can be re-used. 
 *  
 
 *  No UI changes are anticipated at this time. 
 *  Ensure no regressions occur for existing business units post-change. 
 

 
Expected Deliverables: 

 *  Documented list of current RTW/Lost Business notification flows by division (pre-change baseline). 
 *  Finalized notification rules and recipient lists provided by business. 
 *  Updated logic in CRM to trigger unified notifications upon RTW or Lost Business submission, per agreed rules. 
 *  Regression testing results confirming that: 

 *  Notifications are sent reliably 
 *  No duplicate or missed emails 
 *  No other opportunity flows are broken 
 

 *  Documentation outlining how to maintain and update recipient lists or logic in the future.

column8: Technical Spike – Analyze and Document RTW and Lost Business Notification Processes across Water and Hygiene Divisions
column11:
As a technical analyst,
I want to investigate and document the existing RTW (Retain-to-Win) and Lost Business notification logic and configurations across Water and Hygiene divisions in CRM,
 
so that we can identify gaps, differences, and opportunities to standardize the notification and communication process under the One Customer model.
 

 
Background and Rationale: 
Within the current CRM environment, the RTW (Retain-to-Win) and Lost Business notification processes differ significantly between the Water and Hygiene divisions. 

 
For example:
 

 *  Hygiene has established notification rules that trigger email alerts when deals exceed a certain threshold (e.g., $10K), notifying specific distribution lists (e.g., Regional Leaders, BSEs). 
 *  Water, however, may lack equivalent automation or use different thresholds, criteria, and recipient logic. 
 

 
These inconsistencies cause: 

 *  Unequal visibility of at-risk accounts and lost business events across divisions. 
 *  Missed opportunities for proactive leadership intervention and timely customer engagement. 
 *  Confusion among users about which teams are notified and under what conditions. 
 

 
Under the One Customer model, both Water and Hygiene divisions must follow a unified notification framework — ensuring that leadership and sales teams receive consistent, timely, and accurate communications when RTW or Lost Business entries are submitted. 

 
This spike will focus on:
 

 *  Conducting a technical review of CRM workflows, Power Automate flows, plugins, or email alerts related to RTW and Lost Business. 
 *  Identifying and documenting differences in notification logic, criteria, thresholds, and recipients across Water and Hygiene. 
 *  Producing a comparative analysis report highlighting key findings, current behavior, and areas requiring harmonization. 
 *  Preparing inputs for the business team (BSE / Sales Enablement) to define the future standardized notification rules.

 *  Then a side-by-side comparison must be created showing key parameters for Water vs Hygiene, including: 
 *  Trigger field(s) and values 
 *  Notification thresholds (e.g., $ value, deal stage) 
 *  Recipients or distribution logic 
 *  Email templates used 
 

 *  Scenario 3 – Deliver Findings Report for Business Review 

 *  Given the comparative analysis, 
 *  When the spike concludes, 
 *  Then a structured findings report must be shared with business (BSE, Sales Enablement, Leadership) summarizing: 
 *  Current-state notification logic 
 *  Gaps and inconsistencies 
 

 

Deliverables:

 *  Inventory of notification components in CRM. 
 *  Comparative table: Water vs Hygiene notification logic. 
 *  Summary of gaps, redundancies, and inconsistencies. 
 

 *  Presentation-ready summary for leadership/business review.
