9. Role-Based Access and Navigation Model for Base Customer Account (BCA) in CRM
column11:
Business Capability:
 
Today, CRM users in Food & Beverage United (FBU) operate primarily in silos based on their assigned sales skill (Water or Hygiene). Each sales rep, district manager (DM), or corporate account manager (CAM) works within the bounds of their business line and accesses only those accounts that fall under their ownership or territory. There is no unified view of the customer across sales skills, and access is highly fragmented. 

 
With the One Customer initiative, the organization is moving toward a consolidated customer model. Under this new model, multiple Sales Skill Accounts (Water or Hygiene) will be linked under a central entity called the Base Customer Account (BCA). This allows for:
 

 *  A 360° view of customer engagement across business lines. 
 *  Consolidated opportunity visibility. 
 *  Unified account management strategies. 
 

 
The business wants to maintain tight control over who sees what to avoid information overload while still promoting cross-collaboration and transparency where needed. Key business personas will require different types of access: 

 *  Sales Reps (Water or Hygiene) should continue to see only their aligned accounts in “My Accounts” but should be able to navigate to the linked BCA to view a consolidated picture and understand what’s happening in other business lines (e.g., a Water rep viewing Hygiene opportunities). 
 *  District Managers (DMs) will oversee both Water and Hygiene accounts under their district. They should be able to navigate directly to BCAs from the sitemap and view all associated Sales Skill Accounts under their purview. 
 *  Corporate Account Managers (CAMs) will manage parent H5/organization-level accounts and should have a way to discover and access all BCAs linked to their parent accounts, enabling them to manage strategic relationships more effectively. 
 

 
In the future state, ownership will remain unchanged for Sales Skill Accounts, but access to BCAs should be read-only and granted via controlled security mechanisms (roles or team-based access). The goal is to enable insight without disrupting current ownership and access boundaries. 

 
Corporate (H5) Account Ownership and Visibility

 *  H5 (Corporate) accounts are identified using the “Parent Account” field on the Base Customer Account (BCA) and/or Sales Skill Account forms. 
 *  This “Parent Account” is a lookup field—users can click to navigate to the Corporate Account record. 
 *  Only Corporate Account Managers (CAMs) should have full ownership and write access to H5 accounts. 
 *  All H5 accounts should be owned by CAMs by default and shared explicitly with backup CAMs or appropriate regional corporate roles. 
 *  Non-CAM users (e.g., AMs, DMs, BDMs, ) should: 

 *  Have read-only access to the H5 account only if it’s linked to their Sales Skill Account via BCA. 
 *  Be able to see the Parent Account field, click and navigate to the Corporate Account (read-only). 
 *  Not be allowed to edit or replace the H5 account lookup on the sales skill account form. 
 

 *  User Experience Consideration: 

 *  When a user clicks the Parent Account link (H5), the system should open the H5 account record in read-only mode, unless the user is a CAM. 
 *  Attempting to edit an H5 record by a non-CAM user should result in a “read-only access” banner or toast message, clarifying access restrictions. 
 

 

 
 

 
Technical Implementation Considerations: 

 *  Security Role & Access Design: 

 *  Implement a dedicated security role (e.g., “BCA Read Access”) to provide read-only access to the Base Customer Account entity. 
 *  Evaluate whether record-level sharing (manual or automated) or team ownership of BCA records is most scalable. 
 *  Team ownership preferred for ease of maintenance and performance. 
 *  Evaluate the possibility of creating functional teams (e.g., FBU Sales Team, CAM Team) with access granted via business unit or persona membership. 
 

 *  Ownership of Base Customer Account: 

 *  BCAs should not be owned by individual users. 
 *  Assign BCAs to system or functional teams (e.g., “CRM BCA Admin”) to avoid accidental edits and simplify access management. 
 *  Ensure no duplicate ownership-related logic interferes with record-level permissions. 
 

 *  Sitemap Configuration: 

 *  Add a new section in the sitemap labeled “Base Customer Accounts” under Sales or Customer area. 
 *  Use a custom entity icon to differentiate BCA from standard account entities. 
 *  Views under BCA should include key fields: BCA Name, BCA Number, Primary Sales Skill Account, Total Opportunities, Industry, Sub-Market, Linked ERP ID. 
 *  Enable filters in views for Sales Skill, Territory, Ownership, and Account Status. 
 

 *  Form & Subgrid Design: 

 *  BCA form will include tabs for: 
 *  Linked Sales Skill Accounts (subgrid with hyperlinks). 
 *  Opportunities (aggregated view). 
 *  Contacts (aggregated or related). 
 *  Any reference metadata required (e.g., creation source, district, global business, sales skill summaries). 
 

 *  Persona-Based Navigation: 

 *  Sales Reps: 

 *  Maintain current access to only their assigned accounts. 
 *  Add a read-only BCA lookup on their accounts to allow click-through navigation. 
 *  No change to My Accounts views; BCA visibility only through linked records. 
 

 *  District Managers: 

 *  Access all BCAs under their territory directly from the sitemap. 
 *  Can use BCA views to manage full customer coverage across business lines. 
 

 *  Corporate Account Managers: 

 *  On organization (H5) accounts, update the Account-Contact-Email Domain tab: 
 *  Show linked Sales Skill Accounts with a new column for BCA Number (with hyperlink). 
 *  Allow CAMs to click into BCA to view overall footprint, accounts, and opportunities. 
 

 

 *  Technical Spikes and Risk Mitigation: 

 *  Conduct a technical spike to assess: 

 *  Team-based access vs. record sharing at scale. 
 *  Ability to propagate access via the Sales Skill Account ? BCA lookup. 
 *  UI performance or security cache limitations with large team memberships. 
 

 *  Evaluate if the sharing logic should be automated during Sales Skill Account creation or BCA linkage. 
 

 

 
Expected Deliverables: 

 *  Finalized BCA security role configuration and access provisioning model. 
 *  Updated CRM sitemap with Base Customer Account section and custom icon. 
 *  Configured views and forms with all required metadata and filters. 
 *  Functional subgrids and lookups: 

 *  On Sales Skill Account ? BCA (read-only, clickable). 
 *  On H5 parent ? Sales Skill Accounts + BCA link. 
 

 *  Documentation of technical spike outcomes: 

 *  Access model decision (team vs. sharing). 
 *  Record ownership structure. 
 *  Navigation strategy for each persona. 
 

 *  End-to-end regression testing for each persona (Sales Rep, DM, CAM) validating access, navigation, and security scope.

column8: Define BCA Read-Only Access Model (Team-Level & User-Level Roles; Integration Edit-Only)
column11:
As a CRM business user, I need controlled visibility to Base Customer Account (BCA) records in CRM so that I can access the customer information relevant to my role and district/team, while ensuring BCA data is not editable by any business persona and remains system-of-record driven by integrations.
As a system/integration account, I need the ability to create, update, and maintain BCA records through integration pipelines, so that the BCA data is always accurate, synchronized, and aligned with master data sources (CDM, EBS, etc.).
 

 
This ensures end-to-end visibility without compromising data integrity, following the principle of read-only for business users, edit-only for integration accounts.
column19: Moved out of state Pending Prod Release
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria:
 
 
 
 

 *  Visibility – Team-Level Roles 

 *  Given a user with a team-level BCA access role (e.g., AM/DM tied to a district team), 

 *  When they navigate to BCA records in CRM, 
 *  Then they should see only those BCAs owned by or linked to their assigned district team. 
 

 

 *  Visibility – User-Level Roles 

 *  Given a user with a user-level BCA access role (e.g., Accelerators, Ops Admins, BDMs), 

 *  When they navigate to BCA records, 
 *  Then they should see all BCAs within their business unit scope (e.g., FB NA). 
 

 

 *  Read-Only Access 

 *  Given any business persona (e.g., AM, DM, Accelerator, Ops Admin, BDM), 

 *  When they open a BCA record, 
 *  Then the record fields must be read-only, with no ability to edit, create, or delete. 
 

 

 *  Integration Edit-Only   

 *  Given a service account used for CDM/MDM integration,   

 *  When the integration pipeline updates or creates BCA records,   
 *  Then full create/update privileges should be applied, overriding read-only restrictions for users. 
 

 

 *  Sitemap & Navigation Control 

 *  Given a user without a BCA reader role, 

 *  When they access the CRM sitemap, 
 *  Then BCA navigation should not appear in their sitemap or global search results. 
 

 

 

 
Business Requirements: 

 *  Provide role-based access control for BCAs to ensure no manual edits by users. 
 *  Create two new security roles: 

 *  Team-Level Role (e.g., “Ecolab-1C-TASR”): Grants BCA read access scoped to district team ownership. 
 *  User-Level Role (e.g., “Ecolab-1C-UASR”): Grants BCA read access scoped to BU (FBNA). 
 

 *  Limit write access exclusively to integration accounts (CDM, E3D, etc.). 
 *  BCA records must remain read-only for all business personas, regardless of user role. 
 *  Ensure BCA navigation and global search results respect assigned roles. 
 

 
Developer Notes: 

 *  Security Role Setup 

 *  Create two custom security roles: 

 *  Ecolab-1C-TASR (Team Access Security Role): Read, Append, Append To on BCA, scoped to district team ownership. 
 *  Ecolab-1C-UASR (User Access Security Role): Read, Append, Append To on BCA, scoped to BU/FBNA. 
 

 *  Assign privileges to Read, Append, Append To only. No Create/Write/Delete for business users. 
 *  Ensure service accounts (integration) retain full CRUD privileges. 
 

 *  Access Filtering 

 *  Configure ownership logic so BCA records are owned by the district team of the lead division account. 
 *  Ensure team-level security roles only display BCAs linked to the user’s team. 
 *  BU-level users (Accelerators, Ops Admins, BDMs) see all FBNA BCAs. 
 

 *  Navigation & Search Control 

 *  Update sitemap so BCA entity appears only when role is assigned. 
 *  Configure global search to respect role assignments.

column8: Configure Security for Sales Skill Master Data (System Admin Edit; Others Read-Only)
column11:
As a CRM system administrator, I need to ensure that the Sales Skill master data table is secured with the correct access model, so that only authorized roles can create, update, or delete Sales Skill records while other roles have read-only access, ensuring both data integrity and proper visibility.

 *  The Sales Skill table will be created as an organization-owned entity. 
 *  Sales Skill lookups will be referenced in other tables (e.g., Account, User, District) and therefore require consistent read access for business users while restricting modification to admins only.
column19: Moved out of state Pending Prod Release
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria:
 

 *  Given I am a System Admin, 

 *  When I access the Sales Skill entity, 
 *  Then I can create, update, delete, read, append, and append to records without restriction. 
 

 *  Given I am an Ops Admin or Ops Admin Lead, 

 *  When I access the Sales Skill entity, 
 *  Then I can read records, append Sales Skill to related records, and append related records to Sales Skill, but cannot create, update, or delete Sales Skill records. 
 

 *  Given I am a business user (e.g., AM, DM, CAM, BDM, Sales Rep), 

 *  When I access forms or views that reference Sales Skill lookup fields (e.g., on Accounts, Users), 
 *  Then I can see and use the lookup values but cannot modify or create Sales Skill master data records. 
 

 *  Given Sales Skill is used as a lookup on Account, User, District, and other related entities, 

 *  When I attempt to view or assign values, 
 *  Then the Sales Skill values display consistently based on my security role permissions. 
 

 

 
Business Requirements: 

 *  Sales Skill table must be organization-owned, ensuring consistent global security. 
 *  Maintain data integrity: only System Admins can directly manipulate the Sales Skill master data. 
 *  Ensure Ops Admins and Leads can leverage existing Sales Skill records for their operational duties (Append/Append To), but cannot alter master data. 
 *  Ensure all business users can see Sales Skill values wherever referenced (lookup, view, or report), but remain read-only. 
 *  Security must extend consistently to all references (Account, User, District, Customer Setup, etc.). 
 *  Prevent accidental or unauthorized creation of new Sales Skill values by non-admins. 
 

 
Developer Notes: 

 *  Entity Ownership: SalesSkill will be configured as an Organization-Owned entity. 
 *  Role Permissions: 

 *  System Admin: Create = Yes, Read = Yes, Write = Yes, Delete = Yes, Append = Yes, Append To = Yes. 
 *  Ops Admin / Lead: Create = No, Read = Yes, Write = No, Delete = No, Append = Yes, Append To = Yes. 
 *  All Other Roles (AM, DM, CAM, BDM, Sales Reps, Service Users): Create = No, Read = Yes, Write = No, Delete = No, Append = Yes, Append To = Yes. 
 

 *  Lookup Behavior: 

 *  Lookup field on Account form (Sales Skill) ? visible, editable based on other field rules, but lookup values restricted to existing Sales Skill master data. 
 *  Lookup field on User form (Default Sales Skill) ? editable only where district is 1C and field unlocked per user story; security still enforces read-only on master data. 
 *  Lookup field on District form (N:N Sales Skill-District mapping) ? Ops Admin/System Admin can manage mapping; business users only consume. 
 

 *  Audit: All create/update/delete actions on Sales Skill records must be audited (user ID, timestamp, field changes). 
 *  Data Repair/Migration: At cutover, existing Sales Skill values (Water, Hygiene, etc.) must be bulk-loaded by System Admins; no business user action required. 
 *  Navigation: Sales Skill table should not be shown as a sitemap link for business users; only visible in admin apps. 
 *  Testing: 

 *  Verify System Admin full access. 
 *  Verify Ops Admin/Lead read + append only. 
 *  Verify business users can only consume values in lookups but cannot add/modify Sales Skill master data.

column8: Configure Security for Market Segment? Sales Skill Mapping (Ops Admin & System Admin Manage; Others Read-Only)
column11:
As a System Admin or Ops Admin,
I need the ability to create, update, and remove mappings between Market Segments and SalesSkills,
 
so that CRM enforces correct filtering of Market Segments by SalesSkill for 1C districts,
 
while ensuring that business users can only view these mappings in read-only mode.
column19: Moved out of state Pending Prod Release
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria:
 
 
 

 *  Given I am a System Admin or Ops Admin or Ops Admin Lead, 

 *  When I access the Market Segment ? SalesSkill mapping, 
 *  Then I can add , update, and remove mappings as needed. 
 

 *  Given I am a business user (e.g., AM, DM, CAM, BDM, Sales Rep), 

 *  When I view Market Segment ? SalesSkill mappings, 
 *  Then I can only see the mapping but not modify or delete it. 
 

 *  Given the mapping exists, 

 *  When an account in a 1C District requires SalesSkill-driven Market Segment filtering, 
 *  Then the system applies the mappings created by Admins without exposing edit capabilities to end-users. 
 

 

 
Business Requirements: 

 *  Ops Admins and System Admins must have the ability to: 

 *  Add mappings between Market Segment and SalesSkill. 
 *  Update existing mappings. 
 *  Remove mappings when necessary. 
 

 *  All other roles have read-only access. 
 *  Security model must preserve integrity of Market Segment filtering logic driven by SalesSkill. 
 *  Audit must track who added/removed mappings and when. 
 

 
Developer Notes: 

 *  Create native N:N (many-to-many) relationship between Market Segment and SalesSkill: 

 *  System Admins/Ops Admins get delete permission. 
 

 *  If using a custom intersect entity:  

 *  Only deactivate is allowed, delete not permitted, to maintain audit history.  
 *  Provide permissions for create, read, append, append to, and deactivate.  
 

 *  Ensure audit logging is enabled for mapping create/update/remove events. 
 *  Restrict modification access to admin-facing model-driven apps only (e.g., Ecolab Admin), not business-facing ones. 
 *  Verify that existing field filtering logic on Accounts and Leads respects these mappings post-cutover.

column8: Configure Security for District ? Sales Skill Mapping (Ops Admin & System Admin Manage; Others Read-Only)
column11:
As a CRM System Admin or Ops Admin,
I need the ability to create, update, and remove mappings between Districts and SalesSkills,
 
so that correct associations can be maintained to support the One Customer (1C) model,
 
while ensuring no other business users can modify this master data.
column19: Moved out of state Pending Prod Release
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria:
 
 
 

 *  Given I am a System Admin or Ops Admin or Ops Admin Lead, 

 *  When I access the District ? SalesSkill mapping, 
 *  Then I can add and remove mappings as needed. 
 

 *  Given I am a business user (e.g., AM, DM, CAM, BDM, Sales Rep), 

 *  When I view Districts and their SalesSkill associations, 
 *  Then I can only see the mapping but not modify or delete it. 
 

 

 
Business Requirements: 

 *  Only Ops Admins and System Admins can manage mappings between District and SalesSkill. 
 *  All other roles must have read-only access to this relationship. 
 *  Create, update, and delete permissions are enabled only for System Admins and Ops Admins. 
 *  District ? SalesSkill relationship must remain editable at cutover and ongoing for maintenance. 
 *  Security rules must ensure mappings are not exposed inappropriately via sitemap links for non-admins. 
 

 
Developer Notes: 

 *  Create a native N:N (many-to-many) relationship between District and SalesSkill: 

 *  Provide delete permissions for System Admins/Ops Admins. 
 

 *  If using custom intersect entity for District ? SalesSkill:  

 *  Set permissions to create, read, append, append to, and deactivate only.  
 *  Delete not allowed to preserve audit/history.  
 

 *  Ensure relationship is audited (who added/removed mapping, timestamp). 
 *  Verify that Ops Admin role is configured at BU level, System Admin at global level. 
 *  Restrict modification access to admin model-driven apps only (e.g., Ecolab Admin), not business-facing apps.

column7: 8. Enable Creation and Visibility of Sales Skill Accounts in CRM under a Unified Base Customer Account
column11:
Business Objective:
 
To enable cross-divisional growth and improve enterprise customer visibility, CRM must support the creation and lifecycle management of Sales Skill Accounts (e.g., Water, Hygiene) under a centralized Base Customer Account (BCA). This supports key business workflows where customers may expand relationships across multiple lines of business, such as identifying a Water opportunity for a Hygiene customer. It also ensures future scalability by aligning with the One Customer Initiative’s unified enterprise view and integrating with upstream systems like MDM and ERP.
 

 
Additionally, ERP source system logic must be reviewed and revised to support the new structure. In current-state, Water accounts have NLC_SAP as the ERP system and Hygiene accounts have ECL_EBS. Post-migration, all accounts under a unified BCA will reference the same ERP system, typically ECL_EBS. This may require updates to any validation logic or plugins that rely on ERP system values.
 

 
Business Requirements: 

 *  Users must be able to create a new Sales Skill Account (e.g., Water or Hygiene) and link it to an existing Base Customer Account (BCA) within CRM. 
 *  System should support creation of a standalone Sales Skill Account (e.g., as a Prospect) that may later be linked to a BCA through MDM integration. 
 *  Sales Skill must be explicitly designated at the time of account creation and must remain a required field for all sales skill accounts. 
 *  System must validate during account creation that no duplicate Sales Skill Account exists under the same BCA (based on name, sales skill, and account number). 
 *  If a BCA already exists for a customer, the system should surface that BCA during Sales Skill Account creation to prevent duplicate enterprise records. 
 *  When a Sales Skill Account is created as a Prospect, CRM should auto-identify if a matching BCA already exists (via ERP or MDM data sync) and suggest or auto-link the Prospect accordingly after BCA is created. 
 *  Sales Skill Accounts should be visible through appropriate CRM views, subgrids on the BCA form, and must allow users to filter based on Sales Skill, Account Status, and Ownership. 
 *  Role-based access should control who can create Sales Skill Accounts, particularly restricting the creation of Water and Hygiene accounts to authorized roles only. 
 *  The Sales Skill Account form should offer intuitive guidance and prefill capabilities where applicable (e.g., inherited address data from BCA). 
 *  ERP and MDM integration logic must be updated to: 

 *  Accept new Sales Skill Account records. 
 *  Align account number generation logic with the updated structure. 
 *  Return appropriate metadata (e.g., market segment, sub-segment) based on the Sales Skill and BCA relationship. 
 

 

 

 
Technical Implementation Considerations: 

 *  Sales Skill Account Creation from BCA: 

 *  Users can initiate Sales Skill Account creation from within a BCA form. 
 *  The BCA field should be auto-populated and read-only on the Sales Skill Account form. 
 *  Account Type should default to “Prospect”. 
 *  Sales Skill must be selected (e.g., Water, Hygiene). 
 *  Required fields: Account Name, District, Sales Skill, Account Type. 
 *  The new account will appear in a subgrid on the BCA form. 
 

 *  Creation of Standalone Prospects: 

 *  Users may also create Sales Skill Accounts independently without initially linking to a BCA. 
 *  During MDM processing, if a matching BCA is identified, integration will update the record with the BCA reference. 
 *  BCA field should be set as read-only and only populated through integration in this case. 
 

 *  ERP System Logic Review and Changes: 

 *  Existing logic that sets or validates the ERP System field (source system) must be reviewed. 
 *  Example: A Water account previously associated with NLC_SAP will now reflect ECL_EBS due to its migration under a unified BCA. 
 *  Any plugins, scripts, or workflows that use ERP system value (NLC_SAP, ECL_EBS) for validation must be updated. 
 *  Example: If current plugin logic enforces ERP system uniqueness or mapping rules based on account type or sales skill, those need to be revised to support multiple Sales Skill Accounts sharing the same ERP system and account number. 
 *  ERP system field should reflect the true source system of the customer data and align with the ERP master. 
 

 *  Validation and Business Rules: 

 *  Enforce uniqueness of Sales Skill + Account Number + ERP System. 
 *  Prevent duplicate records for the same Sales Skill and Account Number within the same BCA. 
 *  Ensure the BCA lookup is only visible and applicable to accounts tied to One Customer districts. 
 

 *  Form and Security Behavior: 

 *  BCA lookup field must be displayed as read-only and only visible for One Customer accounts (based on district flag). 
 *  Creation of new Sales Skill Accounts should be restricted to users with appropriate roles (e.g., Sales, DM). 
 *  Use business rules to dynamically show/hide the BCA lookup based on form state, district flag, and account status (create vs update). 
 

 

 
Expected Deliverables: 

 *  Updated CRM forms for Account and BCA with appropriate fields, layouts, and business rules 
 *  Ribbon button or command to initiate creation of Sales Skill Account from BCA 
 *  Modified plugins/scripts related to ERP system logic to support the new shared ERP structure 
 *  Updated integration logic with MDM for BCA mapping and ERP system value updates 
 *  Data dictionary update including BCA field, ERP system behaviors, and sales skill metadata 
 *  Regression test plan for: 
 *  Sales Skill Account creation (linked and standalone) 
 *  ERP system validation 
 *  Account number uniqueness enforcement 
 *  Form visibility and field behaviors

column8: TECHNICAL SPIKE: Investigate best approach for filtering Sales Skill by district (N:N lookup vs. plugin).
column11: As a CRM solution team member, I want to investigate and determine the most effective way to filter the Sales Skill lookup based on the selected District, so that users only see valid Sales Skills for a given District and data integrity is maintained across all channels (UI, imports, API). This spike will compare using an N:N lookup filter against a plugin enforcement approach (and possible combination) to recommend the best approach balancing usability, maintainability, and performance.
column19: Moved out of state Pending PO Review
column22:
*  Identify and document at least two viable approaches: 

 *  Client-side filtered lookup using an N:N relationship between District and Sales Skill. 
 *  Plugin enforcement for server-side validation (with or without lookup filtering). 
 

 *  Provide a pros/cons matrix for each approach, evaluating: 

 *  User experience (ease of selection, responsiveness). 
 *  Performance at expected data volumes. 
 *  Maintainability and complexity. 
 *  Coverage for non-UI data entry (API, imports, Power Automate). 
 

 *  Prototype the OOB filtered lookup approach: 

 *  Filter Sales Skill options based on selected District. 
 *  Disable Sales Skill until District is set. 
 *  Clear Sales Skill if District is cleared or changed. 
 

 *  Prototype plugin enforcement: 

 *  Block save if Sales Skill is not valid for the chosen District. 
 *  Ensure plugin runs for all entry points (form save, API, import). 
 

 *  Determine if a PCF control is required (only if OOB filtering is insufficient). 
 *  Document edge case handling: 

 *  No District set ? Sales Skill disabled. 
 *  District changed ? Sales Skill cleared and re-filtered. 
 *  Invalid values blocked for all save operations. 
 

 *  Recommend a final approach and provide rationale in business-friendly terms. 
 *  Deliver sample FetchXML/Web API query or plugin validation logic for the selected approach.

column8: Technical Spike: Define District ? Sales Skill Mapping Mechanism for 1C Accounts
column11:
As the solution team, we need to determine the best mechanism to maintain and enforce the District–Sales Skill allowed combinations for One Customer (1C) accounts. The mechanism must support real-time UI filtering and server-side save validation (for UI, imports, API/SDK, offline sync). This spike will compare OOTB Dataverse N:N vs custom intersect table and document a clear recommendation, with operating guidance for admins/ops.

 
Objectives 

 *  Identify viable approaches (e.g., OOTB N:N vs custom intersect entity). 
 *  Assess pros/cons for maintainability, governance, and extensibility. 
 *  Confirm each option can support: 

 *  UI filtering of Sales Skill by selected District. 
 *  Server-side validation at save time for 1C accounts. 
 

 *  
 
 *  Define admin/ops ownership and update process for the mapping. 
 *  Produce a single recommended approach with rationale and implementation outline. 
 

 
Deliverables 

 *  Option Comparison Write-Up 

 *  Option A: OOTB N:N relationship between District and Sales Skill. 
 *  Option B: Custom intersect entity (e.g., DistrictSalesSkillMapping). 
 *  For each option, document: 

 *  How UI filtering would be configured. 
 *  How server-side validation would query/verify allowed pairs. 
 *  Governance: who updates, how often, and required privileges. 
 *  Data model impact 
 *  Pros / Cons and known limitations. 
 

 

 *  Recommendation & Implementation Outline 

 *  Chosen approach with clear rationale (why it fits our 1C needs). 
 *  High-level implementation steps for: data model/config, UI filtering, server-side enforcement, and security. 
 *  Next-step backlog items (story titles) to implement the chosen approach.
column22:
*  A written comparison of at least two approaches (OOTB N:N vs custom intersect) is produced. 
 *  A standard error message and maintenance guidance (admin update process, cleanup strategy) are documented. 
 *  A single recommended approach is clearly stated with rationale and high-level implementation outline. 
 *  Follow-up user stories are listed to implement the selected approach (e.g., build mapping, configure filtering, add server validation, admin views/security).

column8: Rename ERP Sales Skill Field to Sales Skill and Align Field Behaviors Across 1C Accounts and Forms
column11:
As a CRM User,
 
I want the “ERP Sales Skill” field to be renamed consistently as “Sales Skill” across all CRM forms, subgrids, and Hub screens, and for the locking behavior and mandatory fields to be consistent across 1C accounts,
 
So that the user experience remains standardized, terminology is consistent across the system, and field behavior is predictable between Hygiene and Water accounts.
 

 
Context and Background: 
During the sprint review with business stakeholders, three key feedback items were identified: 

 *  Rename “ERP Sales Skill” to “Sales Skill” Across CRM and Hub: 

 *  The field currently appears as ERP Sales Skill on the Base Customer Account (BCA) form, Account form, and various subgrid views (Opportunities, DVD Programs, RTW/Lost Business, Value Added Services, Contacts, etc.). 
 *  To align with user terminology and simplify the UI, the label should be updated to “Sales Skill” everywhere it is displayed. 
 

 *  Locations to update include: 

 *  BCA Form: 

 *  Account subgrid – ERP Sales Skill ? Sales Skill 
 *  1C Active Contacts view ? Sales Skill 
 *  1C All Contacts view ? Sales Skill 
 *  Open Opportunities (1C All Open Opportunities view) ? Sales Skill 
 *  Closed Opportunities (1C All Closed Opportunities view) ? Sales Skill 
 *  Won Opportunities (1C All Won Opportunities view) ? Sales Skill 
 *  Lost Opportunities (1C All Lost Opportunities view) ? Sales Skill 
 *  TVD Program Section: Pipeline / In-Process / Completed subgrids ? Sales Skill 
 *  Value Added Services: 1C Active VAS and 1C Inactive VAS ? Sales Skill 
 *  RTW/Lost Business: 1C Active RTW, 1C All RTW, 1C Inactive RTW, Lost Business ? Sales Skill 
 

 *  Account Form: 

 *  Field label ERP Sales Skill ? Sales Skill 
 

 

 *  Subsegment Field Mandatory Logic (Org Accounts):  

 *  On H5 Organization accounts that belong to 1C districts, the Subsegment field is currently mandatory.  
 *  As per business feedback, this field should no longer be mandatory for 1C organization accounts.  
 *  The field should remain visible but optional.  
 

 *  Form Field Locking Consistency Between Water and Hygiene Accounts: 

 *  For 1C customer accounts linked to the same BCA, the Water account form and Hygiene account form should exhibit identical field locking/unlocking behavior. 
 *  Any field locked on the Hygiene account should also be locked on the Water account. 
 *  This should only apply to 1C F&B accounts (for now limited to 1C districts; future expansion to all F&B will be considered separately). 
 *  Non-1C accounts are not impacted by this change.

column8: Establish District-to-Sales Skill Relationship for Dynamic Filtering
column11:
As a CRM administrator or user,
 
I want a predefined relationship between Districts and Sales Skills in CRM,
 
so that Sales Skill choices on One Customer accounts are automatically filtered based on the selected District,
 
ensuring that users can only select valid and business-approved Sales Skills for a given District, and preventing misalignment between account data and organizational sales structure.
 

 
Key points:
 

 *  Relationship type will be many-to-many (N:N), allowing each District to have multiple Sales Skills and each Sales Skill to be used by multiple Districts. 
 *  This mapping will be maintained in CRM as a master data configuration, editable only by System Admin and Ops Admin (or designated admin roles). 
 *  The mapping drives filtering logic whenever the Sales Skill field is presented in the UI — e.g., in account forms, views, and any related creation processes. 
 *  The mapping ensures no invalid Sales Skill can be selected for a District. 
 *  This is the source of truth for downstream validation logic, including defaulting rules based on the logged-in user’s profile.
column19: Moved out of state Pending Prod Release
column22:
*  Relationship Configuration 

 *  CRM must have an OOB N:N relationship between the District entity and the Sales Skill entity. 
 *  The mapping must allow linking multiple Sales Skills to a single District and vice versa. 
 *  The mapping is stored in a configurable table/grid within CRM, accessible only to authorized admin roles (System Admin and Ops Admin). 
 

 *  Filtering Logic 

 *  When a District is selected on an account form: 
 *  The Sales Skill dropdown must show only those Active Sales Skills linked to the selected District through the N:N mapping. 

 *  If an Account is tied to an Inactive Sales Skill Record, it should not get cleared from the Account form 
 

 

 *  When a District is changed on the account form:??? To be determined as part of the Technical SPIKE. Add this to a separate story  

 *  The current Sales Skill value is cleared.  
 *  The dropdown is refreshed to show only the Sales Skills linked to the new District.  
 

 *  Data Integrity  

 *  It must be impossible (UI or API) to save a One Customer account with a Sales Skill that is not linked to the selected District.  
 *  The relationship mapping should be validated during data migration and cutover to ensure only valid District–Sales Skill combinations exist in migrated accounts.  
 

 *  Security & Permissions 

 *  Only Ops Admins and System Admins can create, edit, or remove District–Sales Skill mappings. 
 *  Business users can view mappings but cannot edit them. 
 

 *  Performance & Integration Considerations  

 *  Filtering must occur in real-time without noticeable delay for end users when selecting a District.  
 *  The mapping should be available for integration endpoints that require validation or transformation of District–Sales Skill relationships. 
 

 

Developer Notes: 

 *  OOB N:N relationship between District and Sales Skill. 
 *  Form Logic 

 *  Apply onChange event on the District field to trigger the filtering logic for Sales Skill. 
 *  If no District selected, keep Sales Skill field hidden. 
 *  On District selection, fetch allowed Sales Skill from the mapping table and filter the drop-down list. 
 

 *  Defaulting 

 *  Default the Sales Skill from User record on Account record if District 1C flag is true. 
 *  Lock the field for editing 
 

 *  Backward Compatibility 

 *  Do not remove existing District ? Global Business logic; scope is limited to One Customer accounts flagged as Yes.

column8: Default and Manage Sales Skill Selection for One Customer Accounts
column11:
As a CRM user creating or updating a One Customer account,
I want the Sales Skill field to default intelligently based on my user profile and selected district,
 
So that the correct Sales Skill is always assigned efficiently and consistently, without invalid selections.

 

 
Key points:
 

 *  The mapping between Districts and Sales Skills is preconfigured in the system. 
 *  If the user has a Sales Skill assigned in their profile, it will default when creating an account. 
 *  The Sales Skill field is disabled until a District is selected. 
 *  When the District is changed, the Sales Skill is cleared and: 

 *  If the user profile has a default Sales Skill that is valid for the selected District, it is automatically re-populated. 
 *  If no default exists, the field remains blank for manual selection from the District’s allowed list. 
 

 *  Sales Skill is mandatory for saving a One Customer account. 
 *  Filtering ensures only valid Sales Skills are available — no invalid selection scenarios or error messages are required. 
 

 

 
Business Requirements:

 *  The mapping between District and Sales Skill must be pre-configured in CRM. 
 *  For One Customer accounts: 

 *  Sales Skill is mandatory before save. 
 *  Sales Skill is disabled until a district is selected. 
 

 *  When District changes, Sales Skill is cleared and re-validated against profile defaults. 
 *  When Primary Owner changes, Sales Skill re-defaults based on the new owner profile. 
 *  If only one valid Sales Skill exists for a district, auto-populate and lock it. 
 *  No error popups are required—only filtered dropdowns and defaults should guide users. 
 *  Applies only for One Customer = Yes accounts; no changes for non-1C accounts.

column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria:
 
 

 *  Defaulting Behavior – Global Create 

 *  Given I am a CRM user creating a new account using the Global Create option, 

 *  When I select a district for a One Customer account, 
 *  Then the Sales Skill field is displayed on the quick create form. 
 *  And if my user profile has a default Sales Skill valid for the selected district, it defaults and is locked for editing. 
 *  And if my profile does not have a valid default, the Sales Skill field remains blank but must be chosen from the filtered list of active Sales Skills mapped to that district. 
 

 

 *  Defaulting Behavior – New Account Button 

 *  Given I am a CRM user creating a new account using the New Account form, 

 *  When I select a district, 
 *  Then if my profile has a default Sales Skill valid for that district, it defaults automatically. 
 *  And the default value is locked . 
 *  And if I change the Primary Owner to another user, the Sales Skill should re-evaluate based on that new owner’s profile defaults.  
 *  If the new Primary Owner has no default Sales Skill aligned, the Sales Skill becomes blank and must be entered manually before saving.  
 

 

 *  Enablement and Filtering 

 *  Given the Sales Skill field is empty, 

 *  When I have not yet selected a district, 
 *  Then the Sales Skill field should be disabled. 
 *  And once a district is selected, the Sales Skill drop-down populates only with active Sales Skills mapped to that district. 
 *  And if there is exactly one valid Sales Skill for that district, and no profile default exists, it should auto-populate and lock. 
 

 

 *  District Change Handling 

 *  Given a Sales Skill is already populated for an account, 

 *  When the District field is changed, 
 *  Then the Sales Skill field is cleared. 
 *  And if the user profile has a valid Sales Skill for the new district, it should repopulate automatically. 
 *  Else it remains blank until manually selected. 
 

 

 *  Mandatory Requirement 

 *  Given I am creating or updating a One Customer account, 

 *  When I attempt to save, 
 *  Then the system must validate that a Sales Skill is populated. 
 *  Else the record cannot be saved. 
 

 

 

 
 

 

 
 
Developer Notes:

 *  Sales Skill field must be added to both Global Quick Create and Account Main Form. 
 *  Form Logic: 

 *  Use onChange event on District field to trigger filtering and defaulting logic. 
 *  Use onChange event on Primary Owner to re-evaluate defaults. 
 *  Disable Sales Skill until District is selected. 
 

 *  Filtering Logic: 

 *  Pull allowed Sales Skills for the selected district from the District–Sales Skill mapping table. 
 *  If multiple valid options exist, show dropdown. 
 *  If exactly one valid option exists and no profile default, auto-populate and lock. 
 

 *  Defaulting Logic: 

 *  Query logged-in user’s profile Sales Skill. 
 *  If it is valid for the selected district, apply it (locked in Global Create; editable in New Account). 
 *  If invalid, leave blank and require manual input. 
 

 *  Save Validation: 

 *  Prevent save if Sales Skill is blank for One Customer accounts. 
 

 *  Open Question for Business: 

 *  Should defaulted Sales Skill on the New Account form also be locked (like in Global Create) or remain editable?

column8: Ability to store and manage a list of Sales Skills (e.g., Water, Hygiene) in CRM for One Customer accounts.
column11:
As part of the One Customer initiative, CRM must store a master list of Sales Skills (e.g., Water, Hygiene) that can be used to categorize accounts under the unified Base Customer Account (BCA) model.
 

 
A dedicated Sales Skill table will be created in CRM to store this information in a structured way, ensuring flexibility for future expansion (e.g., adding new skills or sub-skills without development). 

 
Each Sales Skill record should contain:
 

 *  Sales Skill Name (user-friendly, e.g., “Water”) – visible to end users. 
 *  Description (optional) – for internal clarification. 
 *  ERP Sales Skill Code (e.g., EBS or ERP code) – used for integration and mapping. 
 *  Status (Active/Inactive) – to control availability in dropdowns without deleting historical data. 
 *  Global Business – mandatory field visible to users and set during record creation; used for downstream processes. 
 

 
Ownership & Maintenance: 

 *  The Ops Admin team (to be confirmed) will be responsible for adding or editing Sales Skill records. 
 *  Other CRM users will have read-only access to this table — they can select Sales Skills when creating or editing accounts but cannot modify the master list. 
 *  Sales Skills will appear in account creation and edit screens for One Customer accounts only. 
 

 
Security & Governance: 

 *  Ensure that only designated roles (Ops Admin or equivalent) have create/edit/delete permissions for the Sales Skill table. 
 *  All other roles have view-only access to prevent accidental data changes. 
 *  Any change in the Sales Skill table should be audited (e.g., who made the change, date, what was changed). 
 

 
This design ensures that: 

 *  Sales Skills are consistent across all accounts. 
 *  Dropdown lists are automatically filtered by “Active” status. 
 *  Global Business values are user-set and always provided.
column19: Moved out of state Pending Prod Release
column22:
*  Sales Skill Table Creation 

 *  A dedicated Organization Owned Sales Skill table exists in CRM. 
 *  The table includes the following fields: (Org Owned Entity) 

 *  Sales Skill Name (required, text, user-friendly) 
 *  ERP Sales Skill Code (Required)
 
 *  Description (optional, text) 
 *  Global Business (required, visible to users, option set as per existing CRM configuration)
 
 *  Status (Active/Inactive) 
 

 

 *  Security & Access Control 

 *  Only users in the designated System Admin role can create, edit, or deactivate Sales Skill records. 
 *  All other CRM users have read-only access to the Sales Skill table through the 1C security role 

 *  Ecolab -1C - UASR  
 *  Ecolab -1C - TASR
 
 

 *  Permissions are applied at the table level to ensure compliance. 
 

 *  Sales Skill table to be made visible on the Ecolab Admin App (Near Districts). 

 *  Visibility in site map to be controlled based on security role 
 

 *  Data Integrity & Availability 

 *  Sales Skill Name must be unique. 
 *  Global Business mapping is mandatory and must be visible on the form when creating or editing a Sales Skill. 
 *  Inactive Sales Skills remain in the system for historical reporting but are hidden from selection dropdowns. 
 

 *  User Experience (Move it to the Account User Story)  

 *  When creating or editing an account, the Sales Skill dropdown displays only Active Sales Skills.  
 *  The dropdown shows user-friendly names only (no EBS codes).  
 *  The Sales Skill field appears for One Customer accounts only, as defined by the “1C” flag or equivalent logic.  
 *  Global Business field is visible and required when creating or editing Sales Skill records.  
 

 *  Audit & Tracking 

 *  All changes to the Sales Skill table (additions, edits, deactivations) are logged with: 
 *  User who made the change. 
 *  Date and time of change. 
 *  Fields modified. 
 

 *  Integration Readiness 

 *  ERP Sales Skill Code field is available for integration mapping but remains hidden from standard CRM views and forms.   
 *  Data is stored in a way that supports linking Sales Skills to Districts, Global Business, and Accounts. 
 

 *  Validation Rules 

 *  Prevent duplicate Sales Skill Names and ERP Sales Skill Code . 
 *  Prevent saving a Sales Skill without selecting a Global Business. 
 

 *  Standard OOB Views should have all the fields on the Sales Skill table 

 *  Quick Find Views 
 *  Lookup Views 
 *  Active Sales Skill View 
 *  Inactive Sales Skill View

column7: 7. Validate and Correct Master Data for Existing CRM Accounts Prior to One Customer Cutover
column11:
Business Capability:
 
To ensure a successful One Customer go-live, business requires that all existing CRM accounts impacted by the F&B United (FBU) program are properly aligned with the latest master data structure. This includes: 

 *  Sales Org and District Alignment: 

 *  All Hygiene and Water Sales Skill Accounts must reflect consistent and updated territory, district, and sales org assignments per the new aligned structure. This is essential for downstream ownership, routing, and reporting. 
 

 *  User Role and Sales Skill Assignment: 

 *  CRM Users must be updated with the correct primary sales skill (either Water or Hygiene) to support segmentation, logic execution, and form behavior in the new CRM design. 
 

 *  District Flag for One Customer Accounts: 

 *  Districts supporting One Customer program must be flagged appropriately (e.g., One Customer Flag = Yes). This will support CRM form logic for displaying BCA-related fields and restrict changes where necessary. 
 

 *  Market Segment and Sub-Segment Cleanup: 

 *  The business has initiated a data rationalization effort to clean up outdated or “other” categories in MDM. CRM must reflect: 

 *  Aligned naming conventions for Market Segment and Sub-Segment 
 *  Elimination of obsolete or duplicate entries 
 *  Controlled updates to ensure non-FBU divisions (80% of accounts) remain unaffected 
 

 

 *  Manual Cleanup Now, Automation Later: 

 *  As of now, the cleanup will be a manual one-time update performed before cutover. However, business has requested future automation of market segment/sub-segment updates from MDM, which will be added to the default backlog. 
 

 

 
Technical Implementation Considerations: 

 *  Territory, District, and Sales Org Updates: 

 *  Validate all FBU Sales Skill Accounts to ensure that their districts and sales orgs align with the latest data from the territory management team. 
 *  If discrepancies are found, update CRM manually or through data repair tools. 
 *  Cross-check with the weekly load process—if it has already handled the update, validate and mark as complete. 
 

 *  District Flag Setup: 

 *  Update relevant district records in CRM with the new “One Customer” flag (Yes/No) based on the districts participating in FBU rollout. 
 *  This flag will drive downstream visibility logic (e.g., when to show BCA field on forms). 
 

 *  CRM User Updates: 

 *  Assign Primary Sales Skill (Water or Hygiene) to CRM user records to support new logic for account creation, record defaults, and access. 
 *  Ensure proper auditing and visibility of this new field. 
 

 *  Market Segment/Sub-Segment Cleanup: 

 *  Review values in CRM for Market Segment and Sub-Segment fields. 
 *  Align the data with the latest values provided by MDM and the business. 
 *  For changed naming conventions: 

 *  Avoid overwriting legacy values unless agreed. 
 *  Update affected accounts using data import or script-based data correction. 
 *  Protect accounts not under FBU scope. 
 

 *  This is expected to be a manual one-time update for Canada. Future automation will be explored but is not part of the immediate scope. 
 

 *  Testing and Regression: 

 *  Regression testing will be required to ensure: 
 *  No negative impact on existing CRM logic tied to territory, district, or market segmentation. 
 *  Reports and views pulling market segments/sub-segments remain valid. 
 *  One Customer–specific logic activates only when relevant fields are flagged. 
 

 

 
Deliverables: 

 *  Verified and corrected Territory/District/Sales Org assignments for all CRM accounts impacted by FBU. 
 *  Updated CRM User records with Primary Sales Skill values. 
 *  District records updated with One Customer flags. 
 *  Cleaned-up Market Segment and Sub-Segment values, aligned with MDM guidance. 
 *  Documentation of all manual updates performed and data governance logs maintained. 
 *  Default backlog item created for future automation of segment/sub-segment population via MDM. 
 *  Regression test scripts for impacted forms, views, workflows, and integrations.

column8: Technical Spike: Redesign Market Segment Filtering for 1C Districts
column11:
As a system designer,
I want to investigate alternative approaches for decoupling the current market segment filtering from the global business field
 
so that 1C districts use a sales skill–driven market segment filtering model that avoids unnecessary exposure of non-relevant Nalco Water records.
column19: Moved out of state Pending PO Review
column22:
Scope / Objectives of the Spike

 *  Analyze the current dependency where the Market Segment table uses the Global Business multi-select option set. 
 *  Identify risks of simply merging Water into Hygiene (e.g., unintended exposure of the entire Nalco Water catalog instead of only Food & Beverage). 
 *  Explore potential design strategies, including: 

 *  Creating a direct N-to-N relationship between Market Segment and Sales Skill 
 *  Using a mapping (intersection) table for flexibility and scalability 
 *  Evaluating if native Dynamics 365 N-to-N relationships or custom mapping tables are better suited 
 

 *  Confirm how the Global Business field should be set behind the scenes when a Sales Skill is selected. 
 *  Define how filtering should behave in 1C districts (based on sales skill) vs. non-1C districts (continue current logic). 
 

Expected Outputs / Deliverables

 *  A documented recommended design approach for filtering Market Segments in 1C districts (N-to-N relationship vs. mapping table). 
 *  A clear decision on how the Global Business field will be managed under the new design. 
 *  A sample data model diagram (or pseudo-model) showing the proposed Market Segment ? Sales Skill linkage. 
 *  A summary of pros/cons for each approach evaluated. 
 *  Follow-up user stories to be created from the spike outcome: 

 *  Build functionality for sales skill–driven Market Segment filtering 
 *  Populate and validate the Sales Skill–Market Segment mapping table as part of master data setup

column8: Establish Relationship Between Market Segment and Sales Skill for Dynamic Filtering
column11:
As a CRM user creating or updating a One Customer account,
I want the Market Segment field to dynamically filter its values based on the selected Sales Skill,
 
So that the correct Market Segment is always available for selection and not incorrectly driven by the outdated Global Business logic.
column19: Moved out of state Pending Prod Release
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria:
 
 
 

 *  Dynamic Filtering by Sales Skill 

 *  Given I am creating or updating a One Customer account, 
 *  When I select a valid Sales Skill, 
 *  Then the Market Segment field should display only the Market Segments linked to that Sales Skill that are related using N:N relationship. via the new mapping table. 
 

 *  Blank Until Sales Skill Selection 

 *  Given no Sales Skill has been selected, 
 *  Then the Market Segment field should remain disabled/blank, preventing premature selection. 
 

 *  Multiple Sales Skills (Water & Hygiene)  

 *  Given a Base Customer Account has both a Water Sales Skill account and a Hygiene Sales Skill account linked,  
 *  When I am creating a new account under the same BCA,  
 *  Then the Market Segment options should still filter correctly based on whichever Sales Skill I choose on that new record.  
 

 *  Validation Requirement 

 *  Given I attempt to save a One Customer account, 
 *  When no Market Segment is selected, 
 *  Then the system should prevent save and prompt the user to select from the filtered list. 
 

 *  Non-1C Accounts 

 *  Given I am creating a non-One Customer account, 
 *  Then the current behavior (filtering based on Global Business) should continue without change. 
 

 

 
Business Requirements: 

 *  New Mapping Table  

 *  Create a new custom intersect table Market Segment ? Sales Skill.  
 *  Fields include:  

 *  Sales Skill (lookup to Sales Skill table)  
 *  Market Segment (lookup to Market Segment table)  
 *  Status (Active/Inactive)  
 *  Created/Modified metadata  
 

 

 *  New OOB N:N relationship between Market Segment and Sales Skill 
 *  Filtering Logic 

 *  Market Segment field must be dynamically filtered based on the selected Sales Skill. 
 *  Global Business should no longer be the driver for filtering in One Customer accounts. 
 

 *  Applicability 

 *  Applies only to One Customer = Yes accounts. 
 *  Non-1C accounts continue with existing Global Business ? Market Segment dependency. 
 

 *  Mandatory Behavior 

 *  Market Segment must be populated before save on One Customer accounts. 
 

 *  Security & Maintenance 

 *  Sales Ops or designated admins should be able to associate and disassociate records. maintain the new mapping table (create, edit, deactivate). 
 *  Field-level security not required beyond standard role-based access. 
 

 

 
Developer Notes: 

 *  Create a OOB N:N relationship 
 *  Custom Intersect Table  

 *  Build a new many-to-many relationship between Market Segment and Sales Skill using a custom intersect table.  
 *  Use OOB or custom lookup controls to maintain referential integrity.  
 

 *  Form Logic 

 *  Apply onChange event on the Sales Skill field to trigger the filtering logic for Market Segment. 
 *  If no Sales Skill selected, keep Market Segment disabled. 
 *  On Sales Skill selection, fetch allowed Market Segments from the mapping table and filter the drop-down list. 
 

 *  Defaulting 

 *  No auto-default for Market Segment in this story; only filtering. 
 *  If only one valid Market Segment exists for the selected Sales Skill, auto-populate and lock the field. 
 

 *  Backward Compatibility 

 *  Do not remove existing Global Business ? Market Segment logic; scope is limited to One Customer accounts flagged as Yes. 
 

 *  Future Enhancements  

 *  Once Global Business is fully deprecated, evaluate decommissioning its role in filtering.

column8: DC: Update Master Data Relationships for PAC Codes, Technology Platforms, Applications, and Units
column11:
As a data conversion and master data analyst,
I need to update and align the master data relationships for PAC Codes, Technology Platforms, Applications, and Units across the Water and Hygiene divisions,
 
so that the opportunity-related filtering logic continues to function correctly under the One Customer model, where all Water and Hygiene accounts are harmonized under a unified Food & Beverage market segment.
 

 
Background & Rationale 
In the current CRM model: 

 *  For Nalco Water accounts, the fields PAC Code, Technology Platform, Application, and Unit are filtered based on the Market Segment selected on the Account record. 
 *  Example: When a user selects a Market Segment “FB” (Food & Beverage under Water), the related lookup values in these dependent fields are restricted to those mapped under FB. 
 

 
With the One Customer transformation, all Water and Hygiene customer accounts will align under the unified Food & Beverage Market Segment structure in CRM. 
This means that:
 

 *  The Water market segments (e.g., “FB – Water”) will be mapped or merged to the corresponding Hygiene market segments (e.g., “Food – Hygiene”). 
 *  To preserve functional continuity and prevent loss of dependent lookups, the relationships between the Water-side Market Segments and their related PAC Codes, Technology Platforms, Applications, and Units must be replicated and linked to the new or corresponding Hygiene-side Market Segments. 
 

 
This ensures that all valid master data relationships continue to function when users create opportunities under the harmonized Food & Beverage market. 

 
Scope
This update applies to: 

 *  Master Data entities: 

 *  PAC Code 
 *  Technology Platform 
 *  Application 
 *  Unit 
 

 *  Reference entity: Market Segment (Hygiene and Water) 
 *  Modules impacted: Opportunities, Master Data Tables, and Filtering Logic in CRM.
column19: Moved out of state Pending Prod Release
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria
 

 *  Scenario 1 – Market Segment Mapping Dependency 

 *  Given that Water and Hygiene Market Segments are to be harmonized under the One Customer initiative,  
 *  When the business provides a final mapping file of existing Water Market Segments and their equivalent Hygiene Market Segments,  
 *  Then the  master data update process must use this mapping as the reference for replicating all related records.  
 *  Create a script/package to configure the below relationship for Hygiene market segments. 
 

 *  Scenario 2 – PAC Code Relationship Alignment 

 *  Given a Water Market Segment and its mapped Hygiene Market Segment, 
 *  When PAC Codes are linked to the Water Market Segment in the PAC–Market Segment relationship table, 
 *  Then identical links must be created between the same PAC Codes and the Hygiene Market Segment, 
 *  And no existing PAC–Water relationships should be deleted or modified. 
 

 *  Scenario 3 – Technology Platform Relationship Alignment 

 *  Given existing Technology Platform records linked to Water Market Segments, 
 *  When equivalent Hygiene Market Segments are identified, 
 *  Then all corresponding relationships between Technology Platforms and Hygiene Market Segments must be created, 
 *  And if duplicate relationships already exist, the process must skip creation without error. 
 

 *  Scenario 4 – Application Relationship Alignment 

 *  Given that Applications are linked to Market Segments, 
 *  When new Hygiene Market Segments are created or mapped, 
 *  Then the Application–Market Segment relationships that exist for the Water versions must be cloned to the Hygiene versions. 
 *  And the relationships must maintain identical reference integrity (e.g., Application ID, Market Segment ID). 
 

 *  Scenario 5 – Unit Relationship Alignment 

 *  Given that Units (used for opportunity metrics) are also tied to Market Segments, 
 *  When One Customer market harmonization occurs, 
 *  Then all Unit–Market Segment relationships for Water segments must be copied to their Hygiene equivalents, 
 *  And verified to ensure no duplicate entries or data loss. 
 

 


 
 

 
Dependencies

 *  Business Dependency: 

 *  Business team must provide final mapping between Water and Hygiene Market Segments. 
 *  Format: Water Market Segment | Hygiene Market Segment | Description. 
 

 *  Sequence Dependency: 

 *  Market Segment mapping must be finalized before executing master data updates. 
 *  Opportunity-related filtering logic should be regression-tested post-update.

column9: Design SSIS Package for Market Segment Mapping Dependency

column11:
User Story- 859809
 
 
Scenario 1 – PAC Code Relationship Alignment 
Precondition: A Water Market Segment and its mapped Hygiene Market Segment 

 *  Verify the PAC Codes are linked to the Water Market Segment in the PAC–Market Segment relationship table 
 *  Ensure identical links created between the same PAC Codes and the Hygiene Market Segment 
 *  Ensure existing PAC–Water relationships is deleted or modified.  
 

Scenario 2 – Technology Platform Relationship Alignment 
Precondition: Existing Technology Platform records linked to Water Market Segments. 

 *  Verify equivalent hygiene market segments are identified. 
 *  Ensure all corresponding relationships between Technology Platforms and Hygiene Market Segments are created 
 *  Verify if duplicate relationships already exist, if it exists the process must skip creation without error. 
 

Scenario 3 – Application Relationship Alignment 
Precondition: Applications are linked to Market Segments 

 *  Ensure new Hygiene Market Segments are created or mapped 
 *  Verify the Application–Market Segment relationships that exist for the Water versions must be cloned to the Hygiene versions. 
 *  Validate relationships maintains identical reference integrity (e.g., Application ID, Market Segment ID). 
 

Scenario 4 – Unit Relationship Alignment 
Precondition: Units (used for opportunity metrics) are also tied to Market Segments 

 *  One Customer market harmonization occurs 
 *  Ensure all Unit–Market Segment relationships for Water segments must be copied to their Hygiene equivalents 
 *  Verify to ensure no duplicate entries or data loss
Ensuring cohesive interaction and data flow between applications to support seamless business processes and system efficiency.

column8: DC - Apply One Customer Flag to All Districts at Cutover and Associate Hygiene and Water Sales Skills to All 1C Districts
column11:
As a system,
I want to update all district records with the correct One Customer flag during cutover
 
so that all districts are consistently flagged as either Yes or No, with no nulls, ensuring data integrity and readiness for One Customer enablement.

 
As a system,
 
I want to assign both Water and Hygiene sales skills to every district flagged as 1C during cutover
 
so that all 1C districts are consistently enabled for both sales skills and ready for the One Customer model.
column19: Moved out of state In QA
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria: 

 *  Given a district is identified as a 1C district in the business-approved list 

 *  When the cutover process is executed 
 *  Then the One Customer flag on that district is updated to Yes 
 

 *  Given a district is not identified as a 1C district 

 *  When the cutover process is executed 
 *  Then the One Customer flag on that district is not updated 
 

 

 *  Given the cutover updates are applied 

 *  When results are compared against the business-approved 1C district list 
 *  Then the Yes values on districts must align exactly with the approved list 
 

 *  Given a district is flagged as 1C in the business-approved list 

 *  When the cutover process is executed 
 *  Then both Water and Hygiene sales skills must be associated with that district 
 

 *  Given a district is not flagged as 1C 

 *  When the cutover process is executed 
 *  Then no additional sales skills (Water or Hygiene) should be assigned to that district 
 

 *  Given the cutover has completed  

 *  When validation checks are performed  
 *  Then all 1C districts must show both Water and Hygiene sales skills in the district-to-sales skill mapping table  
 

 *  Given the cutover updates are applied  

 *  When results are compared against the business-approved 1C district list  
 *  Then each flagged district must reflect exactly two sales skill associations: Water and Hygiene 
 

 

 

 *

column8: CRM: Add ERP Market Code and ERP Sub-Market Code Fields and Populate Values on Market Segment & Sub-Segment Tables
column11:
As a CRM analyst, I want to store ERP Market Codes and ERP Sub-Market Codes on the Market Segment and Sub-Segment tables so that CRM can send stable, code-based values to MDM and avoid issues caused by text description changes.

 
Today CRM only stores market segment name and sub-segment name (text). MDM requires both the numeric codes and the descriptions.
 
To support this:
 

 *  Add a new field ECL_ERPCode on the Market Segment table to store the ERP Market Code 
 *  Add a new field ECL_ERPCode on the Sub-Segment table to store the ERP Sub-Market Code 
 *  Populate these new fields using the mapping spreadsheet shared by the business/MDM team 
 *  Only F&B segments/sub-segments currently require values; all other segments will keep the field blank until future phases 
 *  These codes will be used by integrations going forward instead of relying solely on descriptions

column8: Create Sales Skill Field on User Record
column11:
As a business user,
I need a Default Sales Skill lookup field to appear on my User record when a 1C District is selected,
 
so that I can optionally associate myself with a relevant Sales Skill when working in a One Customer context.
column19: Moved out of state Pending Prod Release
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria:
 
 
 

 *  Given a User record where no District is yet selected, 

 *  When the form loads, 
 *  Then the Sales Skill field should remain hidden and locked. 
 

 *  Given a District is selected on a User record and the District is flagged as a 1C District, 

 *  When the record loads or the District value is updated, 
 *  Then the Sales Skill field should become visible and editable for the user to optionally select a Sales Skill. 
 

 *  Given a District is selected on a User record and the District is not a 1C District, 

 *  When the record loads or the District value is updated, 
 *  Then the Sales Skill field should remain hidden and locked. 
 

 *  Given a Ops Admin selects a Sales Skill from the lookup field, 

 *  When the record is saved, 
 *  Then the selected value should be stored and persist on the User record. 
 

 *  Given a Ops Admin can choose to not set Sales Skill on a user aligned with 1C district , 
 *  Always derive the Sales Skill from the Primary Owner field on the Account.  
 

 
Business Requirements: 

 *  Add a new field on the User entity called Sales Skill (lookup to Sales Skill table). 
 *  Position the field directly below the District field on the User form. 
 *  Field visibility and editability rules: 

 *  If District = 1C District ? show + editable. 
 *  If District = non-1C District ? hidden + locked. 
 *  If no District selected ? hidden + locked. 
 

 *  The Default Sales Skill field must allow only business-approved Sales Skill values. 
 *  Field should be optional — users may save without selecting a value. 
 *  All logic for determining Sales Skill on Accounts is handled in other stories; this story only governs User record field behavior. 
 *  Business must be able to review the field behavior in both 1C and non-1C district scenarios before cutover. 
 

 
Developer Notes: 

 *  Implement using business rules or form scripting for field visibility/editability logic tied to District selection. 
 *  Ensure this new field is added as a Business Recommended field  
 *  Ensure District field lookups reliably indicate whether a District is flagged as 1C (may require referencing metadata or a flag on the District table). 
 *  Validate performance: field visibility should toggle dynamically on form load and on District change without requiring a save/refresh. 
 *  Regression test User form to ensure no conflicts with existing customizations or JavaScript. 
 *  Ensure lookup field filters to active Sales Skill records only. 
 *  This story is only about User record configuration; do not duplicate Sales Skill-to-Account determination logic here. 
 *  Audit logging: changes to Default Sales Skill on User record should be tracked in audit history.

Scenario 1B - Validate Sales Skill field on user record Given District is selected and the District is 1C District 

 *  Log into NW Ops admin role

 *  Go to the user's tab and open any user record where the district field is blank /create new user

Scenario 2:  Validate Sales Skill field on user record. Given District is select and District is non -1C District 

 

 *  Log into NW Ops admin role 
 *  Take any district where Is Eligible for One Customer field is No or blank 
 *  Go to the users tab and open any user record where the district field is blank 
 *  Sales skill field should hidden and locked  
 *  Sales skill should not be visible under district field in user form 
 

Scenario 3- Validate Sales Skill visibility field on User record where no District is yet selected 
 

 *  Log in to the NW Ops admin role 
 *  Take any user where the district field value is not selected 
 *  The sales skill field should be hidden and locked  
 *  Sales skill should not be visible under district field in user record if no district is selected 
 

Scenario 4- Ops Admin should be able to save user form without selecting sales skill field value 

 *  Open any user record with district select and district should be 1C District. 
 *  Sales skill should be visible under the district field  
 *  Don't select value in the sales skill field and save the user record by making other updates 
 *  Ops admin should be able to save the record without sales skill field also. 
 

Combinations - 
 

 *  If District = 1C District ? show + non-mandatory + editable. 
 *  If District = non-1C District ? hidden. 
 *  If no District selected ? hidden.

column8: Cleanup and Align Market Segment and Sub-Segment Values
column11:
As a business user,
I need obsolete or unused Market Segment and Sub-Segment values to be cleaned up and deactivated,
 
so that the CRM only reflects approved, business-relevant segment options going forward.
 

 
As a system,
 
I need to deactivate obsolete Market Segment and Sub-Segment values while retaining historical integrity for older accounts that still reference them,
 
so that reporting and data history are not lost, while ensuring new account setups use only business-approved values.

 
Business Requirements: 

 *  Validate the Hygiene Sub-Segment domain and retain only values approved by business stakeholders. 
 *  Add new Water Sub-Segment values approved by the business to ensure alignment with the One Customer model. 
 *  Deactivate all obsolete or unused Market Segment and Sub-Segment values so they are no longer available for new record creation. 
 *  Ensure historical data integrity is preserved — existing accounts with obsolete values should remain unchanged. 
 *  Confirm that deactivated values are excluded from CRM dropdowns, lookups, and user forms. 
 *  Document the list of cleaned-up and added values for business sign-off.
column19: Moved out of state In Development
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria: 

 *  Given new business-approved Market Segment and Sub-Segment values are identified for Water and Hygiene, 

 *  When the updates is executed, 
 *  I need to assign Sales Skills to the Market Segments, so that the the market segments are aligned with either Hygiene or Water Sales Skill 
 

 *  Given the Hygiene Market Segment and Sub-Segment domain requires validation, 

 *  When the updates are executed, 
 *  Then only business-approved Hygiene Market Segment and Sub-Segments should remain active. 
 

 *  Given obsolete Market Segment or Sub-Segment values exist in CRM for FBU, 

 *  When the update process is executed, 
 *  Then those values should be deactivated (not deleted) and unavailable for new record creation. 
 

 *  Given an existing account is already tagged with an obsolete Market Segment or Sub-Segment,  

 *  When the update process is executed,  
 *  Then the account should still retain its historical value, with no data loss.  
 

 

 

 

 

 
Developer Notes: 

 *  Use status = inactive (or equivalent deactivation) rather than deleting values, to preserve history. 
 *  Ensure lookup filtering respects active-only values for new record creation. 
 *  Regression test account forms, advanced find queries, and reports to confirm obsolete values no longer appear in picklists. 
 *  Validate impact on integrations (e.g., Snowflake, reporting pipelines) — confirm inactive values do not break sync or downstream reporting. 
 *  Add appropriate audit logging or annotation in CRM configuration to record which values were deactivated/added and when. 
 *  Ensure unit tests validate that historical records still load correctly with inactive values.
