column6: Display Sales Skill in Subgrid Views on Parent/Ultimate Parent Account
column11: As a CRM user, I want to view Sales Skill information in subgrid views of existing account records when displayed under Parent Accounts, so that I can easily distinguish between Water and Hygiene account types without disrupting the existing My Accounts, My Team, and All Accounts views.
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria: 

 *  Given I am a Corporate Account Manager (CAM) 

 *  When I open a Parent Account record 
 *  Then in the Accounts subgrid I should see the Sales Skill column alongside Account Name and Account Number so I can distinguish Water vs. Hygiene accounts. 
 

 *  Given I am a Corporate Account Manager (CAM) 

 *  When I open My Accounts, My Team Accounts, or All Accounts views 
 *  Then I should see no changes to these views (no Sales Skill column added, no BCA link) to avoid disrupting established workflows. 
 

 *  Given I am a District Manager (DM) viewing a Base Customer Account (BCA) 

 *  When I open the Accounts/Contacts/Opportunities/TVD/RTW Lost Business subgrids 
 *  Then I should see the Sales Skill column consistently displayed for related accounts to distinguish Water vs. Hygiene. 
 

 

 
Business Requirements

 *  Display the Sales Skill column in subgrid views under Parent Accounts to support CAMs. 
 *  Display the Sales Skill column in subgrid views under Base Customer Account (BCA) records to support DMs. 
 *  Ensure that My Accounts, My Team Accounts, and All Accounts views remain unchanged to avoid retraining or workflow disruption (80% of accounts are not One Customer). 
 *  Ensure consistent visibility of Sales Skill across both One Customer and non–One Customer accounts in subgrids. 
 *  Support clear differentiation between Water and Hygiene accounts at both BCA and Parent/Ultimate Parent levels. 
 


 
 
Developer Notes: 

 *  Entities/Tables Impacted: 

 *  Account (subgrid views under Parent Account, Ultimate Parent Account, and BCA forms). 
 

 *  Views Impacted: 

 *  Subgrid views on Parent Account form (related accounts). 
 *  All Subgrid views on Base Customer Account form  
 

 *  Excluded Views (No Change): 

 *  My Accounts 
 *  My Team Accounts 
 *  All Accounts 
 

 *  Column Placement: 

 *  Add Sales Skill after Account Name and Account Number. 
 *  Ensure consistency across all impacted subgrids. 
 

 *  Sorting/Filtering: 

 *  Support sorting/grouping by Account Name, Account Number, and Sales Skill. 
 

 *  Security/Access: 

 *  No change in permissions—users only see accounts they are already authorized to view. 
 

 *  Regression Testing: 

 *  Validate that My Accounts, My Team Accounts, and All Accounts views remain unchanged. 
 *  Confirm subgrid views correctly display Sales Skill values for both One Customer and non–One Customer accounts.

column6: Display and Enforce Technology Platform Field on H5 Opportunities (1C Only and Water Sales Skill Only)
column11:
As a CAM,
I want the Technology Platform field to be displayed on H5 Opportunity forms and enforced during the Develop stage for Water sales skill opportunities,
 
So that Water opportunities capture the critical technology platform information needed for accurate reporting, pipeline tracking, and alignment with current Water business practices.
 

 
This story ensures:
 

 *  Technology Platform appears on the Develop section of the Opportunity form. 
 *  Technology Platform appears alongside Innovation Growth in the Develop stage of the BPF. 
 *  For Water sales skill opportunities ? Technology Platform must be filled before progressing past the Develop stage. 
 *  For Hygiene sales skill opportunities ? Technology Platform is not required, and only Innovation Growth continues as the business-recommended field. 
 *  Applies only to 1C-linked H5 Opportunities. Non-1C accounts remain unaffected.
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria:

 *  Field Visibility (1C Only) 

 *  Given I open an Opportunity linked to an H5 account, (1C Only) 
 *  When the Opportunity’s Sales Skill = Water, 
 *  Then the Technology Platform field is visible on the Develop section of the form and within the Develop stage of the BPF. 
 *  Given the Opportunity’s Sales Skill = Hygiene, 
 *  Then the Technology Platform field should not be visible. 
 

 *  Mandatory Rule (Water Only) 

 *  Given I am working on an Opportunity with Sales Skill = Water, 
 *  When I attempt to move past the Develop stage without selecting a Technology Platform, 
 *  Then the system must block progression and display an error requiring Technology Platform to be completed. 
 

 *  Optional Rule (Hygiene) (1C Only) 

 *  Given I am working on an Opportunity with Sales Skill = Hygiene, 
 *  When I progress through the Develop stage, 
 *  Then the Technology Platform field is not shown and is not required. 
 

 *  Innovation Growth Coexistence (1C Only) 

 *  Given I open the Develop stage of the BPF, 
 *  Then both Innovation Growth and Technology Platform fields should be visible (for consistency in layout), 
 *  And only enforce Technology Platform as mandatory if Sales Skill = Water. 
 

 *  Non-1C Behavior 

 *  Given I open an Opportunity on an H5 account not linked to any 1C Sales Skill accounts, 
 *  Then there is no change in current form behavior. It should work the same way as it does today 
 

 

 

 
Business Requirements: 

 *  Add Technology Platform field to Develop section of the Opportunity form for H5 opportunities. 
 *  Add Technology Platform to the Develop stage of the Opportunity BPF. 
 *  Apply Sales Skill–based logic: 

 *  Water ? Technology Platform visible + mandatory before exiting Develop stage. 
 *  Hygiene ? Technology Platform hidden. 
 

 *  Keep Innovation Growth visible and business-recommended for both Water and Hygiene. 
 *  Ensure error handling prevents progression past Develop stage without Technology Platform for Water. 
 *  No impact to non-1C H5 accounts.

column6: Detect and Warn Users of Duplicate Contacts Across Existing Customer Account Records Linked to the Same BCA
column11:
As a CRM user, I need the system to detect potential duplicate contacts not only within the same account but also across all accounts linked to the same Base Customer Account (BCA), so that I am alerted when I am about to create a duplicate and can either reuse the existing contact or proceed knowingly.
 

 
Current State: 
Today, CRM’s duplicate detection rule for Contacts functions at the individual account level:

 *  If a user creates a contact named ABC with phone number 123 and buying role XYZ under a customer account, CRM’s duplicate detection rule will trigger if the same Name + Phone Number + Buying Role is attempted again within that same account. 
 *  This works correctly and must remain unchanged. 
 

 
Future State (1C Model): 
With the One Customer (1C) model, multiple Existing Customer Account Records (Sales Skill Accounts) may be linked to the same Base Customer Account (BCA). Example:
 

 *  Contact ABC, phone 123, buying role XYZ exists under the Water account. 
 *  A user then attempts to create the same contact under the Hygiene account, also linked to the same BCA. 
 *  The current duplicate detection will not catch this, because the rule only works at the single-account level. 
 

 
Business Need: 
We need to preserve existing duplicate detection logic (single-account check) AND extend it by adding a BCA-level duplicate detection rule.
 

 
When creating or editing a contact under an account linked to a BCA, CRM should: 

 *  Run existing duplicate detection for the same account (unchanged). 
 *  Run an additional duplicate check across all accounts linked to the same BCA. 
 *  If a match is found in another account under the same BCA: 

 *  Display a warning message before save completes. 
 *  Show a list of matched contacts with key details (Name, Email, Phone, Buying Role, Contact Owner, Account Owner). 
 *  Provide two options: 

 *  Use Existing Contact ? reference the existing record to avoid duplication. 
 *  Create Anyway ? allow creation but alert the user.
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria:

 *  Given I am a user creating or editing a contact under an Existing Customer Account Record linked to a BCA, 

 *  When the system detects a duplicate under the same account, 
 *  Then the current duplicate detection rule should still fire as it does today. 
 

 *  Given I am creating or editing a contact under an account linked to a BCA, 

 *  When a duplicate (same Name + Phone Number + Buying Role) exists under another account linked to the same BCA, 
 *  Then I should see a warning message before save completes. 
 *  And the message should list matched contacts with details (Name, Email, Phone Number, Buying Role, Contact Owner, Account Owner). 
 *  And I should have two clear options: 

 *  Use Existing Contact ? auto-link/reference the existing record. 
 *  Create Anyway ? continue with new contact creation. 
 

 *  And this extended detection should apply only across accounts linked under the same BCA, not to unrelated customer accounts. 
 

 

 
Business Requirements: 

 *  Maintain current duplicate detection logic (same account, same contact). 
 *  Add an extended duplicate detection rule across accounts linked under the same BCA. 
 *  Ensure that both rules work together without conflict. 
 *  Provide a warning message before save completes when a duplicate is found across the same BCA. 
 *  Display matched contact details: Name, Email, Phone, Buying Role, Contact Owner, Account Owner. 
 *  Provide two options: 

 *  Use Existing Contact (reference) 
 *  Create Anyway (bypass). 
 

 *  Do not trigger the extended duplicate detection for unrelated customer accounts. 
 

 
Developer Notes: 

 *  Do not remove or modify the existing CRM duplicate detection rules; they must remain functional. 
 *  Implement a new custom duplicate detection check scoped to BCA-linked accounts. 
 *  The new check must trigger in addition to the standard CRM duplicate detection, not instead of it. 
 *  Query logic must: 

 *  Identify the current account’s linked BCA. 
 *  Check all other accounts linked to that BCA. 
 *  Compare Name + Phone Number + Buying Role against existing contacts. 
 

 *  Warning message must dynamically display matched contacts. 
 *  Ensure “Use Existing Contact” creates a reference link instead of duplication. 
 *  “Create Anyway” should allow the save but log the event. 
 *  Must handle performance efficiently for BCAs linked to multiple accounts. 
 *  Regression testing: confirm current detection still works at single-account level and that new rule does not over-trigger for unrelated accounts.

column6: Deferred Backlog: Update H5 Account Tabs to Show TSR and Hide Cases
column11:
As a CRM user managing H5 (corporate) accounts,
I need the Cases tab to be hidden and only the TSR tab to remain visible for Nalco Water H5 accounts,
 
So that users see only relevant information and avoid confusion with unused Cases functionality.
 

 
For Hygiene H5 accounts, the current behavior remains unchanged — TSR tab is already present and functional, and Cases are not used.
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria:
 
 

 *  Scenario 1 – Nalco Water H5 Accounts (Non 1C ) 

 *  Given I open an H5 account where the Global Business = Nalco Water, 
 *  When I view the tabs, 
 *  Then the Cases tab (or “Cases/TSR” combined tab) must be hidden, 
 *  And a TSR-only tab must be visible, 
 *  And the subgrid showing Cases must also be hidden from the form. 
 

 *  Scenario 2 – Hygiene H5 Accounts (Non 1C and 1C ) 

 *  Given I open an H5 account where the Global Business = Food & Beverage (Hygiene), 
 *  When I view the tabs, 
 *  Then the TSR tab must remain visible as it is today, 
 *  And no change should occur compared to current behavior.

column6: Deferred Backlog: Update GAM Population Logic on H5 Accounts
column11: As a Global Account Manager (GAM), I want the GAM field on H5 accounts populated automatically using MDM Ultimate Parent relationships (instead of legacy SAP 3-digit codes), so that GAM assignments are consistent, accurate, and no longer require manual maintenance.
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria: 

 *  Given an H5 account has a GAM defined in MDM Ultimate Parent, when I view the Team Members tab, then the GAM field is automatically populated with the correct GAM. 
 *  Given an H5 account does not have a GAM defined in MDM Ultimate Parent, when I view the Team Members tab, then the GAM field is visible but blank. 
 *  Given I compare current GAM values with legacy SAP 3-digit code logic, when I validate data, then I confirm the GAM field is now sourced only from MDM Ultimate Parent. 
 *  Given I open an H5 account, when I view the Team Members tab, then the GAM field label reads “Global Account Manager (GAM)” instead of “Food & Beverage GAM.” 
 *  Given I run consolidated reporting across Water, Hygiene, and other divisions, when GAM data is retrieved, then values align correctly using MDM mappings, not SAP codes. 
 

 
Business Requirements:

 *  Retain the GAM field on the Team Members tab. 
 *  Update the label from “Food & Beverage GAM” to “Global Account Manager (GAM)”. 
 *  Stop relying on the SAP 3-digit code to populate GAM, since it is not maintained in EVS. 
 *  Source GAM values from the MDM Ultimate Parent relationship. 
 *  Eliminate manual GAM field maintenance via obsolete codes. 
 *  Ensure reporting and visibility of GAM values works consistently across Water, Hygiene, and other divisions.

column6: Deferred Backlog: Restrict District and Sales Skill Field Updates for Approved Prospects in 1C Districts
column11:
As a CRM system, when a prospect account in a 1C district is approved, the District and Sales Skill fields must be blocked from further edits to preserve territory alignment and sales skill assignments.

 *  While a prospect is still in Pending Approval, users should be allowed to update both the District and Sales Skill fields. 
 *  Once the prospect is Approved, both the District and Sales Skill fields must become read-only/blocked. 
 *  This logic applies only for accounts in 1C districts. 
 *  For non-1C districts, no change in behavior is required — users can continue to edit the District and Sales Skill fields as per today’s functionality. 
 

 
This ensures that once a prospect is approved, its district and sales skill alignment remain fixed and consistent with One Customer rules.
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria:
 
 

 *  Pending Approval Prospect in 1C District 

 *  Given a prospect account exists in a 1C district, 
 *  When the prospect is in Pending Approval status, 
 *  Then the District and Sales Skill fields should remain editable. 
 

 *  Approved Prospect in 1C District 

 *  Given a prospect account exists in a 1C district, 
 *  When the prospect is Approved, 
 *  Then both the District and Sales Skill fields should be blocked/read-only. 
 *  And any attempt to edit these fields should be prevented by the system. 
 

 *  Prospects in Non-1C Districts 

 *  Given a prospect account exists in a non-1C district, 
 *  Then the locking and unlocking of District and Sales Skill fields should continue to behave as they do today .

column7: Testing
Master regression updation
Creating/Updating Test Case
Create an edit or non-edit District and Sales Skill fields

column6: Deferred Backlog: Replace or supplement district charge code usage with EBS business partner number for no-charge tank orders (post-workshop outcome)
Deferred Backlog: Implement unloading point integration between ERP and CRM for tank and tank order records
Deferred Backlog: Extend “Ship labels to” dropdown to include Glenwood and other destinations with appropriate account-based routing logic
Deferred Backlog: Define Customer Account Downgrade/Deactivation Process Post-Business Loss
column11:
As a CRM business owner, I need a clearly defined process for what should happen to an account that is linked to a Base Customer Account (BCA) when the business is lost, so that deactivation and BCA linkage behavior is consistent, auditable, and aligned across CRM and integrated systems.

 
This requirement is for future backlog (not part of R1 or R2) but must be documented now for planning purposes.
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria:
Since this is a definition and process-alignment story, not an immediate delivery item, the acceptance criteria focus on clarity and documentation:

 *  Process Definition 

 *  Given a customer account linked to a BCA, 
 *  When that account is marked as “Business Lost,” 
 *  Then the system must have a defined and agreed process on whether the account: 

 *  (a) is deactivated but still retains the BCA link, or 
 *  (b) is deactivated and the BCA link is removed or piped out. 
 

 

 *  Consistency 

 *  Given multiple customer accounts linked to the same BCA, 
 *  When one account undergoes deactivation due to business loss, 
 *  Then the process must ensure that the BCA remains consistent and is not unintentionally impacted. 
 

 *  Auditability 

 *  Given a downgrade/deactivation event, 
 *  When the account status changes, 
 *  Then the event must be logged with details for audit and historical reporting. 
 

 

 
Business Requirements:
 

 *  Ensure clear alignment between CRM, BCA behavior, and downstream integrations when business loss occurs. 
 *  Define whether the BCA relationship should persist or terminate after customer deactivation. 
 *  Avoid accidental disruption of BCA master records when business loss occurs at the account level. 
 *  Provide audit trail for deactivation decisions and outcomes. 
 *  Mark this requirement as future scope (beyond R1/R2) for business alignment and design finalization.

column6: Deferred Backlog: Create New Snowflake View for Market Segment-to-Sales Skill Mapping Table
column11:
As a CRM reporting user,
I want a new Snowflake view that captures the relationship between market segments and sales skills (including inactive ones),
 
so that I can analyze and validate how market segments are linked to sales skills over time and ensure downstream reporting reflects both active and inactive mappings.
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria:

 *  Given a market segment is linked to one or more sales skills, 

 *  When the mapping is loaded into Snowflake, 
 *  Then the view should display all market segment–to–sales skill relationships. 
 

 *  Given a market segment–to–sales skill mapping is inactive in CRM, 

 *  When the mapping is loaded, 
 *  Then the view should still display the record with its status = inactive. 
 

 *  Given reporting users filter by status, 

 *  When they query the view, 
 *  Then they should be able to distinguish between active and inactive mappings. 
 

 *  Given a sales skill or market segment is deactivated entirely, 

 *  When the mapping is refreshed, 
 *  Then the view should continue to show historical mappings with their current status. 
 

 

 
Business Requirements: 

 *  Create a new Snowflake view for Market Segment-to-Sales Skill Mapping under the One Customer model. 
 *  The view should include the following fields: 

 *  Market Segment ID 
 *  Market Segment Name 
 *  Sales Skill ID 
 *  Sales Skill Name 
 *  Status (Active / Inactive) 
 

 *  All relationships must reflect CRM’s configuration, including active and inactive links. 
 *  View must be queryable by reporting teams for both current active mappings and historical inactive mappings. 
 *  Mapping should refresh automatically with CRM ? Snowflake updates. 
 

 
Developer Notes: 

 *  Work with Siddharth and Zahra to align mappings and coordinate through Fivetran. 
 *  Ensure schema naming follows Ecolab Snowflake standards. 
 *  Confirm with Power BI/reporting teams that the status field is usable for filters and slicers. 
 *  Validate that inactive mappings are clearly surfaced but do not interfere with downstream aggregations unless explicitly included by user filters.

column6: Deferred Backlog: Create New Snowflake View for District-to-Sales Skill Mapping Table
column11:
As a CRM reporting user,
I want a new Snowflake view that establishes a relationship between districts and sales skills,
 
so that I can ensure reporting and analysis respects the allowed district-to-sales skill mappings under the One Customer model.
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria:
 

 *  Given a district is linked to one or more valid sales skills in CRM, 

 *  When the mapping is loaded into Snowflake, 
 *  Then the view should display the correct district-to-sales skill relationships. 
 

 *  Given a district has no assigned sales skills, 

 *  When the mapping is loaded, 
 *  Then the view should return no rows for that district. 
 

 *  Given reporting users filter or aggregate data by district and sales skill, 

 *  When they query the Snowflake mapping view, 
 *  Then they should see only valid combinations defined in CRM. 
 

 *  Given a sales skill is deactivated in CRM, 

 *  When the mapping is refreshed, 
 *  Then the view should  inactive relationships with a status indicating if the association is till active or Inactive. 
 

 

 
Business Requirements: 

 *  Create a new Snowflake view for District-to-Sales Skill mapping to support One Customer reporting and validation. 
 *  The view should include: 

 *  District ID 
 *  District Name 
 *  Sales Skill ID 
 *  Sales Skill Name 
 *  Status: Active/Inactive  
 

 *  Relationships must reflect CRM’s pre-configured mapping of districts to sales skills. 
 *  The view should support filtering logic in Power BI and other downstream tools, ensuring only valid sales skills appear for a selected district. 
 *  Mapping must update automatically with CRM data refreshes to Snowflake. 
 

 
Developer Notes: 

 *  Work with Siddharth and Zahra to finalize field mappings and coordinate Fivetran integration. 
 *  Follow Ecolab Snowflake schema conventions for new views. 
 *  Confirm with reporting teams (Jane Jacobs’ team) that the mapping view integrates into Power BI filtering scenarios. 
 *  Validate that inactive or deprecated district/sales skill links do not surface in the view.

column6: Deferred Backlog: Auto-approve customer service and warehouse stages in the tank order business process flow for intercompany / 1C tank orders
Deferred Backlog: Add Service Plans tab aggregated from related Accounts.
column11:
As a CRM user,
I need a Service Plans section under the Service Visits tab on the Base Customer Account (BCA) form,
 
so that I can see all service plans from accounts linked to the same Base Customer Account Number, making it easier to view and filter service plans across all related accounts in one place.
column22:
*  Tab & Section Setup 

 *  A tab named “Service Visits” is present on the BCA form (or created if not existing). 
 *  Within this tab, a section named “Service Plans” is added. 
 *  The Service Plans subgrid shows all service plans from accounts that share the Base Customer Account Number of the current BCA. 
 *  The aggregation includes service plans from all accounts (Sold-To or otherwise) linked to the same Base Customer Account Number. 
 

 *  Displayed Columns (Order and Changes) 

 *  Columns in the Service Plans subgrid, in order: 

 *  Sold-To Account 
 *  Account Number (new – from the related account)  
 *  Sales Skill (new – from the related account) 
 *  Service Plan Name 
 *  Start Date 
 *  End Date 
 *  Status 
 *  Owner 
 

 

 *  Column Behavior 

 *  Account Number: 

 *  Displays the account number from the related account. 
 *  Appears immediately after the Sold-To Account column. 
 

 *  Sales Skill: 

 *  Displays the Sales Skill value from the related account. 
 *  Appears immediately after the Account Number column. 
 

 *  Both new columns: 

 *  Are sortable and filterable. 
 *  Follow standard CRM behavior for column filtering and search. 
 

 

 *  Sorting Defaults 

 *  Default sort order is Service Plan Name (ascending). 
 *  This sorting applies to all service plans in the aggregated view. 
 

 *  Filtering & View Selector 

 *  The default view shows all service plans linked via accounts that have the same Base Customer Account Number as the current BCA and status is Active. 
 *  Users cannot change filters or select alternative views for this section. 
 

 *  Security 

 *  Only users with permission to view service plans for the related accounts will see them in the subgrid. 
 *  Ability to open or edit service plans follows standard CRM security roles.

column6: DC: Migrate Email Domains from Water H5 to Hygiene H5 During Consolidation
column11:
As a CRM system administrator, I need the email domains currently associated with Water H5 accounts to be migrated and re-linked to the surviving Hygiene H5 accounts during consolidation, so that CDM permission management continues to function correctly under the One Customer model.
 

 
Today, Water H5 accounts hold email domain associations that are used by CDM for user access and permission control. In the future state, Water H5 accounts will be merged into Hygiene H5 accounts. To avoid loss of permissions or access gaps, the email domains must be carried forward to the surviving Hygiene H5.
 

 
This story is focused on data conversion and continuity — ensuring no email domains are lost or orphaned as part of the H5 merge process.

Business Requirements: 

 *  Identify all email domains currently linked to Water H5 accounts. 
 *  Re-link those domains to the surviving Hygiene H5 during consolidation. 
 *  Ensure no duplication of email domains across H5 accounts. 
 *  Verify CDM permission logic remains intact after migration. 
 *  Provide audit/reporting to confirm successful migration.
column19: Moved out of state Sprint Ready
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria:
 
 
 

 *  Email Domains Re-Linked to Surviving Organization (H5) Account 

 *  Given a Water Organization Account is merged into a Hygiene Organization (H5) account during 1C consolidation, 
 *  When I open the surviving Organization (H5) account, 
 *  Then all email domains previously associated to the Water Organization Account must now be associated to the Hygiene Organization (H5) Account. 
 

 *  No Orphaned Domains  

 *  Given a merge of H5 accounts has occurred,  
 *  When I check the email domains table,  
 *  Then no email domains should remain linked to the inactive Water H5 or unlinked to any H5.  
 

 *  Permissions Continue to Function  

 *  Given the email domains have been migrated,  
 *  When CDM applies permission logic,  
 *  Then users associated with those email domains must still receive correct access without interruption.  
 

 *  Merge duplicate domains if any  
 *  Validate that the same Email Domains are not associated to the surviving Hygiene Organization (H5) account

column6: DC: Ensure CKBD Data Continuity During Organization Merges
column11:
As a CRM system administrator, I need CKBD records associated with Water H5 accounts to be carried over and linked to the surviving Hygiene H5 during 1C account merges, so that no CKBD and Local Key Business Drivers data is lost or orphaned when consolidating accounts under the One Customer model.
 
 

 
This story focuses on data conversion and continuity. It ensures that CKBD and Local Key Business Drivers records tied to Water H5 accounts remain accessible from the CKBD tab after Water H5 accounts are merged into Hygiene H5 accounts

Business Requirements: 

 *  Data migration scripts or processes must ensure CKBD records are re-linked to the surviving H5. 
 *  CKBD and Local Key Business Drivers records should not be duplicated; only reparented. 
 *  Align with overall H5 merge and reparenting logic defined in One Customer data conversion strategy. 
 

 

.
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria:
 
 
 

 *  Data Continuity During Organisation Merge 

 *  Given a Water Organization account is merged into a Hygiene Organization account as part of the 1C alignment, 
 *  When I open the surviving Hygiene Organization account, 
 *  Then all CKBD records previously tied to the Water Organization must now be linked to the surviving Hygiene Organization and accessible via the CKBD tab. 
 *  And all Local Key Business Drivers records previously tied to the Water Organization must now be linked to the surviving Hygiene Organization and accessible via the CKBD tab.
 
 

 *  No Orphaned Data 

 *  Given a merge of Organization accounts has taken place, 
 *  When I query CKBD records, 
 *  Then no CKBD records should remain orphaned or linked to an inactive/non-surviving Organisation. 
 

 

NOTE: If an H5 is a mixed account, then we need a logic to copy over the CKBD data

column6: DC: Clone Water SHIP-TO to Create Hygiene SHIP-TO for Common BCA Customers
column11:
As a data conversion analyst,
 
I want to automatically create a Hygiene SHIP-TO by cloning the existing Water SHIP-TO under the same Base Customer Account (BCA),
 
so that both Hygiene and Water SOLD-TOs have corresponding SHIP-TO records for consistent downstream integration and reporting.
 

 
Background and Rationale 
Under the One Customer model, every customer (BCA) can have up to two SOLD-TO accounts — one for Water (legacy NSAP) and one for Hygiene (EBS). 
In some cases:
 

 *  Both Water and Hygiene SOLD-TOs exist for the same BCA. 
 *  Water SOLD-TO has one or more SHIP-TOs, but Hygiene SOLD-TO has none (since Hygiene previously didn’t use SHIP-TOs). 
 

 
To maintain parity across divisions and enable consistent data flow to integrated systems, each Hygiene SOLD-TO must have at least one SHIP-TO. 
If a Water SHIP-TO already exists for the same customer: 

 *  The data conversion package must clone the Water SHIP-TO and link it to the Hygiene SOLD-TO, copying key attributes and updating the Sales Skill to “Hygiene.” 
 

 
The sequencing of related activities must be as follows: 

 *  Update Account Number, Sales Skill and Reparent the Sold To's on the  SHIP-TOs that are promoted to SOLD-TOs (already covered in another SHIP-TO story). 
 *  SHIP-TO merges where multiple Water SHIP-TOs are linked to Sold To's are reduced to one per Water SOLD-TO. 
 *  Update of SHIP-TO number and Sales Skill where applicable.
 
 *  Execution of this cloning logic to create Hygiene SHIP-TOs.
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria
 
 

 *  Scenario 1 – Identify Eligible Accounts for Cloning 

 *  Given a customer (BCA) has both a Water SOLD-TO (legacy NSAP) and a Hygiene SOLD-TO (EBS), 
 *  And the Water SOLD-TO has exactly one active SHIP-TO after all merges are complete, 
 *  And the Hygiene SOLD-TO currently has no SHIP-TO, 
 *  When the cloning process runs, 
 *  Then a new Hygiene SHIP-TO record is created under the Hygiene SOLD-TO. 
 

 *  Scenario 2 – Clone Water SHIP-TO Attributes 

 *  Given the Water SHIP-TO record exists in CRM, 
 *  When the cloning script executes, 
 *  Then it duplicates all core attributes including Name, Address, City, Country, Zip/Postal Code, and Account Number, 
 *  And assigns the Sales Skill = “Hygiene” on the cloned record. 
 *  And establishes the Parent Account relationship with the Hygiene SOLD-TO. 
 

 


 

 

 
Below are some Ship To Scenarios that shows how the cloning needs to be work during the Ship To Process. These scenarios need to be validated 

 *  Scenario SHIPTO-3 — One Hygiene (EBS) SOLD_TO, One Water (NSAP) SOLD_TO (With One Ship To) 

 *  Given one Hygiene SOLD_TO exists in EBS and one Water SOLD_TO exists in NSAP for the same customer, 
 *  And the SOLD_TO merge process has been executed and both are linked to the same BCA, 
 *  When the SHIP-TO process runs, 
 *  Then: 

 *  Update SHIP-TO number on Water Ship To Account= EBS mapping number. Handled in the Ship To 7 Scenarios as part of a different user story 
 *  Set SalesSkill = Water on Water Ship To Account. Handled in the Ship To 7 Scenarios as part of a different user story 
 *  Create one Hygiene SHIP-TO under the EBS SOLD_TO (SalesSkill = Hygiene) by cloning the Ship To that is linked with the water sales skill account. 
 *  Maintain relationship of both SHIP-TOs to their respective SOLD_TOs. 
 *  No SHIP-TO merge or deactivation is required in this scenario 
 

 

 *  Scenario SHIPTO-4 — Multiple Hygiene (EBS) SOLD_TO, One Water (NSAP) SOLD_TO (With One Ship To) 

 *  Given multiple Hygiene SOLD_TOs exist in EBS and one Water SOLD_TO exists in NSAP (With One Ship To), 
 *  And the multiple Hygiene SOLD_TOs have already been merged into a single survivor, 
 *  When the SHIP-TO process runs, 
 *  Then: 

 *  Update SHIP-TO number on Water Ship To Account= EBS mapping number. Handled in the Ship To 7 Scenarios as part of a different user story 
 *  Set SalesSkill = Water on Water Ship To Account. Handled in the Ship To 7 Scenarios as part of a different user story 
 *  Create one Hygiene SHIP-TO for the surviving EBS SOLD_TO (SalesSkill = Hygiene, number = EBS SOLD_TO number) by cloning the Ship To that is linked with the water sales skill account. 
 *  For the single Water SOLD_TO having one SHIP-TO, update that SHIP-TO number to EBS mapping number and set SalesSkill = Water. Handled in the Ship To 7 Scenarios as part of a different user story 
 *  Ensure both Water and Hygiene SHIP-TOs link to their respective SOLD_TOs. 
 *  No merge or deactivation needed. 
 

 

 *  Scenario SHIPTO-5 — One Hygiene (EBS) SOLD_TO, Multiple Water (NSAP) SOLD_TOs 

 *  Given one EBS Hygiene SOLD_TO and multiple NSAP Water SOLD_TOs exist for the same customer, 
 *  And the Water SOLD_TOs have been merged into a single surviving Water SOLD_TO, 
 *  And that Water SOLD_TO has multiple SHIP-TOs (some to be promoted to new SOLD_TOs because of address differences), 
 *  When the SHIP-TO process runs, 
 *  Then: 

 *  Deactivate all Water SHIP-TOs that are being promoted to new EBS SOLD_TOs (address mismatch from SOLD_TO). Handled in the Ship To Deactivation user story 
 *  Merge remaining Water SHIP-TOs sharing the same address into one under the surviving Water SOLD_TO. handled in the Ship To Merge user story 
 *  Update SHIP-TO number on Water Ship To Account= EBS mapping number. Handled in the Ship To 7 Scenarios as part of a different user story 
 *  Set SalesSkill = Water on Water Ship To Account. Handled in the Ship To 7 Scenarios as part of a different user story 
 *  Create one Hygiene SHIP-TO for the surviving EBS SOLD_TO (SalesSkill = Hygiene, number = EBS SOLD_TO number) by cloning the Ship To that is linked with the water sales skill account. 
 *  Ensure both Water and Hygiene SHIP-TOs link to their respective SOLD_TOs.
 
 

 

 *  Scenario SHIPTO-6 — Multiple Hygiene (EBS) SOLD_TOs, Multiple Water (NSAP) SOLD_TOs 

 *  Given multiple Hygiene SOLD_TOs in EBS and multiple Water SOLD_TOs in NSAP exist for the same customer, 
 *  And both sets of SOLD_TOs have been merged into respective survivors and linked to a single BCA, 
 *  When the SHIP-TO process runs, 
 *  Then: 

 *  Deactivate all Water SHIP-TOs that are being promoted to new EBS SOLD_TOs (address mismatch from SOLD_TO). Handled in the Ship To Deactivation user story 
 *  Merge remaining Water SHIP-TOs sharing the same address into one under the surviving Water SOLD_TO. handled in the Ship To Merge user story 
 *  Update SHIP-TO number on Water Ship To Account= EBS mapping number. Handled in the Ship To 7 Scenarios as part of a different user story 
 *  Set SalesSkill = Water on Water Ship To Account. Handled in the Ship To 7 Scenarios as part of a different user story 
 *  Create one Hygiene SHIP-TO for the surviving EBS SOLD_TO (SalesSkill = Hygiene, number = EBS SOLD_TO number) by cloning the Ship To that is linked with the water sales skill account. 
 *  Ensure both Water and Hygiene SHIP-TOs link to their respective SOLD_TOs. 
 

 

 

 

 
Dependencies 

 *  Completion of SHIP-TO Updates where Ship To has been Promoted to a new sold to. 
 *  Completion of SOLD-TO and SHIP-TO Merge stories. 
 *  Completion of Updates to account number and sales skill on Ship To's 
 *  Business-provided mapping spreadsheet identifying Water–Hygiene SOLD-TO pairs under each BCA. 
 *  Integration configuration to avoid re-creating these cloned SHIP-TOs.

column11:
TestCases

 *  Validate that for a BCA, where both Hygiene and water sales skill record exists (after Data merge) and Water sales skill has linked Shipto:

column6: Data Conversion- Identify & Resolve Potential Duplicate Contacts During Account Merges (Data Conversion Only)
column11:
As a data migration lead, I need the data conversion to detect and handle potential duplicate Contact records when multiple Water or Hygiene account versions are merged into a single existing customer account record under the same BCA, so that duplicate contacts aren’t unintentionally carried forward and the post-merge dataset remains clean and usable.
 

 
Business context
In 1C alignment, multiple legacy accounts (e.g., Water variants or Hygiene variants) may be merged into a single account under the same BCA. 
If those source accounts contain contacts with the same Name + Email + Phone + Buying Role, they are potential duplicates and must be surfaced and addressed during data conversion (not via CRM UI logic).
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria:

 *  Given a planned merge of multiple Hygiene or Water accounts into a single account before linking it under the same BCA, 

 *  When the data conversion job runs in analysis/dry-run mode, 
 *  Then it produces a Duplicate Contacts Report listing candidate duplicates using Name + Email + Phone + Buying Role as the match keys, grouped by BCA and target account. 
 

 *  Given the Duplicate Contacts Report is generated, 

 *  When duplicates are confirmed by the data team, 
 *  Then the conversion provides a guided resolution output (per group) indicating which contact becomes master and which become to-link / to-skip, without creating duplicate rows. 
 

 *  Given the conversion runs in execute mode, 

 *  When duplicate groups have a selected resolution, 
 *  Then the conversion prevents creation of duplicate contact rows and retains one master per duplicate set, applying the chosen action for the rest (e.g., skip create, reference/link where applicable). 
 

 *  Given contacts in different BCAs share the same identity information, 

 *  When the conversion evaluates duplicates, 
 *  Then it does not flag cross-BCA matches (scope is within the same BCA only). 
 

 

 
Business Requirements: 

 *  Detect potential duplicate Contacts within the same BCA across source accounts being merged into a single target account. 
 *  Use Name + Email + Phone + Buying Role as the matching keys (normalized for whitespace/case/format). 
 *  Produce a dry-run report for business review: BCA, target account, contact identity fields, source account(s), and recommended master. 
 *  Support a guided resolution: master selection + action for non-masters (skip/create-link/reference as applicable). 
 *  Execute mode must prevent duplicate contact creation and preserve only the designated master per set. 
 *  Apply the same protocol during initial migration and any re-loads. 
 *  Exclude cross-BCA matches from duplicate grouping. 
 

 
Developer Notes: 

 *  Normalization: trim/case-insensitive for Name; standardize Phone (e.g., E.164); exact match on Buying Role; Email lowercased. 
 *  Matching logic: primary key = (Name, Email, Phone, Buying Role). If Email or Phone is missing, still include record but only match when all four fields are present (avoid over-merge). 
 *  Reports: 

 *  Duplicate Contacts Report (dry-run): BCA, target account, source account(s), contact IDs (legacy + CRM), identity fields, suggested master, group ID. 
 *  Resolution Input Template: CSV/XLSX for business to mark master/non-master actions. 
 *  Execution Log: actions taken per contact, skipped/retained counts. 
 

 *  Actions in execute mode: 

 *  Master: create/update one contact. 
 *  Non-masters: skip create; where feasible, store a reference/map to the master (for traceability). 
 

 *  Scope constraints: only contacts within the same BCA; ignore cross-BCA similarities. 
 *  Outputs to deliver: duplicate report, resolution template, execution log, and a summary dashboard (counts by BCA: analyzed, flagged, resolved).

column6: CRM: Contact De-duplication and Alignment for BCA Model
column11:
With the introduction of the Base Customer Account (BCA) model in CRM, contact management practices must evolve to support a shared enterprise view while preserving operational clarity at the sales skill account level. This feature enables structured alignment, de-duplication, and regression validation of contact records across Water and Hygiene sales skills under a single BCA umbrella.

 
Under the new model:
 

 *  Contacts will be created and owned only at the Sales Skill Account level (i.e., Water or Hygiene-specific account), not at the BCA level. 
 *  BCAs will display read-only views of all associated contacts for enterprise visibility, enabling downstream systems and users to see a full contact picture without modifying ownership. 
 *  This approach helps simplify governance, reduce conflicts over ownership, and maintain clear accountability for updates. 
 

 
However, this model introduces potential for duplicate contact creation across Sales Skill Accounts under the same BCA. For example, if a contact is created on both Water and Hygiene accounts under the same BCA, the system may not detect it using standard CRM deduplication logic, which only flags duplicates within the same account. Therefore, new duplicate detection logic must be introduced to detect and warn users of potential duplicate contacts across linked sales skill accounts under a common BCA, based on a defined match rule (e.g., Name + Email + Phone). 

 
Additionally, account merge scenarios must be carefully handled to avoid contact duplication:
 

 *  In scenarios where multiple Water or Hygiene accounts are merged under the same BCA (e.g., during data cleanup or FBU migration), contact lists must be consolidated and deduplicated prior to or during the merge. 
 *  Standard CRM merge logic may simply concatenate contact lists from both accounts (e.g., 5 + 4 = 9), potentially creating duplicate entries. Thus, deduplication and validation tools or custom pre-merge routines must be explored. 
 

 
This feature also includes a technical spike to evaluate and potentially design new deduplication UI behavior, merge conflict resolution experience, and contact match rule configuration. The output of this spike will determine whether configuration, plugin-based logic, or custom UI components are needed. 

 
Finally, regression testing must be conducted to ensure that all existing integrations using contact data remain valid post-BCA model rollout. These include integrations with:
 

 *  Ecolab 3D 
 *  Ecolab.com 
 *  Connect 
 *  CDM (Customer Data Management) 
 *  Other downstream platforms consuming contact information via APIs

column7: Restrict Adding New Contacts from the BCA – Ensure Contact Creation Only from Existing Customer Account Records
column11:
Business Objective:
 
Ensure clean governance and prevent ownership conflicts by clearly defining where contacts can be created or edited. As part of the One Customer model, contacts should no longer be managed directly at the Base Customer Account (BCA) level. Instead, contact records must be exclusively created, edited, and managed at the Sales Skill Account level (Water or Hygiene), aligning with how relationship ownership, communication, and activities are tracked in field operations. 

 
Business Requirement: 

 *  Users must only be permitted to create new contact records under Sales Skill Accounts (CRM Account Type = Sales Skill). 
 *  The “Add New Contact” and “Edit Contact” options should be disabled on the BCA form (CRM Account Type = Base Customer). 
 *  All ownership, lookup values, and activities related to a contact should remain associated with the Sales Skill Account under which it was created. 
 *  The Base Customer Account (BCA) form should display a consolidated, read-only list of associated contacts from all linked Sales Skill Accounts (Water and Hygiene) for enterprise visibility. 
 *  The contact subgrid on the BCA form must be non-editable and clearly labeled as “View Only – Contact Details from Sales Skill Accounts.” 
 *  The subgrid must support basic sorting and filtering (e.g., by name, email, phone), but no inline editing, create, or delete options should be available. 
 *  Show the Sales Skill on each contact row to indicate contact ownership. 
 *  No workflows, forms, or Power Automate logic should inadvertently allow contact creation or updates directly on a BCA record. 
 

Additional Note (for Regression Validation – Contact Touchpoints):
As part of this requirement, the following integration touchpoints must be validated via regression testing to ensure they continue to behave correctly with the One Customer BCA model in place: 

 *  Contact creation and updates must continue to sync correctly to: 

 *  Ecolab 3D 
 *  Connect Portal 
 *  CDM 
 *  Ecolab.com user management 
 

 *  Ensure that contact record changes from CRM: 

 *  Trigger CDM updates appropriately. 
 *  Reflect accurately in external portals and systems tied to that sales skill account. 
 *  Respect the read-only nature of contacts at the BCA level, and ensure external systems are not affected by this constraint. 
 

 *  Validate that no impact is introduced to: 

 *  Role assignment 
 *  Contact-to-user mapping in portals 
 *  Customer communication workflows 
 

 *  Conduct thorough regression scenarios covering common contact creation, editing, syncing, and external visibility actions. 
 *  No new development is expected from this validation; any issues identified during regression need to be separately triaged. 
 

 
 
 
Technical Considerations: 

 *  Update form-level security or JavaScript rules to disable new/edit options on the Contact subgrid within the BCA form. 
 *  Ensure the ribbon button logic (e.g., “+ New Contact” or “Edit”) respects the Account Type context and is hidden or disabled on the BCA. 
 *  Validate that quick create forms, command bar actions, and related entity forms (e.g., Contact > Parent Account lookup) enforce this restriction. 
 *  Test across CRM interfaces: Web, Mobile, and Hub Portal (if applicable). 
 

 
Expected Deliverables: 

 *  Updated Account form logic to restrict contact creation/editing on BCA records. 
 *  Script or ribbon customization to disable or hide add/edit contact buttons for BCA type. 
 *  Regression testing documentation ensuring no paths exist (form, automation, integration) to modify contact data under BCA. 
 *  Sign-off from business stakeholders confirming compliance with contact governance policy.

column8: Restrict Adding New Contacts from the BCA – Ensure Contact Creation Only from Existing Customer Account Records
column11:
As a user, I should not be able to create new contacts directly from the Base Customer Account (BCA) record.
The BCA should only provide an aggregated view of existing contacts associated with linked customer accounts.
 
If I need to create a new contact, I must do so by navigating into the respective existing customer account record and adding the contact there.
 
This ensures consistency, data integrity, and alignment with the current process for contact management.
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria: Add This Acceptance criteria to the Contacts Aggregated sub grid view on the BCA Forms
 

 *  Given I am a district manager viewing a BCA, 

 *  When I try to add a new contact from the BCA screen, 
 *  Then I should not have the option to create a new contact. 
 

 *  Given I want to create a new contact, 

 *  When I go into an existing customer account record, 
 *  Then I should be able to create and save the new contact from there, following the current process. 
 

 

 
Business Requirements: 

 *  The BCA must provide a read-only aggregated view of contacts linked to associated customer accounts. 
 *  The “New Contact” option must be removed/hidden from the BCA interface. 
 *  Users must only be able to create contacts under existing customer account records (not BCAs). 
 *  Existing contact creation flows under customer accounts remain unchanged. 
 *  Ensure that contact associations continue to sync correctly with Sales Skill Accounts and BCAs, but creation is restricted. 
 

 
Developer Notes: 

 *  Suppress/remove the “New Contact” creation option from the BCA form. 
 *  Ensure the contact subgrid on the BCA remains view-only (aggregated from related customer accounts). 
 *  Verify that existing customer account record forms retain full “New Contact” creation capabilities. 
 *  Regression test the aggregation logic so existing contacts continue to display correctly under BCAs. 
 *  Security roles should be reviewed to ensure consistency across user personas (district manager, sales rep, etc.).

column7: 20. Ensure Contact Deduplication and Data Integrity During Account Merges and Data Conversion
column11:
Business Objective:
 
To maintain clean and consistent contact data across Sales Skill Accounts during Base Customer Account (BCA) consolidation efforts. This includes both manual account merges in CRM and automated account merges during data conversion. The goal is to prevent contact duplication, reduce user confusion, and preserve accurate contact history when multiple Sales Skill Accounts belonging to the same BCA are merged. 

 
Business Requirements : 

 *  When multiple accounts (e.g., multiple Hygiene or Water accounts) are merged into a single Sales Skill Account as part of BCA alignment, CRM must ensure that duplicate contacts are not unintentionally carried forward. 
 *  During such merges: 

 *  Contact records with matching Name, Email, and/or Phone should be identified as potential duplicates. 
 *  The merge process should include automated or guided deduplication to avoid retaining multiple copies of the same contact. 
 

 *  If two merged accounts have contacts with overlapping identity information: 

 *  CRM must flag these for review and prompt the user or admin to retain only one primary contact record, merging associated data where possible. 
 

 *  This same process must also be supported during data conversion/migration activities (e.g., from legacy systems into CRM during One Customer rollout). 
 

 
Technical Considerations: 

 *  A technical spike is required to: 
 *  Analyze CRM’s native merge behavior for Accounts and Contacts and assess whether additional logic is needed to support pre-merge deduplication. 
 *  Determine whether CRM’s existing duplicate detection rules can be used in bulk merges or data import jobs. 
 *  Identify required logic to: 

 *  Prevent duplicates from being brought in during initial data loads. 
 *  Support interactive de-duplication workflows during manual merges initiated by business users. 
 

 *  Evaluate performance and UI limitations in scenarios where merged accounts have dozens or hundreds of contacts. 
 *  Merge logic must support: 

 *  Contact identity matching using Email, Phone, Full Name, and other optional keys (e.g., External Contact ID). 
 *  Preservation of contact history (e.g., Notes, Appointments, Opportunity involvement) when duplicates are merged. 
 

 *  Clear handling of edge cases such as: 

 *  Partial matches (e.g., same name but different email) 
 *  Soft duplicates (e.g., slightly varied names or phone numbers) 
 *  Cross-division records with conflicting ownership 
 

 

 
Expected Deliverables: 

 *  Documented pre-merge deduplication rules and logic for Contacts. 
 *  Scripts, tools, or logic embedded in CRM merge process and data conversion jobs to detect and flag duplicates. 
 *  Updated data migration documentation and playbooks reflecting contact deduplication steps. 
 *  Test cases to validate: 

 *  Deduplication accuracy 
 *  Post-merge data integrity (no missing links) 
 *  Regression impacts on contact-related functionality (e.g., Activities, Lookups) 
 

 *  User training or enablement materials outlining the expected behavior during account merges involving Contacts. 
 *  Assurance that merged Contacts are reflected correctly in downstream systems via integration sync.

column7: 19. Detect and Warn Users of Duplicate Contacts Across Sales Skill Accounts
column11:
Business Objective:
 
To ensure data integrity and reduce contact duplication across Water and Hygiene Sales Skill Accounts under the same Base Customer Account (BCA) by warning users in real-time when similar contact records already exist. This will promote reuse of existing contacts, improve customer visibility, and streamline communication across divisions. 

 
Business Requirements: 

 *  When creating or editing a contact under a Sales Skill Account, CRM must check if a similar contact already exists under any other linked Sales Skill Account belonging to the same Base Customer. 
 *  If a potential duplicate is found: 

 *  The system should alert the user before the save completes, showing a warning message with details of the match. 
 *  The message should clearly indicate where the duplicate exists (e.g., “This contact already exists under the Hygiene account for this customer”). 
 *  A list of matched contacts should be shown with key details: Name, Email, Phone, Associated Account, and Contact Owner. 
 *  Users should be given two clear options: 

 *  “Use Existing Contact” – auto-link or reference the existing contact to avoid duplication. 
 *  “Create Anyway” – continue with new contact creation 
 

 *  This applies only to contacts within the same BCA and across Sales Skill Accounts (Water, Hygiene). 
 *  This does not apply to unrelated customer accounts or external divisions. 
 *  Contact de-duplication across business units helps prevent fragmented customer interactions and improves contact management. 
 

 

 
Technical Considerations 

 *  Background logic: 

 *  Trigger real-time or near-real-time contact duplicate detection logic on contact form save or field value change (Name, Email, Phone). 
 *  Matching logic should include: 

 *  Exact or fuzzy match on Email Address. 
 *  Strong match on First + Last Name. 
 *  Optional match on Phone Number. 
 

 *  Search should only run within Sales Skill Accounts tied to the same BCA. 
 

 *  User Interface/Experience Design: 

 *  When duplicates are found, show a modal pop-up window (not inline error) before finalizing contact creation. 
 *  Modal should display: 
 *  Warning banner: “Potential duplicate contact(s) found within this customer’s Sales Skill Accounts.” 
 *  A grid view showing: 

 *  Name 
 *  Email 
 *  Phone 
 *  Related Sales Skill Account 
 *  Buying Role 
 *  Contact Owner 
 

 *  Include radio buttons or checkboxes in the grid to allow users to select an existing contact to reuse. 
 *  Below the grid, provide action buttons: 

 *  Use Selected Contact – This could close the modal and redirect user to the existing contact record or create a reference. 
 *  Create New Contact Anyway – Proceed with creation, with optional reason box (simple comment field). 
 *  Cancel – To exit and modify entered details. 
 

 

 *  Spike required to: 

 *  Evaluate if this behavior can be achieved with native CRM duplicate detection rules or requires custom plugin, JavaScript, or Power Automate extension. 
 *  Validate performance impact of checking across multiple accounts. 
 *  Explore how duplicate warning modal can be implemented with PCF controls or JavaScript dialogs. 
 *  Evaluate integration impacts on downstream systems (Ecolab 3D, Connect, CDM) when contact reuse occurs. 
 

 

 
Expected Deliverables: 

 *  Implement background duplicate detection logic scoped to Sales Skill Accounts under the same BCA. 
 *  Build a responsive model dialog UI for duplicate alerts with grid display and selectable actions. 
 *  Full documentation of match logic, configuration parameters, and UX flow. 
 *  Test coverage: 

 *  Matching accuracy 
 *  Save-blocking behavior (if applicable) 
 *  Merge and reference scenarios 
 

 *  Regression testing for contact creation flows, especially in: 

 *  Merged accounts 
 *  Contact integrations with CDM, Ecolab 3D, Connect 
 

 *  Deployment artifacts and user training collateral to support new duplicate handling behavior.

column6: Controlled Override of Sales Skill Before Customer Setup Submission
column11:
As a business user, I want the ability to update the Sales Skill on a One Customer (1C) account while it is still a Prospect and before the associated Customer Setup record reaches Submitted status, so that I can ensure the correct Sales Skill alignment is captured during setup.
Once the Customer Setup record is submitted, the Sales Skill field must become locked to preserve data integrity and prevent misalignment with downstream processes.
column22:
Business Acceptance Criteria:
 
 

 *  Editable Before Customer Setup Exists 

 *  Given an account is a Prospect and no Customer Setup record exists, 

 *  When a user edits the account, 
 *  Then the Sales Skill field must be editable and changes are allowed. 
 

 

 *  Editable Before Customer Setup Is Submitted (MDM ID and Process ID has no value in the customer set up record) 

 *  Given an account is a Prospect and a Customer Setup record exists but is not in Submitted status, 

 *  When a user edits the account, 
 *  Then the Sales Skill field must remain editable and any changes update the linked Customer Setup record accordingly. 
 

 

 *  Locked After Customer Setup Submission (MDM ID and Process ID has value in the customer set up record) 

 *  Given an account has a Customer Setup record in Submitted status, 

 *  When a user opens the account, 
 *  Then the Sales Skill field must be locked as read-only and cannot be changed by users. 
 

 

 

 

 *  Audit Logging 

 *  Given a user changes the Sales Skill prior to submission, 

 *  When the change is saved, 
 *  Then the system must log the previous and new values in the audit history for traceability. 
 

 

 

Business Requirements:

 *  Editable: Sales Skill must remain editable until Customer Setup reaches Submitted status. 
 *  Locked: Once Customer Setup is Submitted, Sales Skill must be locked for all users. 
 *  Sync: Any change prior to submission must update the global Sales Skill field and related mapping. 
 *  Audit: All Sales Skill changes prior to submission must be captured in audit history. 
 

Developer Notes:

 *  Implement form-level logic: 

 *  If CustomerSetup.Status != Submitted ? Sales Skill editable. 
 *  If CustomerSetup.Status = Submitted ? Sales Skill locked. 
 

 *  Add validation rule on save to enforce lock if attempted update occurs. 
 *  Ensure updates trigger re-filtering of district Sales Skill mapping prior to submission. 
 *  Leverage audit history (CRM standard audit or custom plugin if required) to capture old vs new values of Sales Skill. 
 *  Post-submission ? backend updates only allowed via integration (not end-user edits). 
 *  If a Customer Setup exists and not in Submitted status and if the users tries to update the sales skill on an account, there users should be alerted that a set up record exists and changing sales skill will impact downstream systems.

column6: Add Sales Skill Column to SOW Grid on H5 Account Tab
column11:
As a user viewing the Scope of Work (SOW) tab on an H5 account in the CRM app,
I need the grid to display a new Sales Skill column,
 
So that I can easily identify which SOW belongs to Water and which belongs to Hygiene.
 

 
The new Sales Skill column must be placed immediately after the Owner column in the grid.
 
The grid should continue to display existing fields in the current order: Name ? End Date ? Start Date ? Status ? Owner ? Sales Skill.
 
This change will improve user clarity by surfacing the business division context (Water/Hygiene) directly in the grid view without opening individual records.
column19: Moved out of state In Development
column22:

 *  Scenario 1 – Display Sales Skill for 1C SOW 

 *  Given a Scope of Work record is linked to a Sales Skill (Water or Hygiene), 
 *  When a user views the H5 account’s Scope of Work(Tab) grid, 
 *  Then the Sales Skill value is displayed in the Sales Skill column after the Owner column. 
 

 *  Scenario 2 – Display blank for non-1C SOW 

 *  Given a Scope of Work record has no Sales Skill linked (legacy/non-1C), 
 *  When a user views the H5 account’s Scope of Work grid, 
 *  Then the Sales Skill column is blank for that row. 
 

 *  Scenario 3 – Maintain existing column sequence 

 *  Given a user views the Scope of Work grid on an H5 account, 
 *  When the grid loads, 
 *  Then the column order is Name ? End Date ? Start Date ? Status ? Owner ? Sales Skill.

column6: Ability to select Sales Skill instead of Global Business
